headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Whirlpool Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Chris C
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Whirlpool Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Chris Conley.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturel
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturelli, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investor section of our website at whirlpoolcorp.com. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corporation's future expectations. Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed on our latest 10-K and our other periodic reports as well as on Slide 1 and in the appendix of this presentation. 
Turning to Slide 2. We went to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP financial measures. We believe these measures are important indicators of our operations as they exclude items that may not be indicative of, or are unrelated to, results from our ongoing business operations. We also think the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for analyzing trends in our ongoing business operations. Listeners are directed to the appendix section of our presentation beginning on Slide 36 for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record revenue, ongoing profit and earnings per share for full year 2015. Overall, our integration activities in Europe and Asia pro
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record revenue, ongoing profit and earnings per share for full year 2015. 
Overall, our integration activities in Europe and Asia progressed well and as planned, we delivered significant integration benefits, both in the fourth quarter and for the full year. Our ability to deliver these record results, despite significant volatility in the global economic environment, does demonstrate the strength of our execution and the benefits of our larger global operating platform. 
If you turn to Slide 5, I will review the 2015 financial results. What you see that we delivered strong revenue growth for the year, our revenues were up 5% versus last year and 18%, excluding currency impact. Our ongoing business earnings were a record $12.38 per share and as we expected, we delivered $620 million in free cash flow. 
Turning to Slide 6, you can see our priority -- our 2016 priorities in what we expect to be another record year. We do believe that the challenges we successfully managed in 2015 will carry over into 2016. And by that, we mean we expect the emerging markets will continue to be weak or decline but we do that largely offset by growth in our developed markets. We also anticipate that this strong dollar era that we're experiencing will continue into this year. So within this environment, our focus in 2016 is to continue to grow revenues and we see great opportunities to expand our operating margins. 
We plan to invest to grow globally in both our core appliance business and adjacent business us. We will deliver significant new product innovations in the market. And we continue to expect to deliver very strong cost productivity. 
So turning to Slide 7 where we show our guidance for 2016. We expect to deliver ongoing earnings per share of $14 to $14.75 a share, which represents 15% plus growth versus last year. We also expect free cash flow generation of between $700 million to $800 million, which is a substantial improvement versus the prior year. 
And while 2015 was a year where we faced several challenges, I think we were able to demonstrate our ability to create value for our shareholders through strong operational execution in this environment. in our current guidance reflects our expectation that this level of execution will continue as we do expect to deliver another year of record results in 2016. 
So at this point, I'd like to turn over to Marc Bitzer to review our global operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 9, we will review North America's performance in the fourth quarter. As emphasized in our last earnings call, our strategy in North America had not changed. We performed perfectly in line with our
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 9, we will review North America's performance in the fourth quarter. As emphasized in our last earnings call, our strategy in North America had not changed. We performed perfectly in line with our expectations as we grew revenues and substantially expanded margins in the fourth quarter. 
We grew our revenue 6.2%, excluding currency, and expanded operating margin to 12.4%, an all-time record. As expected, with our recently launched product fully available and nearly fully floored, the investments we made to drive growth in our U.S. business delivered sequential market share improvement in the fourth quarter. 
In addition to a leverage from its revenue growth, a very strong operating margins in the fourth quarter driven by our ongoing costs productivity activity program and favorable mix from our new product introductions, which more than offset nearly $30 million in unfavorable currency impact in Canada and Mexico.
Turning to Slide 10, we outlined our 2016 operation priorities for North America region. Our expectation is that the industry will continue to show strong 5% annual growth behind improved housing trends and consumer sentiment. And we expect to grow our revenues at or above industry levels. We also expect to continue accelerating growth of our new products to capitalize on this increased consumer and to drive improved price/mix and revenue growth. 
Our strong cost productivity programs will continue to drive margin improvement and remain focused on growing our type of core. We anticipate that these actions will more than offset a point of margin impact from negative currency based into days rate for the Canadian dollar and Mexican peso. We expect to deliver operating margins between 11.5% to 12.5%, which is fully in line with our long-term goals and a number of improvements over prior year. 
I will now share the fourth quarter results for our Europe, Middle East and Africa region as shown on Slide 11. Sales were $1.5 billion compared to $1.7 billion in the prior year. Excluding currencies, sales were up 8.1%. Ongoing operating profit was $88 million compared to $101 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
During the fourth quarter, strong execution of our integration plans and ongoing cost productivity mostly offset $45 million in unfavorable currency impact as well as the impact of a significant industry decline in Russia. 
Last year, we saw an unusually strong fourth quarter as trailing consumers bought heavily of the devaluation. As planned, and expected, we also met the marketing technology and product this quarter. 
For the full year, we delivered 4.5% operating margin, which is fully consistent with our guidance at the beginning of the year, in spite of $160 million in currency impact and weaker demand in Eastern Europe. 
On Slide 12, as [indiscernible] the full year 2016, our priorities remains unchanged with a strong focus on integration activities, ongoing cost productivities and growth from new products both within and beyond the core. We expect industry to be approximately flat to 2%, primarily driven by continued strong demand in Western Europe. 
Based on today's rates, weakness in the ruble and Europe will continue, but we plan to more than offset over point of margin impact from currency through ongoing cost productivity and acquisition synergies. Overall, we expect operating margins to be between 7% and 8% for the year, which is a number substantial year-over-year improvement and very consistent and even ahead of our long-term goals. 
Now we'll discuss our Latin America results on Slide 13. Sales for the quarter were $845 million, excluding the impact of currencies, sales decreased 8%. 
Our operating profit for the quarter totaled $58 million or nearly 7% of sales, which represents a substantial improvement in operating margin versus the prior 2 quarters. These margin levels are a clear indication that we have readjusted our business for today's operating environment through already deployed price, mix actions and cost and capacity reductions. 
On Slide 14, we summarized our priorities in Latin America. We expect demand from continued volatility and are fully prepared to deploy further actions necessary. We will continue to invest in new products, grow our business out of Brazil core appliances and are well positioned to capitalize growth in Brazil then demand does return. 
We expect industry decline of 10% and based on today's rate, 0.5 point of margin impact from currency primarily in the first half of the year. 
For growth in our non-Brazil operations, the benefit of previously announced cost base price increases, implemented reduction of fixed costs and improved mix from our new products, we expect to mitigate both currency and demand impact. 
Based on our expectation of demand down 10% and the Brazilian real at current spot rates and disadvantages of our offsetting actions for 2016, we expect operating margins between 6.5% and 7.5%, despite lower revenue due to the currency and emerging market demand. 
Now let's turn to our fourth quarter results in the Asia region, which are shown on Slide 15. Net sales were $312 million in comparison to $282 million in the prior year period. Excluding the impact of currency, our sales increased 15%. 
Our fourth quarter ongoing operating profit was $11 million compared to $17 million in the prior year period. Ongoing operating margin of 3.6% driven by record margins in India and integration benefits in China that were offset by weak demand and increased product and marketing mix. While these investments in China temporarily reduced our margins in the fourth quarter, we expect them to lead to strong growth in margins in the future. 
Turning to Slide 16, we're sharing our 2016 priorities for Asia operations. We will continue to focus on [indiscernible] expansion and ongoing cost productivity programs. Our expectations for flat industry growth in the region. For additional clarity about our assumptions, we are forecasting a 5% industry growth in India and a 2% to 3% industry decline in China. Overall, we expect strong margin performance of 7% to 8%, driven by our larger growth platforms and the benefits of our strong innovation pipeline. 
For Slide 17, we summarized our regional margin goals. We expect 2016 to be another year of record performance and see opportunities for a strong margin expansions in all regions. 
And now, I'd like to turn it over to Larry.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we had a solid year of performance. You may recall that we entered the year with significant currency headwinds and weakened emerging market demand. Given these challenges, our first half ongoin
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we had a solid year of performance. You may recall that we entered the year with significant currency headwinds and weakened emerging market demand. Given these challenges, our first half ongoing earnings of approximately $4.85 per share for flat with 2014. However, based on the actions we took throughout the year, we were able to deliver second half ongoing earnings of $7.55 per share, which is up 15% from last year's results. Our second half earnings momentum and our fourth quarter run rate entering 2016 are solid. 
Turning to our fourth quarter results on Slide 19 and 20, revenues were $5.6 billion. Currency had a $700 million top line impact, but excluding currency, sales were up 4%. 
We achieved all-time record ongoing earnings of $4.10 per share, driven by acquisition synergies and ongoing cost productivity programs, as well as price/mix from new product introductions and previously announced cost base price actions. 
You'll note from the slide that SG&A as percent of sales on a GAAP basis decreased approximately 1.5 points. While we make incrementally higher marketing investment this year to support our product introductions, those were more than offset by acquisition synergies and a planned reduction in acquisition-related costs. 
Our effective tax rate for the year was under 21%. This represents approximately a $0.20 improvement versus our prior full year guidance. 
In summary, we are pleased with the results for the quarter. 
Now turning to 2016. We expect another record year. We will continue to be impacted by currency and emerging market demand. However, we are confident in the actions we are taking to offset these headwinds, and deliver 15-percent plus earnings per share growth in 2016. 
First, on Slide 21, you can see that we absorbed nearly $6 from the combination of emerging market demand weakness and currency devaluation in 2015. As Marc discussed in the regional reviews, our operational focus and additional actions to deployed during the year drove record revenue and earnings performance, despite these challenges. 
Now turning to Slide 22, we share the 2016 assumptions for emerging market demand and currency headwinds included in our guidance. As Jeff mentioned, based on current exchange rates, we expect currency devaluation to continue, although at a reduced level compared to the prior year. Accordingly, we anticipate a negative impact of approximately $1 billion in sales and $2.50 in earnings per share from currency headwinds. Additionally, we're anticipating continued demand weakness in most emerging markets. As a result, we will offset $0.50 in earnings per share impact from that. 
It's important to note that these emerging market countries now represents 15% of our global sales. 
Finally, on Slide 23 and 25, we summarized key actions that we expect will offset the impact from currency and emerging market demand. We expect another very strong year in total cost productivity given material trends, fixed cost reductions taken in Brazil and our normal productivity programs. Our acquisition synergies tied to cost and capacity reduction activities will ramp-up during 2016. We expect solid demand trends in developed markets, combined with positive impact from previous and new product launches and growth in adjacent businesses. And our previously announced cost base price increases in Canada, Brazil and Russia are in full effect. 
On Slide 24, you can see an update on the progress of our restructuring and acquisition integration activities. We incurred $200 million in restructuring expense and delivered $200 million in benefits this year, consistent with previous communications. For 2016, we expect $250 million in expense and continue to expect $175 million in benefits. 
On Slide 26, we highly the cadence of half 1 versus half 2 earnings drivers we just discussed. First, given historical seasonality, volume is stronger in the second half of the year. In addition, we should have lower currency headwinds in the back half of the year based on current rates. Traditionally, we see much stronger seasonality in our cost productivity programs in the second half of the year and our acquisition synergies will ramp-up throughout the year. As a result, we would expect full year earnings seasonality to approximate 40% in the first half and 60% in the second half. 
On Slide 27, our 2016 guidance should deliver ongoing earnings of $14 to $14.75 per share, a 15% increase year-over-year. We are forecasting approximately $700 million to $800 million in free cash flow, which includes planned cash outlays of up to $200 million in restructuring related to acquisitions, $150 million related to our previously announced product warranty cost to Europe and capital spending of between $700 million to $750 million. 
Our priority for cash deployment have not changed as shown on Slide 28. We did repurchased $155 million of stock during the fourth quarter and have $225 million remaining on our existing authorization. We expect to complete our current share repurchase authorization this year. 
Now I'd like to turn it back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. I'd now like to take a moment to update you on our long-range goals that we first outlined at our December 2014 Investor Day conference. Overall, our long-term strategy remains on track and we see tremendous opportunities from our larger
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. I'd now like to take a moment to update you on our long-range goals that we first outlined at our December 2014 Investor Day conference. 
Overall, our long-term strategy remains on track and we see tremendous opportunities from our larger global footprint, our leading position in key markets around the world, our continuation of stepping up levels of new product innovation, our strong brand portfolio with 7 powerful brands, each with over $1 billion in revenues and over the mid- to longer term, we do believe that our leading positions in several key emerging markets will be a great advantage for us. 
So then turning to Slide 31, I would like to summarize our updated management goals. And again, as we discussed earlier last year and carry over to this year, we are -- have been hit by declines in emerging market demands and significant currency devaluation. And this is really the only driver of our change in goals because this has had a large impact on our original sales goals. As a result, we now believe we can grow our revenues to $23 billion to $24 billion in net sales by 2018 versus over previous growth of $26 billion to $28 billion. And again, the difference essentially all purely from currency translation. Because we have rapidly adjusted to the changed global environment from our previously announced cost base price increases, fixed cost reductions and continued investment in new product innovation. And we will continue to do so as we go forward. 
We are offsetting these impacts previously discussed with what I believe is very strong operational execution. And as a result, we still expect to deliver operating margins, consistent with our 2018 goals. So we haven't changed our view at all that we can deliver double-digit operating margins globally. And with that, we expect to reach also our goal of doubling our free cash flow by 2018. 
In total, this will lead to strong earnings growth and we know plan to deliver strong growth in earnings per share to $20 to $22 per share in 2018. Again, the difference between this and the previous is simply a reduction in revenues due to currency. 
These revised targets would represents an improvement of 60% to 80% of our today's levels of earnings and represent exceptionally strong value accretion. 
As always, there are risks of us putting out long-range goals like this. But I think as we've demonstrated to last year, we have been able to adjust the environment and still deliver strong results. 
So turning to Slide 32. You can very specifically see the drivers in our ongoing earnings per share improvements. And again, we have multiple paths to drive value creation. We'll drive it through growth, acquisition synergies and cost productivities and these big levers that we outlined in December of 2014 have not changed. We are on track with our acquisition synergies in Europe and we expect an additional $2 to $3 per share in benefits by 2018. 
We are assuming demand in emerging markets like Brazil, Russia and China begin to stabilize in 2017, but likely only drive moderate recovery growth during this panning fighting cycle and we don't expect to see that until 2018. Additionally, demand in the U.S. is rebounding, consistent with our Investor Day assumptions, and we continue to see solid growth in our adjacent businesses. 
We also now are seeing more and more growth, which is enabled by our [indiscernible] and China acquisitions, which are now part of our baseline revenue assumptions. 
And finally, and importantly, from a cost productivity perspective, we fully expect to continue with strong ongoing annual productivity improvements in addition to the benefits from favorable input cost that we're currently seeing and we see great opportunities to further leverage benefits from our global operating platform. And I think over the last couple years, we've had a good a track record of delivering on those types of the benefits. 
So to sum up, we do expect to grow our earnings per share by nearly 60% to 80% over the next 3 years to between $20 and $22 per share. 
And then on Slide 33, you can see the walk on how we expect to double our free cash flow. And as you can see from this chart, cash flow growth is largely earnings driven. Working capital is just a bit higher due to growth in the business. We don't expect any fundamental changes in our rate of capital expenditures, which run about 3.5% and this has not changed. 
So turning to Slide 34, I just reconfirm, we are committed to achieving our vision of becoming the best global brand and consumer products company. As a reminder, we are #1 globally in 3 out of the 4 regions in the world. We're the largest Western company in Asia. We have a top market position in 5 of the top 7 largest appliance markets in Europe, and we also have the #1 position in the U.S., Canada and Brazil. 
So in total, we have a very high confidence in our growth plans give us an outstanding opportunity to continue driving significant shareholder returns. And we believe 2016 will be a strong step forward towards reaching our 2018 goals. 
So with that, I will end our formal remarks and we would like to open it up for questions.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We can take our first question from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We can take our first question from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got a couple of questions here. First off, regarding Latin America, Jeff, you're going to be looking at a margin up 1% or 2% a year-on-year on obviously continued very challenging times. You don't normally do this, but can you help us with what you're mar
componenttext: Got a couple of questions here. First off, regarding Latin America, Jeff, you're going to be looking at a margin up 1% or 2% a year-on-year on obviously continued very challenging times. You don't normally do this, but can you help us with what you're margin expectations are for the subcomponents of that region for the Brazilian white goods in [indiscernible] and the non-Brazilian white goods just to get a sense of what that margin growth means year-on-year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sammy, I mean just break that out, we don't give you specific, but I'll give you directionally. I mean, there are 3 or, perhaps, 4 segments you can look in that business. The most impacted for all the reasons we talked about, is the Brazilian appliance bu
componenttext: Sammy, I mean just break that out, we don't give you specific, but I'll give you directionally. I mean, there are 3 or, perhaps, 4 segments you can look in that business. The most impacted for all the reasons we talked about, is the Brazilian appliance business because of the currency, because demand being down almost 25% with the expectations -- so that where the heavy hit. But I would say, and I think I said this before, we've been in Brazil market for over 60 years, and we've never lost money in that market. And we continue to be in a positive profit position. So even in that tough situation, but our margins were hurt very badly in appliances. In our adjacent businesses, other than offsetting the inflation, they've remained intact. In Broco, which is our global compressor business, was hurt by demand in emerging markets and currency, but not nearly as much, and we had a reasonably good year in Broco. And [indiscernible] international, I would just say that it got hit by all the same currency -- the currency devaluations came at different times. We have a big position, for example, in Columbia. Columbia peso has devalued by 50%. Late in the year, Argentina obviously, devalued. So we adjust, but there's a larger basket of countries to do so. So those margins, although hurt some were not hurt as bad. So the predominant work, I would say has been to do, which we've already announced, the cost base price increases, which we've already announced and carry over into this year, we've done significant fixed cost reduction, almost 30%, I think. We drive the heck out of productivity, but we still have to offset inflation and negative demand. And I think Marc said it exactly correct. If you based on our assumption of today's spot and currency and the market going down another 10%, we feel pretty good about our ability to improve our margins. If we have another round of volatility, we'll have to adjust again and we are fully prepared to do that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd to add to Jeff is Sam, is just remember that pricing increases went into effect throughout last year. Production -- fixed cost reductions were taken throughout last year, so you still haven't seen the full run rate in the margins in
componenttext: And the only thing I'd to add to Jeff is Sam, is just remember that pricing increases went into effect throughout last year. Production -- fixed cost reductions were taken throughout last year, so you still haven't seen the full run rate in the margins in the fourth quarter exit rate.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two more quick questions, if I could are housekeeping-related. First off, the fourth quarter, your free cash flow was below where your guidance was, the implied guidance. Now is some of that is, I think, is pension contribution, some of it has maybe made
componenttext: Two more quick questions, if I could are housekeeping-related. First off, the fourth quarter, your free cash flow was below where your guidance was, the implied guidance. Now is some of that is, I think, is pension contribution, some of it has maybe made it little lower CapEx, but it doesn't explain the entirety of the variance, Larry. Could you help us with what happened in free cash flow in the fourth quarter?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, Sam, I think we guided to $600 million to $700 million. I believe we ended up at $620 million. So pretty close to the midpoint. I'd say that working capital was a little bit higher but that was more due to timing in receivables than anything
componenttext: No, I think, Sam, I think we guided to $600 million to $700 million. I believe we ended up at $620 million. So pretty close to the midpoint. I'd say that working capital was a little bit higher but that was more due to timing in receivables than anything else. So I think we were very happy where we work we ended up and pretty much consistent with our guidance.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the last question, as it relates to '16 guidance, could you help us with what your expectations are for raw materials and tax and pensions and some of the other below the line items?
componenttext: And the last question, as it relates to '16 guidance, could you help us with what your expectations are for raw materials and tax and pensions and some of the other below the line items?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can help you with some of the below line items, Sam. Tax rate in the prepared remarks we said 22% to 24%. And then you also about asked pension. We will not have a pension contribution this year. We're fully funded from a funding perspective. So you'll
componenttext: I can help you with some of the below line items, Sam. Tax rate in the prepared remarks we said 22% to 24%. And then you also about asked pension. We will not have a pension contribution this year. We're fully funded from a funding perspective. So you'll not see a U.S. contribution this year. You'll see a small amount, then we'll go for the foreign plans.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Sam, on the cost side, if you look at the walk that Larry provided for the margins, I think the way I would look at costs are, we're going to have a very significant cost year this year. And we do look at total cost, which is comprised of our syn
componenttext: Yes, and Sam, on the cost side, if you look at the walk that Larry provided for the margins, I think the way I would look at costs are, we're going to have a very significant cost year this year. And we do look at total cost, which is comprised of our synergies, our restructuring, as well as our ongoing productivity, which includes change in raw material costs. And as we talk about -- and by the way, we think that, that's the best way to look at it because that gives you the net number, which you ought to expect to see in the P&L or in the margins, which is what we show. The challenge talking about, which caused a little bit of confusion last year is when you have this of volatility in currency, we certainly saw net material cost last year, I think we said over $100 million. But we also had -- part of that -- the actual gross number was higher than that, but it's offset by currency increases in markets like Brazil, Russia and so and so forth. So bottom line is, we're going to have a big year of productivity. If you look at the margin walk, it's roughly between all of those factors, it's about a $400 million reduction, of which, I would suspect net, and it really depends on currency raw material ought to be -- we ought to expect same kind of improvement that we saw this year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you guys, and maybe Marc, could touch on the North American market. It looks like you guys got 3% volume. I wanted to also understand your assumptions, the press release says 5% growth. How do you think about volumes going into '16? And with
componenttext: I was hoping you guys, and maybe Marc, could touch on the North American market. It looks like you guys got 3% volume. I wanted to also understand your assumptions, the press release says 5% growth. How do you think about volumes going into '16? And with that, I noticed price is slightly more than 3 points North America. That's probably something I wasn't expecting to that extent of strength. What's the promotional environment like? And what are your expectations for volume in '16 in North America?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob it's Marc, let me try to answer these multiple questions. Let me actually start this -- first off by saying, we're very pleased with our North America Q4. And I know there were some concerns out there but these results would have quite a lot of concer
componenttext: Bob it's Marc, let me try to answer these multiple questions. Let me actually start this -- first off by saying, we're very pleased with our North America Q4. And I know there were some concerns out there but these results would have quite a lot of concern. Let me, first of all, on the units, because you mentioned the 3% unit. First of all, and we said that in a number of previous call, our unit shipments are not comparable to what is AHAM published numbers because we include a lot more now units. So the numbers are not fully comparable. Having said that, what you can compare is our unit growth versus our organic excess growth, so the 3% versus 6%. And you're exactly right, I mean, that shows just how strong our price/mix was, which is the full result of disciplined promotion management and finally, results of our new product introductions. So to have that kind of lists in such a promotion environment is an achievement that we're very proud of. Now let me put it in broader context off the fourth quarter. Again, we delivered good ex currency growth 6%, record margin of 12.4%, which is exactly what we said we would do, drive growth and margin expansion. What is also important to note, we had ex currency revenue growth in all our business units, so Canada, Mexico, more domestic, major store appliances, which also means, we had sequential market share growth Q4 compared to Q3, which is something which we've been driving for very hard. So now with regards to your question about our expectations next year's market. As you know, we guide industry to 5%. As I also said in my prepared remarks, we fully expect to grow our revenue in line or above that market assumption. That's what we guide. That's our expectation based on run rate in which we have developed, based on new product introductions. So we're -- I think we'd say very confident behind these assumptions. Towards -- the comment towards broader industry assumption about 5%. As you know, as we guided in 2015, we initially came out before and we lift it to 5%, 5 plus  percent, [indiscernible] 6.5%. Beginning of the year many people question if North America would come to this group levels and North America, as an industry, did. [indiscernible] largely driven, the confidence of 5% is we still do believe the housing is as best the midpoint of a housing recovery in terms of cycle. We do see consumer sentiment becoming bigger. We do see wealth creation on the mid- and lower income level. So all these factors, if you put it in our macroeconomic model, you have a lot of confidence behind the 5% industry growth.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That makes a lot of sense. And thanks for the detail on North America. Kind of jump on in terms of question. I'd love to understand 2 things. One, the margin walk between 2015 and 2016 in Europe to get to that 7% to 8% range, what's your confidenc
componenttext: Got it. That makes a lot of sense. And thanks for the detail on North America. Kind of jump on in terms of question. I'd love to understand 2 things. One, the margin walk between 2015 and 2016 in Europe to get to that 7% to 8% range, what's your confidence in executing against plan? And putting aside the fact that we understand things change quickly in emerging markets, what's the likelihood that you can actually achieve positive margin momentum in Latin America? And are You confident that Brazil will not lose money? That's a lot of stuff but if you could just take it apart, that would be great.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bob it's Marc again. So let me answer first answer Europe and Middle East and Africa. As you know, we guided at the beginning of '15 to 4% to 5% and with exactly the midpoint. I would say probably not some people maybe surprised but we're guiding now t
componenttext: So Bob it's Marc again. So let me answer first answer Europe and Middle East and Africa. As you know, we guided at the beginning of '15 to 4% to 5% and with exactly the midpoint. I would say probably not some people maybe surprised but we're guiding now towards 7% or 8%, which as you recall, that was pretty much our targets in Investor Day. We are fully confident in the mid- 7% to 8% and the confidence comes from we do see the benefits from restructuring synergies and ongoing cost productivity. So as you know, when you're running a business, you have confidence in cost, that gives you a lot of confidence. It's just much more predicable than any top line assumptions. And if you look at '15, that was largely total cost driven and we know we have momentum, we know we have agreement on certain restructuring activities and that carries into '16. You will also note that our volume assumption for industry is actually not overly bullish, it's 0% to 2%. And frankly, that magnitude between 0% and 2% is entirely driven by what happens to Russia. So we basically, we're not overly bullish on Prussia. If Russia comes around faster but we've seen in prior decades and cycles, then you could see an offset versus 2%, that's the big assumption right now. But again, in Europe, in our view, on our [indiscernible] clockworks and that gives us a lot of confidence for '16 as well. On Latin America, [indiscernible] Jeff's comments. First of all, let me underline Latin America is obviously heavily influenced by what assumption take on Brazil industry growth and real. So on today's spot rates of real and with the assumption that Brazil goes down another 10%, which pretty much will be consistent with what we see right now, so this year region of the marketplace based on our taking cost actions and price/mix, which we have already deployed, we are very confident that 6.5% to 7%, which is, by the way, is not too far away from what we had in Q4. So it's not like we, from a run rate perspective, it's not like we're planning for huge step up. But again, I want to reiterate that the big assumption about the real exchange rates, and we've seen dramatic moves this year and it's the biggest assumption about the industry.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and to only add color on that that Marc had was that this 10% decline is our forecast for demand for the year in Brazil. If you look at the progression of decline throughout 2015, the fourth quarter was the worst that almost 25%. So as this carries o
componenttext: Yes, and to only add color on that that Marc had was that this 10% decline is our forecast for demand for the year in Brazil. If you look at the progression of decline throughout 2015, the fourth quarter was the worst that almost 25%. So as this carries over, our [indiscernible] is to full year probably plus or minus, minus 10%. But by definition, it'll be higher in Q1 and Q2.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Denise Chai from Bank of America.

componenttext: Just want to go back to North America. Can you talk a little bit about how market share has shifted in the last year? And also comment on the impact of product transitions on product availability in the past year because I think Marc said that the new products were fully available and almost fully floored. So just wondering, when that's going to be resolved.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Denise, it's Marc, let me try to answer that. So first of all, as I indicated, in Q4, we had sequential market share growth. On a year-over-year comparison, we had a slight market share loss that's basic of a carryforward of momentum, which we had from
componenttext: So Denise, it's Marc, let me try to answer that. So first of all, as I indicated, in Q4, we had sequential market share growth. On a year-over-year comparison, we had a slight market share loss that's basic of a carryforward of momentum, which we had from a mid-cycle. But again, the important thing is sequentially, we see the business growing in the [indiscernible  categories. Now that is a very important element of this one. To my earlier comment about product introductions, as you were well aware, we had a lot the product introductions the last 18 months in North America, there was laundry, there was pretty much the entire refrigeration line, which was driven by energy standards. So we had -- we are behind unusual higher high amount of product introductions, which, of course, always has a certain impact on the top line. It's not just availability, it's just the ramp-up, ramp down, reflooring. And whenever you do that, you'll have this impact. The availability supply chain for [indiscernible] is fully restored. We're not yet 100% complete with the flooring, but it's pretty much 80% to 90% done on the major product introductions.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up on the realized synergies in 2015?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up on the realized synergies in 2015?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we said Denise, in the prepared remarks  between restructuring and synergies, we had about $200 million. We're very consistent with what we said before. And synergies on both the Europe and Chinese business came in exactly what we said.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we said Denise, in the prepared remarks  between restructuring and synergies, we had about $200 million. We're very consistent with what we said before. And synergies on both the Europe and Chinese business came in exactly what we said.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Megan McGrath with MKM Partners.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a quick follow-up on North America. In terms of the competitive environment, could you just give us an update on that, certainly don't expect you to say that it got a lot better. But was there any change, you talked a lot about the breadth versus
componenttext: So just a quick follow-up on North America. In terms of the competitive environment, could you just give us an update on that, certainly don't expect you to say that it got a lot better. But was there any change, you talked a lot about the breadth versus the depth of the promotions that you saw starting last summer. And any early indications in this -- in the early part of the year about what you're seeing there?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc. Let me try to answer. During our last earnings call, we said we had a slightly elevated promotion intensity out there in the markets. And I would say that was pretty much consistent in Q4. In our -- in that environment, we stuck to plans
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc. Let me try to answer. During our last earnings call, we said we had a slightly elevated promotion intensity out there in the markets. And I would say that was pretty much consistent in Q4. In our -- in that environment, we stuck to plans, which we had for the last couple of years, we participate and create value for our brands and our company, and that's what we've done. So in that promotional environment, which year-over-year was maybe slightly more intense, we basically fully relied on our new products. That's what drove the margin and the price/mix impact, better environment. It's hard to, of course, anticipate what happens in '16, and it's way too early in the year, but right now, we'll expect similar environment like the back half '15.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I want to touch on Asia because it's the one region no one asked about yet. But can you talk about all through the nice gardens that you have out there for the full year but 4Q did dropped off you said you increased some exp
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I want to touch on Asia because it's the one region no one asked about yet. But can you talk about all through the nice gardens that you have out there for the full year but 4Q did dropped off you said you increased some expenses on marketing and other investments in the quarter. Is there any seasonality involved that we should think about when we're modeling 2016? And could you maybe talk us through some of those investments that you made? Or any of those carry over into let's say, the first part of 2016 as well?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc again. Again, conceptually, we got to split the Asia business into a large, the India and the China business and some of our smaller business. Our India business is in, which is probably a publicly traded company, is in a very good shape,
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc again. Again, conceptually, we got to split the Asia business into a large, the India and the China business and some of our smaller business. Our India business is in, which is probably a publicly traded company, is in a very good shape, strong margins, steady margins and they head off to a really strong Q4. In China, we had a, I wouldn't call it seasonality, it's an anomaly. I mean, we basically had a onetime investment in certainly go-to-markets and particularly, in certain technology investments, which are largely related to introduction of new washes, which come to the market in April. So I would not factor that in an ongoing model because we know it's largely onetime expenses.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Samuel Eisner with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just going back to the China, as I think there was some commentary that was given there where you guys are expecting down volumes for that market. Can you talk a little bit about how the integration of transaction [indiscernible] such a large part of t
componenttext: So just going back to the China, as I think there was some commentary that was given there where you guys are expecting down volumes for that market. Can you talk a little bit about how the integration of transaction [indiscernible] such a large part of that market, just kind of when that help out the overall volumes of the market? Just want to better understand what you're seeing on the ground level.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc. Again, China as j,a market, as a single market, from an industry perspective, did not grow in '15 and, in fact, was down on the T2 level by minus 2%. We, in our prepared remarks guided towards -3% for next year. So a pretty, by and large,
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc. Again, China as j,a market, as a single market, from an industry perspective, did not grow in '15 and, in fact, was down on the T2 level by minus 2%. We, in our prepared remarks guided towards -3% for next year. So a pretty, by and large, similar environment in China overall. We just don't see right now the consumer sentiment and the housing to be strong enough to hit into positive territories. Of course, that can change in the context, but right now, that's our assumption going into the '16 year. And that is also based on a fairly [indiscernible] from trade partners, so that's what it is, which, of course, is a change compared 2 or 3 years ago, but I think we have a way to operate in that environment. The integration overall is successful. And of course, there's a lot of work. And as you put together different brands, but it is successful, it is on track. And we're kind of, as you see from the guidance, we're guiding towards 7% to 8% for '16, which by definition cannot only come from India. We anticipate also strong progress on our, not only synergy from cost side, but also from a revenue synergies on the China piece of integration.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's helpful. And then just switching gears back just to North America. Can you just give a comment about how inventors stand right now in the channel? What are your retailers showing? There was some chatter in the fourth quarter about there is a goo
componenttext: So that's helpful. And then just switching gears back just to North America. Can you just give a comment about how inventors stand right now in the channel? What are your retailers showing? There was some chatter in the fourth quarter about there is a good amount of sell-in to [indiscernible] so just curious what you guys are seeing out there at the retail level?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam it's Marc, again. I mean, again, if you take Q4 as an industry and there are, first of all, there is not fully reliable sell-in, sell-outs statistics for North America, so that's based on the data, which we've seen how we triangulate it. You alwa
componenttext: Yes, Sam it's Marc, again. I mean, again, if you take Q4 as an industry and there are, first of all, there is not fully reliable sell-in, sell-outs statistics for North America, so that's based on the data, which we've seen how we triangulate it. You always have in Q4 the beginning, a heavy sell-in that suggest into a promotion period. If you just look at the quarter overall, we do not see elevated inventory level as the year begins. If, at all, I would almost argue the opposite. In the retail inventories are not significantly elevated as the year begins. It's a pretty normal situation. But yes, there was quite a bit of loading to promotions in October, November.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And our next question games from James McCanless with Sterne Agee.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: With T being potentially being sold to another buyer, are you seeing any impact on the ground either in North America or in the Chinese market as that deal progresses? And if so, what steps are you taking to get in front of that?
componenttext: With T being potentially being sold to another buyer, are you seeing any impact on the ground either in North America or in the Chinese market as that deal progresses? And if so, what steps are you taking to get in front of that?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jay, this is Jeff. The question about, are we seeing anything in the market, in either market, I think the answer is no. The GE business, you know the story. I mean, they made an agreement with Electrolux, time expired, it didn't go through. It's clear, a
componenttext: Jay, this is Jeff. The question about, are we seeing anything in the market, in either market, I think the answer is no. The GE business, you know the story. I mean, they made an agreement with Electrolux, time expired, it didn't go through. It's clear, and it's been clear for some time that the General Electric would sell their appliance business. So the global people that you would expect to look at it had plenty of time to look at it. And obviously, they wind up get a substantially improved offer from [indiscernible]. And so from that standpoint, they'll go through the process and we'll know in 4, 5, 6 months how that's going to turn not. But the question is, have we seen any changes? No. I mean, we compete with both companies. Ours is a very substantial competitor in China, very successful and this created value doing that, generally General Electric has been a very good and tough competitor in the U.S. for forever. So Chinese companies haven't -- willing to have a good market position in the U.S. so this is attractive opportunity. And today apparently a great. And that's why we they went to pay the price they did.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And thank you for that. The second question I have and I think you guys touched on this earlier, just with the decelerating year-over-year increase in North American units, do you feel like you're on the cusp of changing that either growth and hous
componenttext: Great. And thank you for that. The second question I have and I think you guys touched on this earlier, just with the decelerating year-over-year increase in North American units, do you feel like you're on the cusp of changing that either growth and housing starts or a pickup in renovation remodel? And I apologize if I missed it, but if you all could comment and where unit growth should go in North America, especially in the U.S.?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jay, it's a Marc. I wouldn't read too much into our guidance of 5 versus the 6 of this year. I wouldn't call that it a deceleration. I think it's a -- the 5 of the midpoint of the spectrum, which is probably you can put 4 to 6 or maybe even 4 to 7, whatev
componenttext: Jay, it's a Marc. I wouldn't read too much into our guidance of 5 versus the 6 of this year. I wouldn't call that it a deceleration. I think it's a -- the 5 of the midpoint of the spectrum, which is probably you can put 4 to 6 or maybe even 4 to 7, whatever, and a lot is driven by the housing consumer sentiment. So I would not -- I would still refer to U.S. is midpoint of a recovery cycle, of a long-term recovery cycle. I don't see the end of the cycle. I don't see a deceleration. And there's still -- 5 is not a precise number, it's a range and it could be well be 6 at the end of the year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jay, we didn't include it in this deck, but I think we have it in our Investor Day that you -- site that -- what we outlined actually 3 years ago was, particularly in the case of the U.S., where the industry demand was relative to our 30-year cycle --
componenttext: And Jay, we didn't include it in this deck, but I think we have it in our Investor Day that you -- site that -- what we outlined actually 3 years ago was, particularly in the case of the U.S., where the industry demand was relative to our 30-year cycle -- 30-year average. And basically, the bubble of 2003, 2005, the decline, the financial recessions, so on and so forth and we kind of laid out what we thought was a reasonable path of recovery and to Marc's point, we view -- we're in the midpoint. And if you look the last 3 years, I would say, our forecast, were actually pretty good, plus or minus 1 point, I think. And we're still underneath 30-year growth rate trend in the United States. So we still have, in our opinion, pent-up demand, as well as every piece of the drivers of demand, replacement, new housing, existing home sales, and discretionary are going in the right direction. So we view it as a very spot and to Marc's point, it could be 5, it could 4, it could be 6.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ken Zener from KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Zener from KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of slides in the deck there. In Europe, considering that is such an important acquisition and profit driver, can you get, you talked about cost restructuring, can you get a little bit more granular, is it such on the execution of the cost side that
componenttext: A lot of slides in the deck there. In Europe, considering that is such an important acquisition and profit driver, can you get, you talked about cost restructuring, can you get a little bit more granular, is it such on the execution of the cost side that you're expanding the margins? Are you actually -- can you describe the, perhaps, in-country dynamic that you're experiencing with this larger portfolio, I mean, are you able to get that acquisitions with the key retailers in countries? Or what else is driving this given the realization of this margin I '16, it seems to indicate, in fact, you might be realizing higher margins longer term than you guided here that long-term guidance?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Marc. Let me first try to explain what happened in '15 and then maybe give an indication for '16 and how that lead dynamics come together. If we just look at the full year P&L in Europe, you'll realize there's -- if you take up a currency impact
componenttext: Ken, it's Marc. Let me first try to explain what happened in '15 and then maybe give an indication for '16 and how that lead dynamics come together. If we just look at the full year P&L in Europe, you'll realize there's -- if you take up a currency impact, there's a small revenue growth, but the margin growth expansion came largely from the cost side, to be very straightforward. And the cost side, on the other hand, yes, there's some ongoing productivity coming from raw materials, which indicates Europe is largely offset through net currency, that's a transactional impact. So the net [indiscernible] comes largely from realizing the synergies in procurement, in footprint, in SG&A. So if you want to say, '15 was largely a restructuring and synergy [indiscernible]. It is important to note that the fact that we held the top line in year 1 in a post merger integration is a big deal because [indiscernible] see in such competitive environment that you're being attacked from all sides. And we even grow it. And some people asked us about the different pieces. Even if you won't break down the 2 legacy business, both elements grow organically, which again is a big deal in year 1 of such a complex integration. Now shifting gears into '16, again, the cost side are carryover benefits and certain restructuring initiatives, which we have just initiated and announced. So that just gives you unusual high amount of confidence because you're not relying on certain raw material assumptions, whatever, it's in your control. And I would say off margin improvement and profit in Europe for '16, it's still 70% to 80% is cost-driven. Now you come -- ultimately, comes back to the question, how much revenue growth can you drive at that brand and product portfolio. I would expect, and I'll come back to more Jeff's point, the long-term plan, in the planning horizon, it's '17, '18, that's when you start revenue growth coming in. For the simple that one it just takes awhile to have all these product platform integration plans because that's the most complicated process. And you see, we already put a lot of products down in the market. The vast majority of a new joint product basically comes '17 and '18. And that's when you should expect the top line growth. Even in the interim and that's the important thing is as one of our biggest attractions [indiscernible] why we bought this is strong country position. There is some with #1 in 5 out of the 7 markets and may [indiscernible] very all transparency [indiscernible]  our market share told by the markets has held up or even expanded in the last years. So that's a very, very important achievement for us.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Jeff, and then given all the product transitions and rollouts that you had this year, I mean, in one of the conference calls, 1 or 2 quarters ago you said it's hindsight perhaps you wouldn't have had so many moving parts at one time. Are there any o
componenttext: Okay. Jeff, and then given all the product transitions and rollouts that you had this year, I mean, in one of the conference calls, 1 or 2 quarters ago you said it's hindsight perhaps you wouldn't have had so many moving parts at one time. Are there any operational/execution issues that you could -- that are happening in '16, I mean, could we be aware of that, that you're a little bit more focused on just so we don't find out that you're worried about it in hindsight?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, if I can't really simplify. I'll give you a couple of perspectives. We did have and we talked about some very, very large new product transitions, which affected millions of volumes -- millions of units of volumes, okay? We always have product transi
componenttext: Ken, if I can't really simplify. I'll give you a couple of perspectives. We did have and we talked about some very, very large new product transitions, which affected millions of volumes -- millions of units of volumes, okay? We always have product transitions, so that is not new. And I would say, if the rest of the world was somewhat stable, that you wouldn't even probably even notice the impact of the product transition problems we had last year. But the fact of the matter is, we had, and the way I described it, the currency devaluation, and it's part a lie, but it is the most impacted movement currencies we've seen ever since we track currency. It costs us over $4 a share. And at the same time, Latin America -- emerging markets, in general, particularly Latin America, it seems like a long time ago, but in 2014, we had an all-time record year in Latin America. Last year, 1 year, our earnings were down by $300 million and cash was down by $300 million. We had record years in any other region in the world. So it wasn't the operational challenges we had on product [indiscernible]. It was that, on top of dealing with a massive currency issue, a massive decline in demand issue. And it means, we had to do a lot of things really well to still grow earnings by 9% last year. So I guess -- so let's fast forward into this year and I should say, we did very well on the cost side last year for a host of reasons, including the synergies, the restructuring, raw material markets, et cetera. So coming into this year, what we all have to mention is we still have big currency and demand headwinds. But there are less than half the size of last year, if things stay as we see them today. We're going to have another great year of cost productivity. And I would say we have no major known operational execution problems today like we had a year ago. So it's a -- that's, I guess, as clear I could try to be -- to hopefully address your point.

componenttext: David, it's a Marc. It's hard to quantify, but we wouldn't want to quantify for competitive reasons. But it's -- there is, in particular, the first half of '15 and Q3 we were impacted, not just by availability, but it's also flooring and new product introductions and that's by definition. Again, as I said before, in Q4, that was behind us. So it's [indiscernible] behind us. But yes, you have, in total, you probably more than 1 point of market share.

componenttext: More than 1 point of market share?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good. Secondly, just can you talk about Canadian and Mexican operations specifically what impact weaker demand had on that 2.9% North American segment unit growth number?
componenttext: Okay. Good. Secondly, just can you talk about Canadian and Mexican operations specifically what impact weaker demand had on that 2.9% North American segment unit growth number?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Marc again. And first of all, when you look at the numbers, yes, the Canadian market was down 8% in Q4. And putting context, Canadian market in the financial recession did not -- did the best offer [indiscernible] so it's held up for much long
componenttext: David, it's Marc again. And first of all, when you look at the numbers, yes, the Canadian market was down 8% in Q4. And putting context, Canadian market in the financial recession did not -- did the best offer [indiscernible] so it's held up for much longer. But obviously, the consumer confidence, oil, the Canadian markets is soft and we do expect it to be soft mostly going forward. In addition to the margin -- and as we -- in the investor meeting showed Canada used to be roughly $1 billion business for us, that was in the old currency exchange rate. So you have a demand-side. And on top of that, the currency move of Canadian dollar has been massive. Keeping in mind there's no production in Canada. So you have a full currency impact. Having said that, in context, our team were very disciplined cost base price increase which we already had announced and executed. We maintained a good margin unfortunately, a much lower base. But the margin in Canada is very intact, very robust, but it's just a much lower base. Mexico is a slightly different story. The Mexico market is steady, pretty much slightly down, but there's not a huge downside in Canada. Mexico is a top line issue because of the Mexican peso was 18 [ph] it's just dramatically devalued. So that has obviously, a negative impact on the pure revenue side. It doesn't impact us so much on an ongoing margin side because we're largely [indiscernible] production is 60%, local to local production, or 70%.

componenttext: Yes, Michael. To answer your question, what I would say is that, that's on 2016 base, 15%. In order of magnitude, obviously, Brazil would be our largest emerging market, followed by Russia -- I'm sorry, China -- it'll be Brazil, China, Russia and then India.
