headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Director of Investor Relations, Chris Co
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Director of Investor Relations, Chris Conley. Please go ahead.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation First Quarter 2016 Conference Call.Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturelli
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation First Quarter 2016 Conference Call.
Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturelli, our Chief Financial Officer.
Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investors section of our website at whirlpoolcorp.com.
Before we begin, let me remind you that as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corporation's future expectations.
Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed on our latest 10-K and our other periodic reports as well as on Slide 1 of this presentation.
Turning to Slide 2. We want to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP measures.
We believe these measures are important indicators of our operations as they exclude items that may not be indicative of or are unrelated to results from our ongoing business operations.
We also think the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for analyzing trends in our ongoing business operations.
Listeners are directed to the supplemental information package posted on our Investor Relations for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record operating results for the first quarter of the year. Our ongoing earnings per share were up 23%, and our ongoing EBIT margins
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record operating results for the first quarter of the year. 
Our ongoing earnings per share were up 23%, and our ongoing EBIT margins were up a full point. We also stated in the statement that we are reaffirming our full year guidance after what we view as a good start to the year. 
Our integration activities in Europe and Asia have progressed well, and we're firmly on track to deliver a significant level of cost synergies for the year. And as you will see from our results, consistent with our full year goals, our strong execution more than offset currency and emerging market demand challenges in parts of the world. 
Now I'll turn to Slide 5, where you see our first quarter results. Our revenues were up 1% versus last year, excluding currency. Our ongoing business earnings were a record $2.63 a share, again up 23%, in line with our guidance for the year. Free cash flow declined slightly versus last year and the quarter. However, we are in track to meet our full year goal. 
On Slide 6, you'll see our guidance, which once again we reaffirmed. We expect for the year to deliver ongoing earnings of $14 to $14.75 a share, which represents over a 15% growth versus last year. We also continue to expect to deliver free cash flow in the range of $700 million to $800 million, which is a strong improvement over last year. So overall, our expectation is to continue to build on what we see as positive momentum that developed throughout the quarter, and we managed -- and as we managed to challenge -- to manage through a challenging environment with strong execution and also expect to deliver another year of record results. 
On Slide 7, we do highlight a few items in our 2016 capital allocation plans. And overall, the priorities here remain unchanged, which are to fund the business, to support strong returns to shareholders and to continue to evaluate value-creating M&A opportunities. 
As you saw during the quarter, we did complete our existing share buyback program with $225 million in share repurchases. In last week, our board raised a new $1 billion share buyback program and 11% increase in our quarterly dividend. With our strong business performance, we believe that we have the appropriate flexibility to continue to execute our capital allocation priorities in order to drive long-term value creation. 
Finally, on Slide 8, you can see our 2016 business priorities. Overall, our focus is to continue to grow revenues and expand operating margins through a number of levers: first, by delivering our restructuring and acquisition cost synergies of $175 million for the year; secondly, we do -- are seeing and do expect to continue to see mixed improvements and revenue growth as we benefit from our new product introductions and the strength of our industry-leading brands. We continue to see and target growth opportunities in our adjacent businesses, and we are leveraging our cost productivity actions to continue to deliver benefits to expand our operating margins. So with these actions, we will generate improved free cash flow for the year, which will enable us to continue to create shareholder value through our capital allocation plans. 
So at this point, I'd like to turn it over to Marc Bitzer. Marc?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review North America performance in the first quarter. We performed in line with our expectations by growing revenues 5%, excluding currency, and expanding operating margins 70 basis
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review North America performance in the first quarter. 
We performed in line with our expectations by growing revenues 5%, excluding currency, and expanding operating margins 70 basis points to 10.5%. We delivered another quarter of sequential T6 market share improvement, and our units sellout in the first quarter outpace the industry, behind the strength of our recently launched products and investments we made to drive profitable growth. 
Our strong operating margins were driven by our ongoing cost productivity programs and operating leverage from revenue growth, which more than offset $30 million in unfavorable currency impacts in Canada and Mexico. 
Turning to Slide 11, we outlined our 2016 operational priorities for the North America region. Our expectations is that the industry will show 5% to 6% annual growth behind strong housing trends and consumer sentiment. We expect to grow at or above the industry rates for the year as we accelerate the growth of our new products and continue to make targeted investments to drive profitable growth. Our strong cost productivity programs will continue to drive margin improvement, and we'll remain focused on growing our adjacent businesses. 
Turning to Slide 12, we highlight our exciting new top load laundry platform. It represents a new area in laundry with an industry-leading capacity and intuitive front touch controls. We saw significant first quarter growth in the top load laundry with very positive consumer and major trade customer support and expect this trend to continue. 
I will now share the first quarter results for our Europe, Middle East and Africa region as shown on Slide 13. Sales were $1.2 billion compared to $1.3 billion in the prior year. Excluding currency, sales declined 3%. The top line was a little soft across Europe due to a slightly weaker industry of down 1%. The market was down slightly, but there were strong and what we believe temporary demand declines in the U.K. and Russia, where we have a much larger business. 
Ongoing operating margin was 4.9%, a 220 basis point increase compared to prior year and in line with our expectation for full year margin improvement. Strong execution of our integration plans and ongoing cost productivity more than offset $20 million in unfavorable currency impact. 
On Slide 14, our 2016 priorities remain unchanged with a strong focus on integration activities, ongoing cost productivity and growth from new products. We expect the industry to be flat to up 2%. For the year, we continue to expect to grow in line with market and to deliver margin expansion, consistent with our full year guidance of 7% to 8%. 
On Slide 15, we're proud to feature Europe's first fully connected appliance suite. These products work together seamlessly to give consumers the performance they expect while offering flexibility and peace of mind. 
Now I will discuss our Latin America results on Slide 16. Sales for the quarter were $705 million. Excluding the impact of currency, sales decreased 4%. Industry in Brazil were down 13%, which was in line with our forecast of down 10% for the full year. However, through strength of our brands and products, we gained market share and continue to outperform industry. 
Our operating profit for the quarter totaled $42 million, nearly 6% of sales compared to 6.6% at prior year. It is important to note that the first quarter of 2015 was the beginning of last year significant real devaluation and industry decline. We have readjusted our business for today's operating environment  previously announced cost-based price increases, new product introduction and substantial cost and capacity reduction and are on track to deliver our full year operating margin guidance. 
On Slide 17, we summarize our priorities in Latin America. We expect to manage through continued volatility through strong cost productivity programs and by maintaining our right-sized fixed cost structure. We will continue to invest in new products and remain well positioned when the consumer demand does return. Based on our expectation of demand down 10% and the benefits of our offsetting actions, we expect to successfully navigate short-term challenges and deliver on our full year guidance. 
Slide 18 is our Consul freestanding range. This is a value-based price product for Brazil that includes several premium cooking features that deliver great value for consumers. The initial sales results of this product have been very strong. 
And now we turn to our first quarter results in the Asia region, which are shown on Slide 19. Net sales were $371 million in comparison to $378 million in the prior year period. Excluding the impact of currency, our sales increased 3%. Our ongoing operating profit was $27 million compared to $26 million in the prior period. Ongoing operating margins were 7.3%, an increase of nearly 0.5 points, driven by revenue growth and ongoing cost productivity. 
Turning to Slide 20. We share our 2016 priority for our Asia operation. We will continue to focus on growth through distribution expansion and ongoing cost productivity programs. Our expectation continues to be flat industry in the region with stronger demand in India and slight weakness in China. Overall, we expect strong margin performance of 7% to 8%, driven by a larger growth platform and the benefits of our strong innovation pipeline. 
On Slide 21, we showcase our new top load laundry product for the China market. Similar to our North American product, it features front touch controls and innovative wash technology for improved fabric care. This is a great example of leveraging our product development capabilities across region. 
And finally, on Slide 22, we summarize our regional margin guidance for the full year. Our first quarter performance was consistent with these goals, which remain unchanged as we continue to see opportunities for strong margin expansion in all regions. 
And now I'd like to turn it over to Larry.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we had solid performance in the first quarter that was in line with our expectations. Our earnings momentum entering the second quarter and expected run rates for the second half are strong. T
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we had solid performance in the first quarter that was in line with our expectations. Our earnings momentum entering the second quarter and expected run rates for the second half are strong. 
Turning to the our first quarter results on Slide 24. Revenues were $4.6 billion. Currency had a top line impact of nearly $300 million. And excluding currency, sales were up 1%. 
We achieved record ongoing earnings of $2.63 per share, which was up 23% year-over-year, primarily driven by acquisition synergies and ongoing cost productivity programs. We achieved these results while absorbing a currency impact of over $0.50 per share or approximately 1 point in margin. Our ongoing EBIT margin improved by a full point during our lowest volume quarter, and we are on track for the full year guidance of 8% to 8.5%. 
In summary, we are very pleased with our results for the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 25, we expect another record year of performance and are reaffirming our full year guidance. As Marc discussed in the regional reviews, we are confident in our operational plans and as a result, expect to deliver 15%-plus growth in ongoing earnings per share in 2016 and approximately $700 million to $800 million in free cash flow. 
On Slide 26, we outline our expectations for EBIT margin expansion. As previously communicated, we expect to expand our margin by over 1 point, primarily driven by ongoing cost productivity, favorable price mix and acquisition cost synergies. We expect to continue funding our global brand and product innovation and to absorb between 1 and 1.5 points of margin impact from currencies. Currencies very recently have strengthened versus the dollar. While we are not adjusting our currency assumption at this time, should trends continue, we would see lower headwinds. 
On Slide 27, we highlight the cadence of the first half versus second half earnings drivers. First, given seasonality of our business, we expect volume to be stronger in the second half of the year. Second, we should also have lower currency headwinds in the second half of the year. Third, we expect strong results from cost productivity programs, and our acquisition synergies will continue throughout the year. As a result, and consistent with prior disclosures, we would expect full year earnings to approximate 40% in half 1 and 60% in half 2. 
On Slide 28, we share some details on our first quarter free cash flow results and capital allocation actions. Our free cash flow declined slightly versus prior year, primarily due to higher restructuring cash, legacy products actions and temporary working capital funding related to the integration of product transitions in Europe. We executed a balanced approach to capital allocation by funding the capital needs of our business and returning cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and the completion of our share repurchase program. 
Our plan to generate $700 million to $800 million in annual free cash flow are on track. With our recently announced $1 billion share buyback program, we have appropriate flexibility to continue with a balanced approach to capital allocation throughout the year. 
On Slide 29, you can see an update on the progress of our restructuring and integration activities. We incurred $47 million in restructuring expense and delivered $58 million in benefits in the first quarter. For the year, we expect $250 million in expense and $175 million in benefits, consistent with previous communications. 
In summary, our strong first quarter results support the run rates needed to deliver our full year guidance. Given our results and strong balance sheet, we also believe we have the right plans in place to deploy cash in ways that will maximize shareholder value. 
Now I'd like to turn it back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. I'll turn to Slide 31, which summarizes again our 2016 priorities, which are built around revenue growth, margin expansion and delivering strong free cash flow for the year. Four months into the year, we feel like we have very strong and ro
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. I'll turn to Slide 31, which summarizes again our 2016 priorities, which are built around revenue growth, margin expansion and delivering strong free cash flow for the year. Four months into the year, we feel like we have very strong and robust plans to deliver on all these priorities, and we remain confident in our full year guidance. 
And as I outlined on Slide 32, we continue to execute our value-creation strategy, which is unchanged, and this gives us an outstanding opportunity to continue delivering significant shareholder returns. 
So with that, I'd like to conclude our formal remarks and open up to Q&A right now. Thank you.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go first to Robert Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go first to Robert Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Larry, just want to talk about currency for a minute. First, FX exposure in North America, you guys called out a $30 million headwind, and I was kind of trying to understand when you think that headwind will abate and kind of it looks like it's a little b
componenttext: Larry, just want to talk about currency for a minute. First, FX exposure in North America, you guys called out a $30 million headwind, and I was kind of trying to understand when you think that headwind will abate and kind of it looks like it's a little bit more than just translational. And you guys sound very, very confident in your guidance, and I wanted to understand do you think there's potential upside to your guidance because of what's going on within FX? And how should we try to quantify that?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob. Yes, as I said in the prepared remarks, we saw currencies began to strengthen towards the end of the quarter, and we've seen over the last couple of weeks or so that, that continued strengthening. So if I was kind of bracketed, I would say if th
componenttext: Yes, Bob. Yes, as I said in the prepared remarks, we saw currencies began to strengthen towards the end of the quarter, and we've seen over the last couple of weeks or so that, that continued strengthening. So if I was kind of bracketed, I would say if these trends continue to be positive, and we see the continued strengthening, we expect probably the lower end of our currency headwind guidance. We said 1% to 1.5%, we'll be closer to that 1%, so that would be approximately $0.50 a share. Again, I think currencies are moving in the right direction. The earnings that we posted in the first quarter is fully in line with our expectations and support our full year guidance. Operationally and Marc mentioned, things are going very well, and so that gives us the confidence in our full year guidance.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and I was hoping, Marc, could you talk for a second about what you're thinking, revenue trends in Europe? It sounds like demand was a little bit softer than you might have otherwise expected. Do you think this is kind of something that's going to
componenttext: Got it, and I was hoping, Marc, could you talk for a second about what you're thinking, revenue trends in Europe? It sounds like demand was a little bit softer than you might have otherwise expected. Do you think this is kind of something that's going to persist? Or do you think this is transitory? And how should we think about revenue growth accelerating in tandem with your ability to get synergies from Indesit.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, it's Marc. So let me actually put the European performance in context. First of all, on a full year basis, as you know, we guided towards 7% to 8% margin. We guided the market demand to be flat to plus 0 -- plus 2%, and we said we would grow in line
componenttext: Rob, it's Marc. So let me actually put the European performance in context. First of all, on a full year basis, as you know, we guided towards 7% to 8% margin. We guided the market demand to be flat to plus 0 -- plus 2%, and we said we would grow in line with market, which also tells you we have a lot of focus on further margin expansion in Europe. With that in mind, and as I indicated my prepared remarks, we're actually very pleased with our performance in Europe in Q1. We delivered a substantial margin improvement of 220 basis points, and we continue to deliver integration cost synergies, and I would argue we are fully on track towards the full year margin target. On the revenue side and I said that in my remarks, we see that it's a slight softness versus what we had in mind, but to underline that, we characterize that as it's a very softness. But particularly driven by the U.K. and Russia whereas you know post-Indesit acquisition, we have a significant exposure, where we saw some weakness. From what we see today, we do not see structural. We consider that a very temporary issue.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And final question switching over to Latin America, it sounds like I'm just trying to understand a little bit, it sounds like you had a tough comp with 1Q '15 and then I'm trying to put that in context. Was Brazil in line with your i
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And final question switching over to Latin America, it sounds like I'm just trying to understand a little bit, it sounds like you had a tough comp with 1Q '15 and then I'm trying to put that in context. Was Brazil in line with your internal expectations for the quarter? Or is it something else going on with the other segments in the Latin American business? I'm just trying to understand how you're thinking about demand and profitability with the 3 businesses in this segment.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, it's Marc again. Simple answer is we're 100% aligned with our internal plans in Q1. To give a little bit more color, keep in mind the decline in particularly the Russian or Brazilian macroeconomic environment started pretty much Q1 last year but real
componenttext: Rob, it's Marc again. Simple answer is we're 100% aligned with our internal plans in Q1. To give a little bit more color, keep in mind the decline in particularly the Russian or Brazilian macroeconomic environment started pretty much Q1 last year but really accelerated as we went through the year, and you saw the same on the currency. So Q1, what I would say kind of the toughest comparison if you want to say because it was just the beginning of the recession. So we saw a significant impact obviously, on the top line converted back from U.S. dollars and then also on demand side. We knew that coming to the year, and that's why we put the plans where plans are, and I would say we're extremely pleased with how the team performed on price margin realization, i.e., on delivering cost base and inflation-based price increases speaking. We're very pleased with how the team has been managing capacity and fixed cost, and the results is a margins, which are particularly keep the top line in line very promising, and we're very confident that we will deliver on our full year guidance margins.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Are the other businesses performing well inside Latin America?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob, there's always gives and takes I would say but compressor business is performing solid or strong and consistent with what we've seen the last couple of quarters. Our client business in Brazil had some issues, largely driven by the introduction o
componenttext: Yes, Rob, there's always gives and takes I would say but compressor business is performing solid or strong and consistent with what we've seen the last couple of quarters. Our client business in Brazil had some issues, largely driven by the introduction of import tariffs in Ecuador and Colombia, but again these are typically onetime effects. They're just pipeline issues.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: And we can take our next question from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to first kind of dive into the North American region a little bit more, if possible. You mentioned that the 1Q sales, I believe, outpace the industry and just wanted to get a sense where did that strength come from. Was there any particular product
componenttext: Wanted to first kind of dive into the North American region a little bit more, if possible. You mentioned that the 1Q sales, I believe, outpace the industry and just wanted to get a sense where did that strength come from. Was there any particular product categories? And offsetting it because you did have a 5% volume growth, and I know that includes some other of the categories in Canada, Mexico. Maybe give us a sense of how those regions did as well.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's Marc. So let me try to answer your question. First of all, and I repeat that from prior calls is that in a number of calls, our reported unit shipments versus the T6 market are not comparable. We're not doing an apples-to-apples comparison b
componenttext: Michael, it's Marc. So let me try to answer your question. First of all, and I repeat that from prior calls is that in a number of calls, our reported unit shipments versus the T6 market are not comparable. We're not doing an apples-to-apples comparison because obviously, in our unit shipments, there's a lot more than what is typically the AM T6. So don't fully compare it. Anyhow having said that, and taking that into context, our unit shipments in Q1 in North America were up 5%. That typically would say it's slightly training versus what the AM numbers would show as I mentioned before but not fully comparable. What is, however, very important to keep in mind and I indicated that before our shipment volumes, i.e., sell-in volumes after a weak start in January, we had a very strong February, March. That momentum continued and carried into Q2. And even more important, the measure that we internally look at are we call sell-out volumes, i.e., what is sold through on the trade partner level. And on that level, we even outpaced the overall market. So we're actually very pleased with the U.S. volume of U.S. shipment trends and the momentum we're carrying. To your question was it one category? No it is not one category, but of course, we feel in particular that we've regained strengthen our laundry category, which I do know is our flagship, and we had last year some issues, and we saw strong growth in laundry, but it carried through other categories as well.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great run down, and certainly appreciate the apples-to-apples is not comparable there. I guess, secondly, on the margin itself, if you kind of adjust for the $30 million FX hit as well as the top line, I'm actually calculating line an the 11.5% a
componenttext: That's a great run down, and certainly appreciate the apples-to-apples is not comparable there. I guess, secondly, on the margin itself, if you kind of adjust for the $30 million FX hit as well as the top line, I'm actually calculating line an the 11.5% adjusted North America margin. So I was wondering if that's correct, Larry, and maybe just kind of drive-through what were some of the puts and takes of that. And considerably, it would seem that overall as particularly as currency headwinds lessen, you'd still be very much on track to hit the full year margin guidance. So just trying to get a sense of the different benefits that you're seeing on the margin side. Again, excluding the currency headwind, it looks like it was about 100 basis points above the reported number.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, let me take this again. As you know, we guided full year North America margins 11.5% to 12.5%. If you would take the midpoint to that, that would be 0.7% higher than largest actual. If you would take the midpoint of that range. Q1 was exactly 0.7% h
componenttext: Mike, let me take this again. As you know, we guided full year North America margins 11.5% to 12.5%. If you would take the midpoint to that, that would be 0.7% higher than largest actual. If you would take the midpoint of that range. Q1 was exactly 0.7% higher than last year. So quarter -- Q1 year-over-year, we exactly in line with kind of they midpoint of what we guided on a full year basis, which obviously gives us confidence we're very well on track towards our full year guidance, and that typically, as you also know, and particularly as you follow our share for a long time there's a lot of seasonality in our Q1 business. There's a couple of factors like small domestic appliance showing much strong in Q4 and Q3, and that's the normal issue. You would go back to last couple of years, you see margin lift as the year progresses, and again that's very typical, and that's why we're very confident. Particularly with regard to your question on FX, yes, you're probably correct, particularly in Q1, our FX burden was high. Within North America with 2 currencies very simply it's Canadian dollar and Mexican peso. First of all, both finally regained some strength towards the end of the quarter. However, on a quarter average and particularly compared to last year, it was a tough comparison. That comparison get a lot -- less challenging as the year progresses.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to ask in North America what you're seeing in the competitive environment and specifically, can we get an update on the anti-dumping suit?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Denise, let me first talk about competitive environment. Again, it's kind of -- as we always said, this is a market where you will always see promotions as we have said the promotions in terms of value creation or if they don't create value. Right now, we
componenttext: Denise, let me first talk about competitive environment. Again, it's kind of -- as we always said, this is a market where you will always see promotions as we have said the promotions in terms of value creation or if they don't create value. Right now, we saw I mentioned in last earnings call, we saw a slightly elevated level of promotions in Q4. We adjusted for that, and that's pretty much the same level in Q1. So it's kind of -- I wouldn't describe the situation as overly concerning or surprising to us. We operate very well in that environment. We delivered strong sales growth, and again as I mentioned before, we're very pleased with our sellout momentum, which ultimately, as you know, transit into sell in. So we are actually very confident about the overall volume growth and our ability to finally regain some market share, which we lost last year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Denise, this is Jeff. Regarding the dumping, let me give you just a brief update on that. I believe we told you last time is end of January, the ITC commissioners unanimously voted to proceed with the investigation in the washer dumping trial or process t
componenttext: Denise, this is Jeff. Regarding the dumping, let me give you just a brief update on that. I believe we told you last time is end of January, the ITC commissioners unanimously voted to proceed with the investigation in the washer dumping trial or process that we filed. It is tracking in line with our knowledge of the process and our expectations. At a high level, we would expect by midyear or just beginning the third quarter that the Department of Commerce will complete their investigation and establish dumping levels and cash deposits for violating companies. Typically, there's going to be 6 months where the Department of Commerce releases its final anti-dumping determination and then it goes back to ITC, which we would expect within the next month and have a final conclusion to that. So from our perspective, it's progressing as it should. Again, we feel very strong that this has been going on for some period of time, quite a long time, really a continuation of the previous washer dumping, which we brought, and so we expect the process to continue along its path.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and just one more. So in terms of raw materials, are you still expecting to see like a north of $100 million benefit this year and mostly in the first half? And just related to that, how should we think about the North America pricing of down 2% on
componenttext: Great, and just one more. So in terms of raw materials, are you still expecting to see like a north of $100 million benefit this year and mostly in the first half? And just related to that, how should we think about the North America pricing of down 2% on an average unit basis? Are we seeing you reinvest some of the raw material savings?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Denise. I think our guidance for total cost productivity, which includes the $100 million plus in raw materials, is still very valid, and we're very confident in that. And our Q1 results fully support what we expect for the full year for productivity
componenttext: Yes, Denise. I think our guidance for total cost productivity, which includes the $100 million plus in raw materials, is still very valid, and we're very confident in that. And our Q1 results fully support what we expect for the full year for productivity perspective.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Denise, it's Marc again. Let me just comment on what you referred to minus 2%. Again, very important to highlight the revenue growth, excluding currencies. As we said, the published revenue growth in North America is plus 3. Excluding FX, it's plus 5, whi
componenttext: Denise, it's Marc again. Let me just comment on what you referred to minus 2%. Again, very important to highlight the revenue growth, excluding currencies. As we said, the published revenue growth in North America is plus 3. Excluding FX, it's plus 5, which exactly matches our unit growth. So on an average of sales value per unit, we're exactly flat year-over-year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from David McGregor with Longbow Research.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- you touched already, Marc, on the fact that you're happy with the kind of recovery in the North American business. I guess, I wanted to just go back to that a little bit. A couple of earnings calls ago, you'd indicated that, that may have caus
componenttext: Yes. The -- you touched already, Marc, on the fact that you're happy with the kind of recovery in the North American business. I guess, I wanted to just go back to that a little bit. A couple of earnings calls ago, you'd indicated that, that may have caused you over 100 basis points of market share. I guess, the question is can you update us on the progress on the product availability issues from last year? And do you feel this recovery positions you to regain 100 basis points plus market share that previously indicated the situation cost you last year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, to that point yes, you're correct. Last year our availability issues, which are very largely related to the huge amount of product introductions, they cost us some market share. And when we guided on the full year basis growth in line with marke
componenttext: So David, to that point yes, you're correct. Last year our availability issues, which are very largely related to the huge amount of product introductions, they cost us some market share. And when we guided on the full year basis growth in line with market -- above market, that basically implies that we're regaining that market share. I will characterize in particular on a sequential base that Q1 is fully on track for recovering that lost market share. I would also expect that now Q2 also year-over-year improvement, and yes, that is led largely by the laundry category, where we had some product introduction issues. So, and that is now fully on track and actually very strong performance.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for Larry. You talked about the $175 million of benefit this year. I guess, the question is how much of that goes to margins versus how much of that of being reinvested elsewhere in other initiatives?
componenttext: A question for Larry. You talked about the $175 million of benefit this year. I guess, the question is how much of that goes to margins versus how much of that of being reinvested elsewhere in other initiatives?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're referring to the synergies -- and synergy benefits and David, that always flow into margins.
componenttext: Well, I think you're referring to the synergies -- and synergy benefits and David, that always flow into margins.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, the way, I guess, I would look at it the if you go to the margin walk page, basically, and particularly because it with Europe and China, where we talked about acquisitions, synergies, it was squarely our position that these would be brought t
componenttext: Yes, David, the way, I guess, I would look at it the if you go to the margin walk page, basically, and particularly because it with Europe and China, where we talked about acquisitions, synergies, it was squarely our position that these would be brought to the bottom line and expand our margins. And to date, that's been the case. You've got another moving parts, raw materials, cost productivity, mix, price, et cetera, et cetera, and in currencies. And so there's give and takes, but as a general principle, the restructuring and in M&A synergies, we're using in those particular parts of the world clearly, the expand margin.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you're looking at Europe, David, certainly some very nice solid margin improvement, probably about [ph] 3.5 points of synergies, but that's been, partially offset to Jeff's point, from the unfavorable currency that we're driving.
componenttext: Yes, if you're looking at Europe, David, certainly some very nice solid margin improvement, probably about [ph] 3.5 points of synergies, but that's been, partially offset to Jeff's point, from the unfavorable currency that we're driving.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with MTM.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with MTM.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up a little bit on the North American competitive environment. We've seen a lot of sort of signage and stuff from the big-box stores around a spring Black Friday event. Just wanted to get your thoughts on that in terms of appliances. Is t
componenttext: Wanted to follow up a little bit on the North American competitive environment. We've seen a lot of sort of signage and stuff from the big-box stores around a spring Black Friday event. Just wanted to get your thoughts on that in terms of appliances. Is this about the same as last year? Is this a new initiative for them in terms of more aggressive promotional into spring?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc. I mean, first of all, from an overall competitive environment, trading environment, promotions are just the nature of the North American business. I mean, you will have spring Black Friday or Earth Day, you will have a Labor Day and red,
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc. I mean, first of all, from an overall competitive environment, trading environment, promotions are just the nature of the North American business. I mean, you will have spring Black Friday or Earth Day, you will have a Labor Day and red, white and blue. So there's a lot of promotional holidays. That's just the nature of the U.S. market, but it doesn't drive the entire market. So as we have said in the past, the name of the game is how we effectively play between promotional environment and kind of the regular ongoing business environment. On promotions, we, on a case-by-case basis, to make the decisions in order to great value for us and our customers or not and then we make a situation assessment. As I mentioned before, we saw slight increase of promotion environment in Q4, and that carried into Q1. As evidenced from margin expansion, I think we can create value, grow the business and add expand margins despite the environment. So we're not overly concerned about it.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And wanted to follow up on the share buybacks. Obviously you put a new large share buyback into place. You seem to be pretty opportunistic in the first quarter on buying back shares. So how are you looking at that $1 billion authorization? Are you t
componenttext: Okay. And wanted to follow up on the share buybacks. Obviously you put a new large share buyback into place. You seem to be pretty opportunistic in the first quarter on buying back shares. So how are you looking at that $1 billion authorization? Are you thinking about just continuing to be opportunistic? Are you going to put some things more regular in place? Do you have a goal in terms of keeping your shares outstanding at a similar level? If you could give us some are color, that would be great.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Megan, this is Jeff. The way, I guess, for us to frame it is this is part of our capital allocation process. And on an ongoing basis, we have dialogue with our board on -- in terms of opportunities to create value for shareholders. And over time, the
componenttext: Yes, Megan, this is Jeff. The way, I guess, for us to frame it is this is part of our capital allocation process. And on an ongoing basis, we have dialogue with our board on -- in terms of opportunities to create value for shareholders. And over time, they vary or different opportunities occur. Certainly, completing our last share repurchase we felt was a very good use of capital for our shareholders. We are funding our business at appropriate levels now to deliver new product innovations to the marketplace around the world. We are funding the business for restructuring opportunities with our M&A acquisitions, which are delivering wondering great cost benefits. In the past, we've demonstrated when we saw great M&A opportunities, we move very quickly on them, and we have, and then you also have certainly a return to shareholders, both dividends and share repurchases and again, we've given our long-range view of what our financial performance we expect to be. And obviously, that makes our shares based on that, in our view, have great opportunity to increase in value. And as we balance all of those, we make different decisions during different periods. But the point of all that is we have the ability to look at all these opportunities in any period of time and act on them, and that's what we've been doing. We will not, nor have we in the past, given specific time frames for when we expect to complete this. You should expect we -- as we have been at today's levels it's likely be a buyer this year of our shares, but we don't have a defined period of time by which we're going to complete it.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Should we interpret for North America the 5% rough -- [indiscernible] 5% plus to be now saying 5% to 6%? I mean, are you taking that up 1%? For the industry guidance? Or is that just a rounding error and -- and the reason I'm asking it seems like North America obviously AM turned out better could it be weather or not, but I think with some people it's maybe surprising with the higher demanding we saw in AM impacted you guys guidance at all to the upside.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Technically speaking, we're taking it up 0.5 points because that's the average of 5% to 6%. But all joking aside, we do see strength in the North American market in Q1, and we expect some of that strength to carry throughout the year progresses. Behind th
componenttext: Technically speaking, we're taking it up 0.5 points because that's the average of 5% to 6%. But all joking aside, we do see strength in the North American market in Q1, and we expect some of that strength to carry throughout the year progresses. Behind that is where we are, and we remain confident about the U.S. housing market. I know there have been some somewhat sluggish numbers about housing starts, and we do see that being corrected over time. So we're still counting on 1.15 to 1.2 housing starts, and we're still counting on existing home sales of 5 3, 5 4, in that ballpark, and we continue to see that as we are observing the market everyday. So that's why we said it's 5% to 6%. Could it even be more? Could be. We do not see weakness today on the North America market demand.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Ken, it's Marc again. Obviously we got to see how the year progresses. I can only say in particular related to what I mentioned before, our sellout in Q1 as been very strong, and we're talking about high single digits, low double digits sellout, which is an indication of a new floor product, the new product introduction are working on the floor. If you know products are working on the floor and are selling them, before you know, the shipments will come. So that's why we are bullish on what we said before we will go in line or above market, and obviously, our focus is on above markets.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, the trend, indeed, is really there. I think we kind of have the full impact of this in late summer, Q3. We improved Q4 versus Q3. We improved Q1 versus Q4. To Marc's point, the real important things are what our consumers buy, not necessarily what yo
componenttext: Ken, the trend, indeed, is really there. I think we kind of have the full impact of this in late summer, Q3. We improved Q4 versus Q3. We improved Q1 versus Q4. To Marc's point, the real important things are what our consumers buy, not necessarily what you're shipping. That will fall, and that's been very positive. So I think -- we like the trend we've been on, particularly over the last 8, 10 weeks, and our performance throughout the market should be good.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Sam, this is Jeff. Let me just add on that because obviously, there's a lot of talk for over the year about currency. Our big parameters is we gave guidance for the year in February were really about the things that had been the most volatile, which
componenttext: And, Sam, this is Jeff. Let me just add on that because obviously, there's a lot of talk for over the year about currency. Our big parameters is we gave guidance for the year in February were really about the things that had been the most volatile, which are our currency levels and demand levels, particularly emerging market demand levels. In the first quarter, we were able to operate within those parameters. Late in the quarter, the currency portion, and so far, in April, has been better than our assumptions. The demand is not. It's about in line in some markets are worse, and a few markets are better, but in our view was it's particularly with what we've seen volatility wise and in the case of Brazil, the political chaos and so on and so forth, way we too early for us to change our currency assumptions. But to Larry's point, if you take our 2 big parameters, currency levels and demand, our view is if they get better, we'll get better.

componenttext: Hold on. We said in February real was essentially 4:1 in dollars in February it's now 3.55. So a 10% strengthening built around the political scenario. So it could -- our view is if it stays at 3.55, which is where it is today, we'll do better in America. The same with the euro, which was probably 1 08 or so in February. It's 1 12, 1 13, that's the translation effect there. Now, for the most part, the part we have today have a couple of negatives around the world but net-net, whereas currency was bad all year last year, we have a little bit of stabilization, which we view as a good thing, but it's way too early for us to adjust any guidance based on that.

componenttextpreview: Tom, it's Marc Bitzer. So first of all, as you know, in the full year basis, last year, Europe revenue was pretty much flat, and that's where we are kind of based on market something pretty much expecting this year directionally. So Q1 on constant FX or l
componenttext: Tom, it's Marc Bitzer. So first of all, as you know, in the full year basis, last year, Europe revenue was pretty much flat, and that's where we are kind of based on market something pretty much expecting this year directionally. So Q1 on constant FX or local currency was minus 3. So we are kind of trading 3 points pretty much behind, where we want to be from a revenue side again. As I mentioned before this is largely driven by Russia and U.K. for different reasons. U.K., British pound weakness. We announced some cost-based price increases. As you also know, we have a safety recall election that is a certain temporary U.K. issue. Russia, the market remains soft throughout Q1. As we set off at Investor Day Russia is a market of extreme volatility. We saw in previous if market comes down very quickly and also comes up very quickly. It's started already last year pretty much around February or also Q1 over Q1 was a slight weakness even we thought beginning of the quarter some signs of stabilization in Russia market, but it's very hard to predict how Russia market evolved going forward. Again, the latest trends have been a little bit more encouraging, but it still remains very soft.

So in short, we are pleased with how the team kind of mitigates that a negative impact of inflation, currency on to price-mix. So we're very pleased with the progress.

componenttext: David, it's Marc. And as you know, we typically don't break down market share progress quarter-over-quarter, country-by-country. Having said that, I reaffirm that one of the key strengths of that acquisition have been the market share strength and position, which we have in several key countries, and that is to be honest, 1 year or 1.5 years into that integration has been fully we confirmed our business in particular, Italy, France, U.K. and Russia and Poland remain very strong and now very strong. We do not see, to your question, a decline of market share, significant decline in some of our smaller markets. I think what is we confront the structural benefit of having a strong market position, but we don't see a dramatic shift year-over-year between weaker and stronger markets.

componenttext: And David, over time, I think you'll see it demonstrated through our continued ability to build our overall margin structure, and I think the other point Marc made in Q1 is when you look at overall market, we also have a market mix and you would -- having strong share, Russia and U.K, having those markets down more, which would weight our overall mix a little bit worse than margin, but that's really, in our view, a temporary situation.

componenttextpreview: Yes, David. Overall in that business, there's a number things in it. But 2 that you know very well. One is our kitchens small appliances business. In the case of North America, we have a consumer products business. We have a commercial laundry business, a
componenttext: Yes, David. Overall in that business, there's a number things in it. But 2 that you know very well. One is our kitchens small appliances business. In the case of North America, we have a consumer products business. We have a commercial laundry business, and then everywhere around the world, slightly different, but these businesses are -- each one of them are somewhat different, but our view is we'd like to be able to consistently grow this at least double-digit. And these -- and that'll be the consumer products ultimately, commercial laundry given our position. We also have similar businesses like this in Brazil. We're developing them now in Europe with the acquisition. We don't yet have these businesses in China. So it varies a little bit around the world. But on average, yes, these are nicely margin business, probably at least double our margins that we have in what we call our core major appliance business, and so again, when we talk about capital allocation, and that's one thing. We do focus on where are the opportunities to grow these businesses. Could be by adding product lines, could be by expanding in new markets around the world and so on, and we focus on that very strongly.

componenttext: Ken, it's Marc. I mean, obviously, our sell-through sellout has been higher than the sell in. So that by definition is the reduction of trade inventory in the quarter. That is by definition. So no matter how you turn it, ending inventory of retailers is lower than coming in. I would say it's a combination of both I think some retailers were slightly behind inventory coming into the quarter. But right now, I would argue strong sell-through momentum of our products, we will see, and we are seeing the shipments coming, catching up. So if there is -- this is not a structural inventory reduction. It's temporary and ultimately, as Jeff pointed out before, sell in always follows sell out.
