headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Whirlpool Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to our Senior Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Chr
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Whirlpool Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to our Senior Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Chris Conley. Please go ahead.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturel
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Larry Venturelli, our Chief Financial Officer. Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investors section of our website at whirlpoolcorp.com.
Before we begin, let me remind you that as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corporation's future expectations. Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed in our latest 10-K and our other periodic reports as well as on Slide 1 of the presentation.
Turning to Slide 2. We want to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP measures. We believe these measures are important indicators of our operations as they exclude items that may not be indicative of or are unrelated to results from our ongoing business operations. We also think the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for analyzing trends in our ongoing business operations. Listeners are directed to the supplemental information package posted on our Investor Relations website for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
Following our prepared remarks, the call will be open for analyst questions. [Operator Instructions] With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record operating results for the second quarter, driven by strong ex currency revenue growth and substantial margin expansion of 1.
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, we reported record operating results for the second quarter, driven by strong ex currency revenue growth and substantial margin expansion of 1.6 points. 
Our integration activities in Europe and Asia continue to progress well, and we remain on track to deliver significant cost synergies for the balance of the year. Our strong operational execution more than offset currency and demand challenges around the world. And as a result, we delivered another record quarter of performance. Following the strong first half performance, we're increasing our full year guidance for ongoing earnings per share to $14.25 to $14.75. 
Before we move to the details of the quarter results, I'd like to highlight an important ruling by the Commerce Department on our washer trade fair trade case. We're very pleased that this ruling confirmed that LG and Samsung continued to dump washing machines in the U.S. market. Both companies are now required to pay substantial deposits for these products which they import from China. 
As we've previously discussed, this unlawful behavior clearly had a negative impact on our washer -- washing machine market share and earnings in 2015 and in the first half of 2016. But despite this, we are pleased that we're still able to deliver record results through the strength of the rest of our portfolio of products and brands. 
I'll now turn to Slide 5 where we'll take a look at the financial results for the second quarter. Our revenues overall grew 3% versus last year ex currency. Our ongoing earnings per share grew by 30% to a record $3.50 per share. And this came through strong execution of acquisition synergies, volume growth and ongoing cost productivity programs and free cash flow improved versus last year.
Turning to Slide 6, you'll see that we are raising our 2016 guidance volume to strong first half performance. Again, we now expect ongoing earnings per share to be $14.25 to $14.75 per share. We are reaffirming our expected free cash flow generation of $700 million to $800 million, which represents a significant improvement over the prior year. We are confident that our continued focus on execution and strong second half actions will enable us to deliver another year of record results.
On Slide 7, you'll see that our 2016 priorities remain unchanged. We do remain confident in our ability to manage economic volatility and have deployed strong operational plans, which we believe will enable us to grow revenues and continue to expand our operating margins.
On Slide 8, our capital allocation strategy remains also unchanged. We continue to prioritize funding the business, along with delivery of strong return to shareholders, and we continue to evaluate opportunistic value-creating M&A opportunities. 
During the second quarter, we did purchase $100 million of shares during the quarter. We intend to continue repurchasing stock through the year and we currently have $900 million of remaining share repurchase authorization. So overall, we do remain confident in our ability to deliver long-term value creation through strong cash generation and the execution of our balanced capital allocation process.
Before I move on to our regional businesses, I wanted to comment on the leadership announcements, which we made in late June. As you probably know, our Chief Financial Officer, Larry Venturelli, has announced his planned retirement. We also have announced that Jim Peters, currently our Vice President, Corporate Controller and Chief Accounting Officer, will succeed Larry as Chief Financial Officer. 
First of all, I'd like to take this opportunity to thank Larry for his over 15 years of service to our company in a number of leadership roles, including the last 5 years as Chief Financial Officer. Larry has played an integral part of our executive management team and in helping us in our global expansion, including most recently the successful acquisitions of Indesit in Europe and Hefei Sanyo in China. 
At Whirlpool where he will be greatly missed but we always wish and his family the very best in his upcoming retirement. At this time, I'm also pleased to welcome Jim Peters into his new role of Chief Financial Officer. Jim does have a very broad background in our global finance leadership and a number of roles and in our business operations And I'm very confident that under his leadership, we will continue to execute our global value creation plans. 
So with that, I'll stop here and turn it over to Marc Bitzer to review our global operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review North America's performance in the second quarter. We delivered record operating profit by growing ex currency revenues 4% and expanding operating margin to 12.3%. We improved T
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review North America's performance in the second quarter. We delivered record operating profit by growing ex currency revenues 4% and expanding operating margin to 12.3%. We improved T6 market share versus prior year and saw strong consumer demand for our products. 
Our record second quarter operating margins were driven by our ongoing cost productivity programs and operating leverage from revenue growth, which more than offset $20 million in unfavorable currency impacts in Canada and Mexico.
Turning to Slide 11. We outline our 2016 operation priorities for the North American region. We continue to expect the industry to grow 5% to 6% for the full year. As we have done consistently, we will make targeted investments to grow profitably at or above the industry rates. We continue to leverage our strong cost productivity programs to drive margin improvement, and we remain focused on growing our adjacent businesses. We are confident that these actions will allow us to deliver at the higher end of our margin targets for 12% to 12.5%.
Turning to Slide 12. We highlight our exciting new French Door bottom-mount refrigeration platform. The jumbo capacity product features the most shelf space among leading brands in the industry. It offers the first-to-market flexible pantry and spread shelving system, delivering both [ph] the capacity and flexibility our customers desire. 
Beginning on Slide 13, I will review the second quarter results for our Europe, Middle East and Africa region. Sales were $1.3 billion, down slightly from the prior year. Excluding the impact of currency, sales were flat. Ongoing operating margin was 4.6%, a 40 basis point increase compared to prior year. This margin expansion included a 200 basis point unfavorable currency impact primarily from the British pound and the Russian ruble. We have deployed previously announced cost-based price increases to offset this currency impact.
Turning to Slide 14. We want to put our European business in context by providing additional details of our first half performance and the plan for the second half. We made significant progress on the integration of Indesit, demonstrated by the substantial first half restructuring and synergy benefits that Larry will discuss in more detail. 
We are confident in our ability to deliver planned 2016 synergies evenly in the third and fourth quarters. We experienced a negative first half currency impact primarily in U.K. and Russia and have deployed previously announced cost-based price increase to improve our operating margins as we progress throughout the second half of the year. We are in the process of integrating product platforms across Europe and expect to make strong progress by year-end. We expect to grow second half revenues by fully deployed marketing and sales activities.
We do believe we have the right actions to address the operating environment, and as a result, we expect operating margins to improve throughout the second half. We expect our exit rate on operating margins in the fourth quarter to be more consistent with our long range expectation of 7% to 8%. 
On Slide 15, in addition to the second half actions we discussed, our 2016 priorities remain largely unchanged, with the continued focus on integration activities, ongoing cost productivity and growth from adjacent businesses. We also continue to expect the industry to be flat to up 2% for the full year, but clearly, there is some uncertainty in the European region. Through the strength of our operating plans and continued acquisition benefit remain confident in our long-term guidance of 7% to 8% operating margins by 2018.
On Slide 16, we're proud to feature award-winning building of our new built-in kitchen suite. This product incorporates advanced cooking technology and on-demand recipes with elegant contemporary aesthetics for sophisticated customers.
Turning to Slide 17, I will discuss our Latin America results. Sales for the quarter were $826 million. Excluding the impact of currency, sales increased 4%. The industry in Brazil continues to be challenging. However, our top line performance in Brazil was strong as we continue to leverage our leading portfolio of brands to drive growth and outperform the industry. We were able to gain several points of market share in the second quarter substantial improving our operating margins. Our operating profit for the quarter totaled $50 million, 190 basis point increase compared to prior year.
The actions we have taken over past year to improve margins in a challenging environment and grow market share have been successful, and we now expect to deliver the higher end of -- range of our margin targets of 7% to 7.5%.
On Slide 18, we summarize our priorities in Latin America, which have not changed. As we've done consistently, we will manage economic volatility through strong cost activity programs and by leveraging our right-sized fixed-cost structure. We will continue to invest in new products and remain well positioned to capitalize on growth in Brazil when consumer demand does return.
On Slide 19, we're highlighting our award-winning Brastemp brand. This year, Brastemp was recognized in a nationwide study as Brazil's most engaging consumer appliance brand, building on 6 decades of inspirational performance and superior design. 
Now we turn to our second quarter results in the Asia region, which are shown on Slide 20. Net sales were $363 million in comparison to $381 million in the prior year period. Excluding the impact of currency, sales were flat. Our ongoing operating profit was $29 million compared to $31 million in the prior year period. Ongoing operating margins were 8.1%, flat to prior year as continued record performance in India and ongoing cost productivity offset weak demand in China.
Turning to Slide 21, you will see that our 2016 priorities for Asia have not changed. We remain focused on growth through distribution expansion and ongoing cost productivity programs. We also continue to focus on the longer-term opportunity in China as we navigate through demand uncertainty.
On Slide 22, we showcase our new front-load washer machine for China. We leverage the integration between Hefei, Indesit and using the best of the best to provide consumers with world-class laundry performance.
Finally on Slide 23, we summarize our regional margin guidance for the full year. Given continued global volatility in some regions and strong first half performance in others, we have adjusted our margin expectations as follows: North America increase to 12% to 12.5%; Latin America increase to 7% to 7.5%; Europe decrease to 5.5% to 6% due to negative currency impacts and the expected timing of our offsetting actions; Asia remains unchanged at 7% to 8%. 
It is important to note that we are on track for strong margin expansion in all regions and have not changed our overall operating margin guidance. We remain confident in our ability to manage for global volatility and to deliver our strong second half plans.
Now I'd like to turn it over one last time to Larry.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with our second quarter results on Slide 25. As Jeff mentioned, we had strong performance in the second quarter despite a challenging external environment. Net sales were $5.2 billion. Excluding the i
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with our second quarter results on Slide 25. As Jeff mentioned, we had strong performance in the second quarter despite a challenging external environment. Net sales were $5.2 billion. Excluding the impact of currency, revenues were up 3%. We achieved record ongoing earnings of $3.50 per share, which was up 30%, primarily driven by acquisition synergies, volume growth and ongoing cost productivity.
In the second quarter, currency impacted our revenues by approximately $150 million, EBIT margin by about 1 point and net earnings by $0.50 per share. Our ongoing EBIT margin improved by more than 1 point, and we are fully on track for our full year guidance of 8% to 8.5%. On a GAAP basis, our second quarter tax rate was driven by the timing of tax settlements and planning activities and does not impact our previous guidance of 22% for the full year. Our ongoing tax rate for the quarter was 22%, consistent with our previous guidance. Overall, we are very pleased with our results for the quarter and the appropriate runways to deliver a very strong second half.
Turning to Slide 26, let me take a moment to discuss the expected impact of currency on the results for the year. You may recall in our original guidance for 2016, we assumed a negative impact of $2.50 per share. During our first quarter call, as currencies began to improve, we indicated that if April rates held, we would expect $0.50 per share lower currency headwinds for the year. 
While there was significant volatility to key currencies in the second quarter, the net result for the basket of currencies we're exposed to has not changed substantially since our last call. We expect the impact of currency to be approximately $2 per share for the full year. We will continue to execute previously announced cost-based price increases and deliver cost reductions to offset negative currency impacts, and our ongoing hedging programs continue to be an effective tool for us to reduce short-term volatility.
On Slide 27, you'll see an update on the progress of our restructuring and acquisition integration activities. Through the first half, we incurred restructuring expense of $87 million and delivered $120 million in benefits. We now expect $200 million in expense for the year and are increasing benefits to $200 million. Overall, we are on track to deliver our previously announced synergy goals through 2017.
Turning to Slide 28, I will discuss our expectations for full year EBIT margin expansion. As previously communicated, we expect to expand our margin by over 1 point, primarily driven by ongoing cost productivity and cost and capacity reductions. Our first half year-over-year EBIT margin improvement continues to support our full year expectation. We expect to continue funding our global brand and product innovation and to absorb approximately 1 point of margin impact from currency.
On Slide 29, we highlight the cadence of second half earnings drivers. Consistent with historical trends, we expect a meaningful step-up in the seasonality of our volumes between Q3 and Q4. We expect negative currency impacts to continue in Q3 but will lessen in Q4. As a result of these trends, we expect our second half earnings to approximate 45% in the third quarter and 55% in the fourth quarter, which is very consistent with what you saw last year. 
On Slide 30, we share some details on our first half free cash flow results and capital allocation actions. Our free cash flow improved versus prior year, primarily due to the improved earnings. Consistent with our strategy, we executed a balanced approach to capital allocation by funding the capital needs of our business and returning cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and previously announced share repurchase program. We plan to buy back additional shares throughout the year.
Turning to Slide 31, we're adjusting our full year guidance in response to our strong first half results. As Marc discussed in the regional reviews, we are confident in our operational plans, and as a result, expect to deliver 15%-plus growth in ongoing earnings per share in 2016 and approximately $700 million to $800 million in free cash flow.
Finally, on a personal note regarding my retirement, I've had the opportunity to work with many of you in the financial community over the past several years. It's been an honor and privilege representing Whirlpool, and I wish you all continued success in the future. I'd like to turn it back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. I'll summarize on Slide 33, which shows again our 2016 priorities, which haven't changed, and our plan is to drive revenue growth, margin expansion and to generate strong free cash flow for the year.Overall, I think our ongoing efforts to
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. I'll summarize on Slide 33, which shows again our 2016 priorities, which haven't changed, and our plan is to drive revenue growth, margin expansion and to generate strong free cash flow for the year.
Overall, I think our ongoing efforts to drive margins, especially in the areas of volatility around the world, have demonstrated our ability to manage in the needed actions within our control in response to this global volatility. And I think the first half of the year is really a good example of that because we had many changes that we're able to adapt to. 
We do believe we are well positioned in the second half, and we have deployed strong operational plans across the world to make sure we deliver our goals. So overall, we do expect to deliver record results and while at the same time executing a balanced capital allocation approach. 
Finally on Slide 34, we do continue to execute to our long-term value creation strategy. Overall, we remain confident in our goals. We do expect to be able to continue to leverage our industry-leading brands, keep bringing a strong portfolio of innovation in the marketplace and our best cost position to ensure that we're delivering strong returns to our shareholders. 
So with that, I'd like to end our formal remarks and open this up for Q&A.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our first question from Denise Chai with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our first question from Denise Chai with Bank of America.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to start with the antidumping ruling that came out. What's different this time compared to 2 years ago? And could you just walk us through the mechanics of how duties apply and what it theoretically means for market pricing? So for exampl
componenttext: I guess I wanted to start with the antidumping ruling that came out. What's different this time compared to 2 years ago? And could you just walk us through the mechanics of how duties apply and what it theoretically means for market pricing? So for example, if Samsung and LG moved production back to Korea and Mexico, would the old duties still apply? And really what are the next steps? So any color around that would be very helpful.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Denise, this is Jeff. Yes, the current fair trade action is for washing machines in the U.S. market. And one [ph] since this is a continuation of the 2013 situation but at the time, dumping is -- the law is -- applies to countries, not companies. And
componenttext: Yes, Denise, this is Jeff. Yes, the current fair trade action is for washing machines in the U.S. market. And one [ph] since this is a continuation of the 2013 situation but at the time, dumping is -- the law is -- applies to countries, not companies. And the countries involved then were South Korea and Mexico, and we won very decisively in that case. But the companies, which are LG and Samsung, basically moved their production to China immediately to work around this and continue dumping. And so our new case is for dumping against manufacturers in China but it specifically affects LG and Samsung. So that required a new action. We're going through the process. We believe the evidence is compelling, as evidenced by the Commerce Department's preliminary judgment with the duties they've levied. They are now having to pay cash deposits on imports, and in fact, one of them is actually retroactive through the last 3 months because all the product they brought in the marketplace. There's a very clear Commerce Department process that is followed. They will make the final determination duties in December. Then it goes to the International Trade Commissions to evaluate injury, and we expect that judgment to be mid- to late January.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Denise, it's Marc. Maybe just one additional comment specifically to your questions. So the 2013 order is still active and in place. So to your question moving back to Korea or Mexico, it doesn't help them because the old order is still active and in plac
componenttext: Denise, it's Marc. Maybe just one additional comment specifically to your questions. So the 2013 order is still active and in place. So to your question moving back to Korea or Mexico, it doesn't help them because the old order is still active and in place.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what flexibility, I guess, do they have in terms of market pricing? I'm just wondering if what this ruling...
componenttext: Okay. So what flexibility, I guess, do they have in terms of market pricing? I'm just wondering if what this ruling...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't speak to competitors' market pricing. The same based on the evaluation by the Commerce Department, they have -- their conclusion is they are dumping again from China. They've already proven they're dumping from South Korea and Mexico. And based on
componenttext: I can't speak to competitors' market pricing. The same based on the evaluation by the Commerce Department, they have -- their conclusion is they are dumping again from China. They've already proven they're dumping from South Korea and Mexico. And based on that, they're going to charge substantial tariffs. And I guess the company can either adjust their pricing or continue to pay these substantial tariffs. But that's really their decision.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And sorry, just last one. So to illustrate, if a washing machine for Samsung or LG washing machine is retailing for say, $1,000, then what does -- what do the tariffs of 110% and 50%...

componenttext: Well, if you just take only on the value, forget retail price, if you take the value, it's somewhere in the neighborhood of -- in the case of the lower level, probably $175, $180 to the higher level of over $300. So it's substantial.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take the next question from Sam Eisner with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take the next question from Sam Eisner with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to the EMEA commentary here, I want to get a better understanding on FX. Obviously, the decrement to that, I think, Larry you called out was about a 200 basis point, 2-point headwind to the quarter. But looks like decrementals for the total
componenttext: So going back to the EMEA commentary here, I want to get a better understanding on FX. Obviously, the decrement to that, I think, Larry you called out was about a 200 basis point, 2-point headwind to the quarter. But looks like decrementals for the total company were around 35% and we were closer to 25%. So just curious if you can talk a little bit about the transactional exposure within the EMEA business and how we should think about that going forward.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam it's Marc Bitzer. So let me maybe just provide some clarity on it. And yes, you're correct. The currency predominantly impacts the margin. And to put that in context, there's obviously a number of currency moves on currency baskets in what flows Europ
componenttext: Sam it's Marc Bitzer. So let me maybe just provide some clarity on it. And yes, you're correct. The currency predominantly impacts the margin. And to put that in context, there's obviously a number of currency moves on currency baskets in what flows European regions. But most impactful one, just given the size and movement, have been the British pound and the Russian ruble. Other ones as well but these are the most impactful ones. And what it was just operationally in the U.K., like us, most competitors don't produce in the U.K. Almost nobody produce in the U.K. So basically, any currency weakness of the British pound turns into kind of a lower margin for us. That's [indiscernible] immediate impact. It's somewhat similar in Russia, maybe to a lesser extent, because we produce more in Russia. The combination of these 2, once you put it in absolute terms, was basically $30 million just in the quarter, just these 2 big markets. So we're talking substantial so back on a European level, that's more than 200 basis points so that's where the number comes from. Now -- and just for clarity, I'm referring to year-over-year impact of currency. As you also know, Russian ruble even on a weak level, has stabilized. So I think sequentially, we don't see big surprise but still a year-over-year impact. And as you also know, the British pound for the quarter average has deteriorated but obviously, particularly post-Brexit [indiscernible] has been significant and it has a significant impact on our margin.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we're adjusting our actions accordingly.
componenttext: And we're adjusting our actions accordingly.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to Jeff's point, I mean, obviously what you -- what we're doing as a company in this kind of environment, we basically have cost-based price increases, which we have communicated and largely implemented in some of these markets, obviously the U.K. one
componenttext: So to Jeff's point, I mean, obviously what you -- what we're doing as a company in this kind of environment, we basically have cost-based price increases, which we have communicated and largely implemented in some of these markets, obviously the U.K. one is fairly recent, but we expect in the second half to fully compensate the currency losses through these cost-based price increases.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful, Marc. And then when I think about the North American business, if I read back into the pricing, pricing looks to be down about 1% in the second quarter. It was slightly down in the first quarter, so it seems as though you could argue
componenttext: That's very helpful, Marc. And then when I think about the North American business, if I read back into the pricing, pricing looks to be down about 1% in the second quarter. It was slightly down in the first quarter, so it seems as though you could argue that you're using price as a tool to accelerate volumes. If we look out to 2017 where maybe raw materials are not as supportive, how do we think about that dynamic going forward in your ability to continue to gain share when raw materials are maybe not as much of a tool for you guys anymore?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marc again. So let me first talk about the Q2 pricing, which you observed in North America. There's actually a very straightforward and easy explanation for this. One, big 2 components. One is Mexico, the impact of Mexico. Keep in mind, in North Amer
componenttext: It's Marc again. So let me first talk about the Q2 pricing, which you observed in North America. There's actually a very straightforward and easy explanation for this. One, big 2 components. One is Mexico, the impact of Mexico. Keep in mind, in North America, we have 3 countries flowing through the overall North America revenues. You have Mexico, significant currency decline year-over-year. Also still in Canada, to a lesser extent. So roughly we had an $8 decline in the quarter of [indiscernible] more than half of that is just coming from currency. Also combined a little bit of mix impact we have pretty strong volume growth in Mexico, profitable volume growth in Moscow, but it has a mix impact on the AST. The other part and that goes straight back to Jeff's earlier comment, yes, we are exposed to the continued and sustained dumping practices in the washer business. And that has an impact and our ASV. I'm pleased that despite all that, we delivered very strong operating margin which shows how strong the underlying business is. But these 2 factors explain the ASV in Q2.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, just on the washer side, as we've said, it had significant negative impact on our market share, which is volume but also on earnings. So that's embedded in there based on the kind of type of promotion we saw in the second quarter.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Best of luck to you, Larry. Great working with you. Question on just kind of going back to North America with the sales growth. And clearly, this has been an area of focus for Whirlpool and reaccelerating that. With roughly a 4% revenue growth rate ex cur
componenttext: Best of luck to you, Larry. Great working with you. Question on just kind of going back to North America with the sales growth. And clearly, this has been an area of focus for Whirlpool and reaccelerating that. With roughly a 4% revenue growth rate ex currency in 2Q, as you look forward, I mean, this is obviously also a big focus over the next couple of years to get to the 2018 goals. I mean, is there sort of a number that you are expecting to be sustainable or perhaps even accelerate, excluding currency, as you continue to get some momentum on the new product front and perhaps a little more stability with antidumping?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's Marc. Let me maybe just comment a little. So yes, in Q2, we had a 4%, excluding FX, revenue growth and a very, I would say, solid volume growth of 5%. And you also know the ins and outs market share T6 units. So we're very pleased with the m
componenttext: Michael, it's Marc. Let me maybe just comment a little. So yes, in Q2, we had a 4%, excluding FX, revenue growth and a very, I would say, solid volume growth of 5%. And you also know the ins and outs market share T6 units. So we're very pleased with the market share progress and revenue growth. I would also, and that probably gives us confidence [indiscernible] point out what you're seeing as our sell-in unit growth and sell-in market share, our sell-out trends are very strong and probably outpacing even the [indiscernible] obviously a very positive development, which we've seen. And as I also said in my remarks earlier, our commitment is to grow at or above market for 2016. And we're firm on that commitment. It's obviously way too early to talk about the '17 and '18 target, but I would expect a similar guidance from ourselves that we grow at or above market.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Got it. That's very helpful, Marc. I appreciate that. And then just on the restructuring benefits, increased it by $25 million for '16. How should we think about the total amount of benefit over the entire period, if you can just remind us of that number and does that number change at all as well?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Larry. Yes, we did increase the restructuring benefits from $175 million to $200 million for 2016. As you know, what we committed to was $350 million by 2017 and we're fully on that path.
componenttext: This is Larry. Yes, we did increase the restructuring benefits from $175 million to $200 million for 2016. As you know, what we committed to was $350 million by 2017 and we're fully on that path.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions if I could. First, the washing machine profitability or at least the ability to expand margins if you were able to normalize washing machine profitability. I think you mentioned in the that you're losing money currently in washers. I
componenttext: A couple of questions if I could. First, the washing machine profitability or at least the ability to expand margins if you were able to normalize washing machine profitability. I think you mentioned in the that you're losing money currently in washers. If you were able to return the washer part of the segment in North America to appropriate margins, what might be your margin upside for overall North American margins?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc. First of all, and I hope I was clear in our earlier comments. Washers, as defined in the antidumping case, don't equate to what we call laundry, okay? Laundry is broader as our dryers, as our capacity very specific definition of the washer
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc. First of all, and I hope I was clear in our earlier comments. Washers, as defined in the antidumping case, don't equate to what we call laundry, okay? Laundry is broader as our dryers, as our capacity very specific definition of the washer case. So don't equate these 2 ones. Having said that, if you look at the pure washers, the profitability is clearly, clearly below where we would expect at any moment in time if we're losing money on top of a volume impact. So your question unfortunately short probably the more theoretical question. The reason I'm saying this one, as evidenced by the ruling of preliminary ruling, there has been a significant amount of stockpiling by LG, Samsung at the end of Q2, i.e. inventory loading. And unfortunately, we see that's still entering the market in Q3. So there is still an impact and that's just the reality. I would also not be surprised even though to some extent a speculation at this point if that both players continue to serve [indiscernible]. So I would see some relief on our margins on washers, but it needs to be seen to what extent LG and Samsung actually follow the order, and that's not our decision.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, to be clear, short term, we got to get through the year and get this completed successfully, gauge the reactions on. But to your point, the theoretical question, it's worth a lot to our North America business, at least a couple of points.
componenttext: Sam, to be clear, short term, we got to get through the year and get this completed successfully, gauge the reactions on. But to your point, the theoretical question, it's worth a lot to our North America business, at least a couple of points.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my second question, if I could re-ask what one of my peers asked in terms of 2017, the ability or willingness of either the consumer or the retailer channel partner to accept price increases. What do you think the willingness might be and the ela
componenttext: And then my second question, if I could re-ask what one of my peers asked in terms of 2017, the ability or willingness of either the consumer or the retailer channel partner to accept price increases. What do you think the willingness might be and the elasticity would be of the industry if you do have to raise prices or the industry participants have to raise price next year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam. We've had this discussion in the past, and the reality is there are -- price points won't change. Model feature per content change, okay? So it's not affordability and therefore not elasticity question at all. It's whatever number. 5% price incr
componenttext: Yes, Sam. We've had this discussion in the past, and the reality is there are -- price points won't change. Model feature per content change, okay? So it's not affordability and therefore not elasticity question at all. It's whatever number. 5% price increase on it, 5 [ph] on the ASV is $25. They'll still be $4 99 [ph] and so on. So first of all, we have made no decisions to talking about any future price increases. We're going to see how the environment involves, and we'll make the decisions as we always do. We have great levers to improve margin, mix and many other tools. But the one, I guess, directly to your question I point out is I don't see any price elasticity of the kind of levels that we have historically looked at.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc. Also maybe in addition to this one, I guess you wouldn't have asked the question if you'd develop the context of question about material trends. So let me proactively also address this one because we've seen in some of the earlier comment
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc. Also maybe in addition to this one, I guess you wouldn't have asked the question if you'd develop the context of question about material trends. So let me proactively also address this one because we've seen in some of the earlier comment about material price. Of course, we do observe material trends, and of course, there are certain elements of the global material market like the U.S. the prices, which are somewhat of a concern. I want to just comment 2 things on this one. A, we have long-term contracts particular to this deal. We have on several commodities very strong and favorable hedge positions. So we're, I would say for '16, certainly very well positioned on the material side. And I would say way too early to speculate about the '17 mature trance. Of course, certain spot prices, but I would also argue demand on certain materials is just not strong enough to see that going into fully into '17.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing, Sam, would be if you go back to history, you follow us for a long-time, when we've had material inflationary environment before we've been able to overcome that through a lot of different tools and continue to improve our earning
componenttext: And the only other thing, Sam, would be if you go back to history, you follow us for a long-time, when we've had material inflationary environment before we've been able to overcome that through a lot of different tools and continue to improve our earnings and our margins also, but it's too early to call on pricing.

componenttext: Just a forewarning, I am going to go back in the queue here so I'm not going to ask too many all at once. Europe, you guys talked about $30 million EBIT hit in 2Q. The margin guidance revision to 5.5% to 6% implies more than $30 million. Could you please tell us what that the dollar value is and how that would fall in sequentially 3Q and 4Q within that guidance?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marc and there's obviously a number of timing and moving parts. So the $30 million refers to the exact what we lost in Q2 predominantly to British pound and ruble. Obviously, that is an average currency rate for the quarter, and you need to be aware
componenttext: It's Marc and there's obviously a number of timing and moving parts. So the $30 million refers to the exact what we lost in Q2 predominantly to British pound and ruble. Obviously, that is an average currency rate for the quarter, and you need to be aware the exit run rate of British pound was way below the average. So the impact of the British pound if you wouldn't do anything going [indiscernible] Q3 and Q4. The offsetting element of previously announced increase, which we've already implemented or ones which we have not yet fully implemented but announced certain ramp-up period. So the negative part of the currency, which right now we just have it was going to be with us for the rest of the year, and we are starting to offset every month more through previously announced cost price increases.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we won't fully offset that in the third quarter.
componenttext: But we won't fully offset that in the third quarter.

componenttext: Just the timing doesn't work because in most markets, in every market is different, you have certain pre-lead time between many communicate actually implement, there are contracts in place. You have the ramp-up time of these price increases. The important thing is, however, by a particularly as we go in Q4 and the exit run rate, we expect to be fully offset by cost-based price increases.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, let me zoom out in Europe in total. First of all, I really want to reiterate the synergies and the integration fully on track. For the cost side, it's a safe bet, i.e. what we control, we do control, and we deliver more, as evidenced by Larry's ear
componenttext: Again, let me zoom out in Europe in total. First of all, I really want to reiterate the synergies and the integration fully on track. For the cost side, it's a safe bet, i.e. what we control, we do control, and we deliver more, as evidenced by Larry's earlier comments. So the increase of restructuring benefit that's largely Europe. So the cost side is fully on track, but it is going really well. You have 2 elements in Europe. There's a little bit of an overlap. One is the currency, the currency impact operating margin. The offsetting action are cost-based price increase. That takes time to ramp up so I expect the margin impact in this one to go with every month be less than this. But of course, right now, it's a Q3 pending issue. The volume impact is to a lesser extent. We're not -- in Q1, as you may recall, in Q1 a volume decline of 4%. Now in Q2, we're at plus 2.1% so it's getting better but it's not yet fully at the pace of the market. That is largely explainable directly by the platform integrations. And again, that's something which to some extent expected but still [indiscernible] as you go through it we're basically replacing 80% of our SKUs in Europe this year. massive factory moves, product platform moves. That is basically we expect it to be largely completed by the end of the year. That is probably single biggest driver behind the top line issue. But again, I want to -- the top line has it's -- we don't like to see it but it has a lesser impact on the bottom line than the currency.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: And Larry, good luck. Big contributor, you'll be missed. Just wanted to see if you guys could step me through what's going on in the slide deck on Page 27. You're taking down your expenses by $50 million for restructuring, and you're boosting the benefit this year by $25 million. I'm trying to understand and just tie this maybe to Marc's comments about where is this kind of trade-off occurring. It's obviously very positive development. Can you step us through kind of the puts and takes here?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Larry. On the restructuring side, yes, we did take down the restructuring expense for this year down about $50 million. Now part of that is related but some of that frankly has to do with timing between years. So -- and we'll provide guidance for
componenttext: This is Larry. On the restructuring side, yes, we did take down the restructuring expense for this year down about $50 million. Now part of that is related but some of that frankly has to do with timing between years. So -- and we'll provide guidance for next year in a few months. But overall, to Marc's point, the integration has been going well. The restructuring has been going well. The benefits just we've been able to accelerate some of the benefits from the acquisition and the integration. That continues to go well and we remain fully committed in what we communicated back through 2017 of $350 million-plus.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bob, it's Marc. Keep also in mind, as Larry there's always a little bit of time lag between the expenses and the benefits. So the way you should read this one is the increase of benefit has largely to do with actions taken in '15, which are really --
componenttext: And Bob, it's Marc. Keep also in mind, as Larry there's always a little bit of time lag between the expenses and the benefits. So the way you should read this one is the increase of benefit has largely to do with actions taken in '15, which are really -- I mean, we get a strong use [ our of this one. And the expense there's 1 or 2 little piece, which we had in mind, which will probably do '17 and we will announce at the appropriate time.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So this just sounds like a timing issue. Assuming on the next slide on Page 28, you took your price/mix down from 50 basis points to 1%, up to 0 [ph] to 0.5 [ph] I was trying to understand why you kind of tweaked that downward a little bit. And your volume growth in Asia and Latam is excellent, and you didn't move up your outlook in terms of industry what you guys could do there. I was trying to understand if that's portending weakness in the second half or just abundance of caution.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I would just say there's been a number of moving parts to the first half of the year, and we're assuming there'll be a number of moving parts in the second half of the year. The composite of the margin walk simply is -- are 6 months actual versus run
componenttext: Bob, I would just say there's been a number of moving parts to the first half of the year, and we're assuming there'll be a number of moving parts in the second half of the year. The composite of the margin walk simply is -- are 6 months actual versus run rates going forward. And we're doing a little bit better as we said on the cost synergy side. We've seen a little bit of, I won't say weakness but lasting of the total on the pricing. Volume nets out about the same in total but it varies a lot. I think as I look in the first half of the year and for the full year, it'll be another great example of how -- having our balanced global representation operating platform, allows us to take advantage of markets that are going well and offset markets that face challenges during the year. And second quarter is a great example of that. I imagine the second half will be the same there's no real big changes in any of our assumptions with the one exception of March more pointed out in terms of short-term European margins.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, let me maybe also add in Brazil because explicitly asked for Brazil also. Don't read our performance in Q2 as an indication of the overall market environment. The environment continues to be very challenging. I would read this as we were decisive on
componenttext: Bob, let me maybe also add in Brazil because explicitly asked for Brazil also. Don't read our performance in Q2 as an indication of the overall market environment. The environment continues to be very challenging. I would read this as we were decisive on actions early on, maybe early in the cycle, to maybe also early in the cycle and now we start seeing the benefit of these actions earlier than maybe our people I would say right now given the unfortunate confidence of political economic and consumer confidence in Brazil, I don't think we can count on a recovery on this one in '16.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Larry, congratulations on your retirement [indiscernible] investors. A couple of questions here. First of all, your competitor talked a lot about weakness in private label business in North America. I'm just wondering if you could comment trends you're se
componenttext: Larry, congratulations on your retirement [indiscernible] investors. A couple of questions here. First of all, your competitor talked a lot about weakness in private label business in North America. I'm just wondering if you could comment trends you're seeing in the private label business this quarter.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Marc. I don't know can comment competitors' comments. What I can comment is on our own private-label brand of business. So we see over last 5 years a trend from our private-label business to our brand which is absolutely. And that's ultimately
componenttext: David, it's Marc. I don't know can comment competitors' comments. What I can comment is on our own private-label brand of business. So we see over last 5 years a trend from our private-label business to our brand which is absolutely. And that's ultimately a reflection of the strength of our brand portfolio. That trend is continuing so it's nothing or surprising all of a sudden. It's been I would say a multiyear erosion. And again, that's portfolio strong brands help us very strongly. I would say also in addition, and I think we've been talking about this repeatedly, where we take pride in our very balanced distribution footprint. What it means, we have, I would say a very similar balance most of our national trade partners so whenever you see movement or wins and losses of one trade partner in a market, we typically don't see the pain because we have a very well-balanced distribution footprint, which obviously also helps us mitigating any trends you might market place by private-label or OEM business.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. You didn't see anything that was really discontinuous or different from the trend you're seeing over the past 5 years you discussed?

componenttext: We did not see the acceleration for trend. We did see a continuation of a trend. these are private-label all [indiscernible] went on we saw very strong growth from our Maytag business but that worked for us.

componenttext: David again, it's Marc. No -- short answer, no we didn't see a massive change. Again, the expanded answer is and it's my usual comment is in the sell in T6 is not reflective of our total volume, and there's always like in every quarter inventory moves in differences between sell-in and the so-called sellout. I would say in this quarter, some of these numbers may be a little bit more distorted just because of the stockpiling [indiscernible] it's just a reality. But I would say from everything which we've seen, if you take all data points into account that's why he was still see a 5% to 6% steady state industry growth for this year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: In terms of the sell-through mark that continue that point, the Asian shipments were notably softer in 2Q relative to 1Q. And it sounds like stockpiling that benefited within that shipment number. I guess, what I'm trying to understand is in terms of the sell-through pace that you observed through of the first half of the year and what you're seeing in terms of expectations and activity in the back half of the year. Any change in that relative pace is the question.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Eric, it's Marc. My comment particularly referred to our sell-through. We don't have unfortunately no reliable industry sell-through data. It's just data source issue. So we have sell-through data and about 65% of our customers out there so we have a
componenttext: And Eric, it's Marc. My comment particularly referred to our sell-through. We don't have unfortunately no reliable industry sell-through data. It's just data source issue. So we have sell-through data and about 65% of our customers out there so we have a pretty good proxy what happens in our business. And that pace has been ahead of our sell-in volumes and also quite a bit ahead of our overall market. To your point earlier, it's hard to gauge exactly sell-through. Yes, you could say July 4 was maybe a little bit slow than some partners expected. On the other hand, the rest of the quarter was a little bit stronger. And it's -- I wouldn't read anything into what it would mean for Labor Day or any other promotion periods. Will be ups and downs, and of course, more aggressive people will be like Memorial Day, you may seen says it on July 4 but have a normal what I would call the normal promotion ups and downs. And I don't think that changes any of our view in the full year industry guidance.

componenttext: I would say it's actually pretty constant. There's probably more noise actually in the sell-in and the inventory data vendors and sell-through data, so I think it's pretty steady. Now again, there's differences by promotion. There's also difference by channel. For example, we continue to see very strong sell-through in sell-in on the builder and contract segment. Very subtle difference across the different channels but sell-through is actually pretty steady.

componenttext: I just wanted to get a little more color on Latin America on how you saw demand progressing in the second quarter. And then maybe talk about if you're taking any competitive actions and leading to the market share gains that you guys are seeing in the market.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take this again. Again, first of all, as a reference point, the minus 10%, which we gave as guidance for first to Brazil, that is not Latin America in total and I would argue outside Brazil the rest of Latin America is probably stronger than t
componenttext: Yes, let me take this again. Again, first of all, as a reference point, the minus 10%, which we gave as guidance for first to Brazil, that is not Latin America in total and I would argue outside Brazil the rest of Latin America is probably stronger than the minus 10%. So my 10% particularly in Brazil. I would say given the extreme volatility, which we've seen in Brazil over the last 5, 6 quarters, I would right now say close exactly what happens by quarter or if would know probably wouldn't give that guidance. But right now, it's actually -- we still expect the full year industry to be down minus 10%. We knew in Q1 it was even worse so maybe it's stabilizing. But bear in mind it's stabilizing on a very low level because last year was already significant reduction. So we do not see any recovery or any significant recovery in Brazil in the back half of this year. To your question about competitive reaction we simply do not know we do not ask them. And frankly, we focus on our own profitability. We did the actions a year ago. [indiscernible] pain and I would say in our business is very well on track and keep also in my these are not just mechanics of pricing up and down. These are new products, product introductions, innovation which we brought to the market.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that. In Brazil, as we talked about last year, we had 3 ways of disruptions. The demand has been constant -- negative demand has been constant and has carried into this year. We had 3 major currency devaluations, last one being in Sept
componenttext: I would just add to that. In Brazil, as we talked about last year, we had 3 ways of disruptions. The demand has been constant -- negative demand has been constant and has carried into this year. We had 3 major currency devaluations, last one being in September, October. And we had to adjust each time to those. And then thirdly is inflation. So this year, demand is pretty much playing out as we expected, and we expected it to be down. We're both through cost and cost-based price actions. We are dealing with both currency and inflation, but the third factor is we continue, despite the environment, to invest very strongly a new product and brand innovation. That is enabling us to improve our market position. The cost and the price position are allowing us to improve our margins, but the market share gains are purely the fact that we continue to bring new product of the marketplace.

And then the currency piece is now the $200 million is now in our guidance, and that's reflected in each of the regions that Marc took you through from a margin perspective.

componenttext: I guess I'll touch on a region that we haven't touched a lot so far today, which is Asia. Wondering if you had walked through your review of the market demand in China and India. And I know you said in your presentation that China was down. Do you think that you are gaining share yet from your distribution expansion? Or is it still too early for that to be happening?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc. As you point out, first of all, let me zoom out on a little. We're very pleased and satisfied with our operating margin, 8% in such a volatile region and a competitive region [indiscernible], so we're very pleased with that progress. But
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc. As you point out, first of all, let me zoom out on a little. We're very pleased and satisfied with our operating margin, 8% in such a volatile region and a competitive region [indiscernible], so we're very pleased with that progress. But you're also right, it's a little bit of tale of 2 stories right now. India in particular, which is a big part of that region, we had some actual results. That was a strong market, but we also made very good progress in market for cost productivity and new product introductions and we gained share. So I will say India is really a very bright spot in Asia, one. China is impacted even integration is on track, but it's impacted by a soft market demand. And I talked about China market demand typically refer to so called T2, it's not the same definition as North America. But right now even though we don't have latest June data, I would right now assume Q2 China was high single digits negative. So this is also obviously nontrivial in a very competitive market, which characterized by a little bit overcapacity. So specifically to your question our distribution expansion translate into market share gains I would say not yet because also underlying [indiscernible] to opposing moves expanding brand distribution and actually gaining volume of Whirlpool brand, while at the same tumor phasing out or reducing some value brand business so there's 2 offsetting items, and that's why the, net-net, you don't get see the market share growth, which over time you should expect.

componenttext: It's Marc. So first of all, every market around the world is slightly differently set up. So the kind of construction business, which we have in the U.S. will be referred to sum up, buildable contract, you don't have the same magnitude in U.K. because there is no typical -- in there is a pure national build you don't have national build business. Having said, but of course, like any other market in particular anyone you talk about kitchen demented still impacted by housing activity. I would say not to the same extent as North America in terms of correlation but there is an impact. Do we see any signs of a pullback here? No adjustably do not see it. So -- but could you expect that over time? Maybe. I would say it's too early to tell. As you also know and I just now right tried to draw the analogy [indiscernible] currencies you may see behaviors from a market demand. We have -- wouldn't be the first market short-term even see an increase of demand because people are still going for lower-priced appliances, and then you see the opposite effect. It's too early to see by then what speculation but pattern, which we have seen in many markets. So you may see the combination of first increasing demand and then softness of demand.
