headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would now like to turn the conference over to the Senior Director of Investor Relati
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would now like to turn the conference over to the Senior Director of Investor Relations, Chris Conley. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Jim Peters, our C
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Jim Peters, our Chief Financial Officer.
Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investors section of our website at whirlpoolcorp.com.
Before we begin, let me remind you that as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corporation's future expectations.
Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed on our latest 10-K and our other periodic reports, as well as on Slide 1 of the presentation.
Turning to Slide 2. We want to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP measures.
We believe these measures are important indicators of our operation and they exclude items that may not be indicative of or are unrelated to results from our ongoing business operations. We also think the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for analyzing trends in our ongoing business operations.
Listeners are directed to the supplemental information package posted on our Investor Relations section of our website for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
[Operator Instructions] 
With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, our operational execution offset some significant external challenges that we saw in the quarter. But we did deliver record results for the third qua
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, our operational execution offset some significant external challenges that we saw in the quarter. But we did deliver record results for the third quarter. 
During the quarter, currency continued to be volatile and negative and we saw some softness in the appliance demand, most prominently in the U.K. and the U.S. Despite this volatility, we are able to deliver record results, and year-to-date, our earnings have increased by 18%. In North America and Latin America, we expanded margins while gaining market share, which was done by leveraging our leading brands, launching innovative new products and delivering strong ongoing cost productivity. And finally, consistent with our balanced capital allocation approach, we've repurchased $100 million of our common stock during the quarter. 
Overall, the fundamentals of our business remains strong, and we continue to adapt to our operating plans in order to deliver strong results.
I'll now turn to Slide 5, where you'll see our third quarter results. 
Our revenues, ex currency, increased slightly. Our ongoing business earnings grew to a record $3.66 a share. It is [ph] gained through a combination of acquisition synergies, unit volume growth and ongoing cost productivities. And we improved our free cash flow for the year.
Turning to Slide 6. We have an update on the external environment and some of the challenges that we're facing and offsetting. We have seen what we believe is a temporary softness in industry demand in the U.S., particularly what you saw [ph] earlier in the quarter in July and August, with some rebound in September. We believe this is due to consumer confidence we gained [ph] primarily due to the focus around the U.S. elections.
In addition, the promotional environment in the U.S. has been -- has elevated during the quarter, especially in the washing machine category. There, certain import competitors continue to unlawfully dump product, and we're responding with continued investment in our strong brands, launching new, innovative products, as well as our fair trade actions. 
For the year, in Europe, our integration is on track and we're delivering cost synergies in line with our plans. And our previously discussed margin recovery actions in Europe are progressing, and we do expect to see the positive impact of these actions over the next couple of quarters, somewhat later than we originally thought because we continue to see currency and demand volatility, particularly in the U.K. market.
Overall, we expect to deliver a record performance this year with approximately 15% ongoing EPS growth, over 0.5 point of ongoing EBIT margin improvement and good improvement in free cash flow. 
On Slide 7, we've updated our 2016 guidance to reflect these changes. We now expect to deliver ongoing earnings of $14 to $14.25 a share and to generate approximately $700 million in free cash flow.
Turning to Slide 8. We show our balanced capital allocation approach, which has not changed. We continue to appropriately fund our business and expect to invest between $650 million and $700 million in capital this year. As I mentioned, we did repurchase $100 million in share repurchases during the third quarter, and we do intend to continue repurchasing stock in the fourth quarter. So in total, we remain committed to delivering our long-term value creation objectives through our operational execution and a balanced approach to capital allocation.
So with that, I'm going to turn it over to Marc Bitzer to review our global operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review our performance in North America. Net sales increased 2% versus prior year and grew 3% excluding currency, and we expanded our ongoing operating margins to a third quarter recor
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review our performance in North America. Net sales increased 2% versus prior year and grew 3% excluding currency, and we expanded our ongoing operating margins to a third quarter record of 12.1%. Our operating margins were driven by strong ongoing cost productivity programs and unit volume growth, which more than offset approximately $25 million in unfavorable currency impact in Canada and Mexico. 
During the quarter, we gained over 1 point [ph] of market share versus the prior year as consumer demand for our brands and products have continued to be strong. As demonstrated by our performance, we remain focused on driving both revenue growth and margin expansion.
Turning to Slide 11. I will discuss some external factors affecting our North America region. As Jeff outlined earlier, we have seen a temporary slowdown in U.S. appliance industry demand since our last call. We are confident that the stiff [ph] in consumer discretionary purchases is temporary as consumer confidence has been impacted by the upcoming U.S. elections. We increasingly see solid consumer demand for our strong brands and new products and expect to continue to generate profitable market share gains. However, we have seen an increase in promotional activity in the U.S., especially on washers. This corresponds with significant inventory stockpiling by certain competitors at the end of the second quarter, who we believe are continuing to unlawfully dump products. This higher promotional intensity had a significant negative impact on our washer margins in the third quarter. We continue to pursue our fair trade case for washers manufacturers [ph] in China and anticipate a final ruling in early 2017.
Additionally, we have recently announced cost base price increases, primarily in washers, to allow us to recover the cost of our investments in new and compelling products. We expect that these actions, along with a focus on value-creating promotions and strong productivity programs, will offset negative margin impacts from continued dumping by certain competitors.
We fully expect to deliver strong results in the fourth quarter and remain on track to achieve our long-term goal. 
Turning to Slide 12, we'll discuss key drivers of the U.S. appliance industry. The fundamental underpinning U.S. appliance [ph] demand are healthy. During recent years, we have seen steady growth in key macro indicators, including housing starts in both new and existing home sales, as well as improvement of other [ph] relevant indicators such as consumer sentiment and unemployment. While some of the individual monthly data is volatile, the trends overwhelmingly demonstrate strong demand for housing, increasing levels of employment, real wage growth and long-term improvement in consumer sentiment. We've seen 15 consecutive quarters of appliance industry growth in the U.S., and all of these underlying macro trends support continued growth to U.S. appliance industry in the coming years.
As such, we believe that the current industry slowdown is a temporary shift, consistent with what we're seeing in the retail environment for housing, [ph] and we remain confident that the multiyear cycle of U.S. demand growth will continue in 2017 and beyond. 
Turning to Slide 13. We outline our 2016 operational expectations for the North America region.  We now expect the industry to grow 3% to 4% for the full year. Through the end of the third quarter, the industry's up a little over 3.5%. We continue to expect to grow at or above industry rates with targeted investment in our strong brands and new products, as we have done consistently throughout the year. We continue to execute strong cost productivity programs and we remain focused on achieving growth in our adjacent businesses. We now expect to deliver 11.5% to 12% margin in 2016, an increase over the prior year.
Beginning on Slide 14, we will review our third quarter results for our Europe, Middle East and Africa regions. Sales were $1.3 billion, down 9% versus the prior year. Excluding the impact of currency, sales were down 6% as we saw demand softness in certain key countries, particularly in the U.K.
Ongoing operating margins were 3.7%. Our margins were negatively affected by approximately $40 million in unfavorable impact in our U.K. business from a devaluing British pound and softening demand environment.
Turning to Slide 15, we'll provide an update to our previously deployed actions in Europe. 
The integration of Indesit continue to be on track, and we fully expect to deliver planned cost synergies in the fourth quarter and into 2017. Consistent with what we've seen since the Brexit decision, currency continues to be a headwind and demand in the U.K. remains soft, causing our previously announced cost base price increase to be implemented slower than anticipated. Our platform integration and manufacturing transitions remain on track. However, we reduced manufacturing volumes in response to this lower demand, [ph] most of which occurred in the third quarter, and we now expect roughly 0.5 point [ph] margin impact for the full year. As a result, our margin expansion in Europe is slightly delayed. 
In summary, we believe we have the right actions in place to manage through [ph] volatility and deliver our long-term goals.
On Slide 16, our 2016 priorities for the European, Middle East and Africa region remain largely unchanged. There's a continued focus on integration activities, ongoing cost productivity and growth from adjacent businesses. Similar to the third quarter, we plan to manage inventory levels as we continue product and brand transitions [ph] in the fourth quarter.
Our industry guidance remains flat to up 2% for the full year. We now expect to deliver 4.5% to 5% operating margin for the full year and remain confident in our long-term margin guidance of 8%.
I will now discuss our Latin America results on Slide 17.
Sales for the quarter were $800 million, an increase of 7%. Excluding the impact of currencies, sales increased 2%. Our third quarter operating profit totaled $45 million, and margin increased 150 basis points versus the prior year. Despite operating in a challenging demand environment, we expanded margins and delivered strong revenue growth from continued investments in our brands and products. We gained significant market share while also improving price mix in Brazil, and we continue to benefit from substantial fixed cost reduction actions, which we began implementing last year.
On Slide 18, our priorities in Latin America have not changed. We remain well-prepared to manage through volatility, as we have done consistently over the past several quarters through cost productivity, significant market share gains and positive price mix. For a couple quarters now, we've been monitoring the difference between sell-in and sell-out volumes in the Brazilian market, at which time [ph] because we've seen our trade customers build some inventory, we are expecting an inventory correction in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we now expect the Brazil industry to be down 10% to 12% for the full year. We now expect to deliver 6.5% to 7% operating margins for the full year.
Now we turn to our third quarter results for the Asia region, which are shown on Slide 19. 
Net sales were $338 million versus $346 million in the prior year period. Excluding the impact of currency, sales increased 2%. Our ongoing operating profit was $17 million compared to $27 million in the prior year period. Ongoing operating margins were 4.9% as continued demand softness and price/mix challenges in China more than offset continued record performance in India. 
Turning to Slide 20. You will see our 2016 priorities for Asia. We are focused on marketplace investments on our core product offerings, driving strong mix. The brand transition from Sanyo to Whirpool is progressing, and we are now focused on increasing awareness of our Whirlpool brand. As a result of these actions we're confident in our ability to deliver our long-term margin goals in the Asia region. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Jim Peters.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we delivered another quarter of record results despite operating in a challenging external environment. Turning to our third quarter results on Slide 22. Net sales were $5.2 billion. We achiev
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we delivered another quarter of record results despite operating in a challenging external environment. 
Turning to our third quarter results on Slide 22. Net sales were $5.2 billion. We achieved record ongoing earnings of $3.66 per share, primarily driven by strong delivery of acquisition synergies, unit volume growth and ongoing cost productivity program. Currency had a top line impact of approximately $40 million and reduced EBIT margins by approximately 1 point. 
Some currencies have strengthened against the U.S. dollar, most notably in Canada and Brazil. However, we are hedged at rates more reflective of last year's environment, and as such, we are not seeing the full benefit of those currencies strengthening in our operating margin. Our third quarter tax rate was driven by the timing of tax settlements and planning activities, and we now expect a 19% tax rate for the full year. Overall, we are pleased with our results through the first 3 quarters of 2016 and are on track to deliver strong full year results.
On Slide 23, we provide an update on the progress of our restructuring and acquisition integration activities. Through the third quarter, we have incurred restructuring expenses of $116 million and delivered $165 million in benefits. We continue to expect $200 million in expense and $200 million in benefits for the full year, which is ahead of plan. I will now discuss our expectations for full year EBIT margin expansion on Slide 24.
As Marc discussed in the regional reviews, we have seen elevated promotional activity in the U.S. since our last call, as well as delayed benefits of our previously announced cost base price increases in the U.K. Both had a negative impact on our price/mix, which we now expect to be flat to slightly negative for the year. We are also slightly reducing our ongoing cost productivity due to the impact of softer global demand on production levels.  As a result of these changes, we now expect to deliver approximately 7.5% EBIT margin for the full year, more than 0.5 point expansion over the prior year. 
On Slide 25, we share some details of our free cash flow results and capital allocation actions through the third quarter. Our free cash flow improved versus prior year, primarily due to improved earnings. We expect full year free cash flow of $700 million, which is inclusive of $150 million of restructuring cash outlays and $155 million associated with legacy product warranty actions in EMEA. Consistent with our strategy, we continue to execute a balanced approach to capital allocation by funding the capital needs of our business and returning cash to our shareholders.
We have executed $425 million in share repurchases year-to-date, and we plan to buy back additional shares in the fourth quarter, consistent with our prior statement.
Turning to Slide 26. We are adjusting our full year guidance, as discussed earlier. We are confident in our operational plans and expect to deliver up to 15% growth in ongoing earnings per share and approximately $700 million in free cash flow in 2016.
Now I'd like to turn it back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Turning to Slide 28, I'd like to summarize our discussion today. We have deployed strong actions to offset the operating challenges we faced in the third quarter. We do expect to deliver another record year, including about a 15% EPS growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Turning to Slide 28, I'd like to summarize our discussion today. 
We have deployed strong actions to offset the operating challenges we faced in the third quarter. We do expect to deliver another record year, including about a 15% EPS growth and strong free cash flow. 
On Slide 29, you'll see our long-term value creation strategy, which remains unchanged. We are committed to being the best global brand and consumer products company in the world. 
We believe our ability to generate earnings growth and free cash flow is very strong. We have the leading market positions in 3 of the 4 regions [ph] the world, a very strong platform for our continued growth. And our brands are very well-established and reach over 90% [ph] of the clients consumers [ph] globally. So we are confident that our strategy will continue to deliver significant value. 
Finally, on Slide 30, I want to make a few comments on our 2016 operating performance and over a longer period of time. Over the last 5 years, we have delivered record results, including -- counting 2016, with over 20% annualized earnings EPS growth despite what I would describe a challenging external environment. And in the last 2 years, we've absorbed over $6 per share impact from global currencies weakening against the U.S. dollar in a very unprecedented manner. Additionally, we've seen significant demand declines in our major emerging markets, which are Brazil, Russia and China. This has had a $2 impact per share over the last 2 years. But within this environment, we were able to grow our earnings by 10% in 2015, and we expect to grow them additionally by 15% this year. And all while driving strong free cash flow. We've used that cash to reinvest in our business, increase our dividend, pay down debt and buy back nearly $700 million in stock. 
Today, managing through economic volatility is the new normal, and it's part of our everyday operating management system. We believe that we continue to demonstrate our ability to navigate through those challenges, and because of that, we remain confident in our ability to effectively manage our business in this type of environment. 
So in total, we believe we have significant opportunities to continue creating shareholder value going forward. 
So with that, I'm going to end our formal remarks, and we'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Megan McGrath with MKM Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Megan McGrath with MKM Partners.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, a little bit of a practical question on the U.S. market in relation to the washers business. And you indicated that you're going to -- you've started cost base price increases, but you've dealt with this before in the past in terms of this
componenttext: I guess, first, a little bit of a practical question on the U.S. market in relation to the washers business. And you indicated that you're going to -- you've started cost base price increases, but you've dealt with this before in the past in terms of this dumping behavior. How, from a practical perspective, do you implement price increases in an environment where your competitors are lowering their prices aggressively?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc Bitzer. Let me try to answer. First of all, let me first talk about what happened in Q3 in washers and what we are going to do about it going forward. First of all, in Q3, as we indicated in our remarks, we saw an increased promotional in
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc Bitzer. Let me try to answer. First of all, let me first talk about what happened in Q3 in washers and what we are going to do about it going forward. First of all, in Q3, as we indicated in our remarks, we saw an increased promotional intensity, in particular, in washers. I would say all the other categories had promotional intensity, but nothing earth-shattering [ph] or surprising to our -- from our perspective. In washers, it was more intense. To some extent, we were not completely surprised because we saw certain competitors stockpiling a lot of inventory at the end of Q2, and I think we made a remark on that during the last earnings call. The negative impact on us is kind of twofold, if you want to say. One, because obviously, we cannot and will not participate in certain value-destructing promotions. So of course, you lose volume and, thus, [ph] the leverage in your overall production. Two, is a mix element, because if you basically have the high-end of your range by certain competitor pulled down very much, [ph] you lose a lot of mix. To be more specific, take a typical front load washer, we have a line structure anywhere from $399 or $499 to $999 -- not $399, $499 to $999. [ph] If certain competitors bring that down to $599 or even below, it's hard to build a line structure, and therefore, you lose mix. So you had [ph] a twofold negative impact on our business. What we're going to do about it, apart from continue to invest in new product and innovation, which we are launching in the market, [ph] is two, yes, we have announced certain price increases because we felt that certain price levels just do not reflect the cost investment we [ph] put behind product. These price effects or cost base price increases are in effect for January 1. Thirdly, as Jeff also indicated, we are continuing to pursue the antidumping lawsuits. We remain confident in our ability to win on this one So I think the combination of all these 3 elements make us believe that we can fully restore our margins in the washer business.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more? Your unit actually were up nicely in the quarter in North America. So it does look like overall, you might have gained share. It sounds like it wasn't in washers. I'm not sure if there was some growth outside th
componenttext: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more? Your unit actually were up nicely in the quarter in North America. So it does look like overall, you might have gained share. It sounds like it wasn't in washers. I'm not sure if there was some growth outside the U.S. Could you talk us through your unit growth a little bit in the quarter?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Megan, it's Marc again. First of all, let me also remind everybody on the call that our unit growth is not exactly reflective of T6 or T7 industry numbers. Several times before so already, on call it the outside the T6 or T7 volume we saw solid growt
componenttext: Yes, Megan, it's Marc again. First of all, let me also remind everybody on the call that our unit growth is not exactly reflective of T6 or T7 industry numbers. Several times before so already, on call it the outside the T6 or T7 volume we saw solid growth in Canada, Mexico and also in our KitchenAid SDA business which had an above-average unit growth, a slightly negative impact our ASPs but overall has some margin. If you peel back the onion and go back to T6 or T7 units, solid growth refrigeration and dishwasher, cooking business, but of course in particular the washer segment, our market share progress was not [indiscernible].

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Next, we'll move to Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions if I could. Jim, could you help us with the earnings sensitivity of the pound? Knowing that it weakened after the quarter? And then talk about based on the fact that you're seeing maybe increasing the weak demand in the U.K., your ab
componenttext: A couple of questions if I could. Jim, could you help us with the earnings sensitivity of the pound? Knowing that it weakened after the quarter? And then talk about based on the fact that you're seeing maybe increasing the weak demand in the U.K., your ability to offset that sort of pressure next year, with subsequent price increases?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam. And to begin with as I talked about the script earlier, with the pound right now, while we are seeing some weakness to it, we still are hedged within the U.K. so we'll continue to see ongoing weakness in the U.K. but as Marc talked about earlier
componenttext: Yes, Sam. And to begin with as I talked about the script earlier, with the pound right now, while we are seeing some weakness to it, we still are hedged within the U.K. so we'll continue to see ongoing weakness in the U.K. but as Marc talked about earlier, our price increases are now beginning to take hold. And so I would say that as you look into Q4, we still will have an impact, deteriorating impact to the pound but it will begin to be more offset by the price increases at that point.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc. Let me just give me a bit of context and color on this one. As we indicated in earlier calls, our U.K. business at the time of the acquisition was roughly about $1 billion. So it's a very significant business. We have strong market positio
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc. Let me just give me a bit of context and color on this one. As we indicated in earlier calls, our U.K. business at the time of the acquisition was roughly about $1 billion. So it's a very significant business. We have strong market position and strong above average operating margin. If you just look at a pure currency now Q3 over Q3 last year, you basically have roughly 22% decline. So it's been massive. To Jim's earlier point, it has been a little bit moderated because of some hedging programs, but it's still massive. You also need to keep in mind that about 85% to -- yes roughly 85% of products which we sell in the U.K. are imported or produced on a euro base. So you basically have a full cost base impact on this one. So it's significant. The $40 [ph] million impact, which I referred to in the script, is related to one, obviously the margin loss because of higher cost base; and two, we implemented a price increase in September -- or we started to implement it and yes, we saw significant volume reduction in the month of September. The combination of these 2 things were roughly $40 million. So it's by definition, a massive impact on our operating results in Europe in Q3. To your question about the price increases and the progress, we had a small price increase in July, where we frankly had a hard time getting traction. We're seen the traction on the invoices, but yes, we still have a drag on the volume. And we expect that drag also be there for Q4 a slightly lower level.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: To Marc's point, probably over 95% of all products sold in the U.K. are imported. So our view is that pricing is critical for us to get our margins back. And I think others will have to [indiscernible].
componenttext: To Marc's point, probably over 95% of all products sold in the U.K. are imported. So our view is that pricing is critical for us to get our margins back. And I think others will have to [indiscernible].

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In isolation, what's the EPS impact of just the pound for 2017 of where we are right now, trying to get a sense of that.
componenttext: In isolation, what's the EPS impact of just the pound for 2017 of where we are right now, trying to get a sense of that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We said in third quarter, again, without -- where you the impact of the pound, we had the impact cost us basically $40 million, which is roughly $0.40 a share so it's really big for a quarter. But going forward, 2 things. One is the rate that we get a pri
componenttext: We said in third quarter, again, without -- where you the impact of the pound, we had the impact cost us basically $40 million, which is roughly $0.40 a share so it's really big for a quarter. But going forward, 2 things. One is the rate that we get a price increase, which we said it would take at least a couple of quarters for us to work this through our system. And to Jim's point, we are normal -- we have are normal hedging process in place which will smooth out some of the volatility but we have the whole impact to do that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Sam, in our guidance we talked about a 1 point impact due to currency through the year what we've seen the weakening of the pound, strengthening some other currencies offset each other. So we still feel that is correct accurate for the full basket of
componenttext: And Sam, in our guidance we talked about a 1 point impact due to currency through the year what we've seen the weakening of the pound, strengthening some other currencies offset each other. So we still feel that is correct accurate for the full basket of currencies for this year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last question before I defer to others, the cash flow guidance was lower more so at least by my math than the EPS guidance, are you drilling down inventories outside -- I think you mentioned the EMEA, you're drawing down inventories. Where should we antic
componenttext: Last question before I defer to others, the cash flow guidance was lower more so at least by my math than the EPS guidance, are you drilling down inventories outside -- I think you mentioned the EMEA, you're drawing down inventories. Where should we anticipate inventories by year-end based on current plans?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at our guidance and our free cash flow guidance is more reflective of lower earnings, being at the lower end of our earnings. We went to the lower end of our free cash flow guidance. Again, inventory we think will be relatively consist
componenttext: I think if you look at our guidance and our free cash flow guidance is more reflective of lower earnings, being at the lower end of our earnings. We went to the lower end of our free cash flow guidance. Again, inventory we think will be relatively consistent year-over-year. So I don't think you're going to see a big change there. They will come down significantly in the fourth quarter as we talked about and Marc talked about some of the actions that we are taking.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe it's for Jeff, just big picture, 2018 you guys have talked about earning $20 to $22 per share and today you're taking down your margin targets for this year -- or for the full year, and you also reduced cash flow guidance. Is this kind of a temporar
componenttext: Maybe it's for Jeff, just big picture, 2018 you guys have talked about earning $20 to $22 per share and today you're taking down your margin targets for this year -- or for the full year, and you also reduced cash flow guidance. Is this kind of a temporary adjustment to kind of macro environment soft patch in the U.S. and U.K? Or do you feel like current trends will make it a lot more difficult to get your long-term EPS targets?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, again, it really relates to our -- the time it takes us for a recovery as we talked about here. But nothing fundamentally has changed about what I would call our long-term strategic drivers of our earnings and free cash flow potential. So the goals w
componenttext: Bob, again, it really relates to our -- the time it takes us for a recovery as we talked about here. But nothing fundamentally has changed about what I would call our long-term strategic drivers of our earnings and free cash flow potential. So the goals we have out there, $23 billion to $24 billion, 9% to 10% EBIT, 5% to 6% free cash flow which would equate roughly to $20 to $22 a share, we still think our global operating model certainly has the capability of delivering that. What we're dealing with right now as you saw is we're dealing with some fairly substantial external shocks that we had taken actions for, and some things, like as Marc mentioned the demand in the U.S. we think will light itself in the coming months, the U.K.'s going to take longer; and we've got to see the effect of this elevated promotional scheme in the U.S. But having said all that, I would say that the goals we feel good about, we're assessing the timing of those goals given where we are at this moment. In our January call, as we normally do, we'll give our 2017 guidance and provide you the very thorough update on our long-range goals.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And maybe you can just drill down if you try to segregate North America, what part of the headwind was just from increased promotional activity? And what part was due to general consumer weakness? I mean, it does seem that the consumer is
componenttext: That's helpful. And maybe you can just drill down if you try to segregate North America, what part of the headwind was just from increased promotional activity? And what part was due to general consumer weakness? I mean, it does seem that the consumer is freaked out a little bit around the election. Do you think that's kind of a transitory thing? And since the end of the quarter just looking at shipments, do you feel the consumers kind of back in action? This is just a lull in demand that will self correct? Or is this something more like a change in the trajectory of what you anticipated?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, this is Marc. First of all, in Q3, we still expanded margins in North America. So we moved from 12.0 to 12.1. Having said that, strong environment less promotion pressure would have been significantly different. That's very obvious. So to your first
componenttext: Bob, this is Marc. First of all, in Q3, we still expanded margins in North America. So we moved from 12.0 to 12.1. Having said that, strong environment less promotion pressure would have been significantly different. That's very obvious. So to your first question about the consumer demand, to some extent, it's a little bit of a speculative answer, but we do see -- span of attention is right now shifting towards discretionary demand and ultimately yes, we see what we think is a temporary softness of consumer confidence. As you know in our products and particularly discretionary demand is larger by consumer confidence. Will that improve and recover after November 8? Probably not immediately, not the next day but over time, we expect it to do so. If you also look at the fundamentals will be included in the presentation in the script, the fundamentals of the housing market are 100% intact. You can look at it from whatever angle, we just don't see a slowdown of the cycle. So in the broader scheme of things, we see the consumer sentiment right now being of a very temporary nature, and we do see a full recovery in 2017.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we move to Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Next, we move to Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a lot of different pieces moving here. I wonder if you could just -- if I could focus Europe on the margin reduction from the second quarter, roughly 100 bps times your sales would imply closer to kind of a $50 million EBIT headwind or $0.50. And in th
componenttext: So a lot of different pieces moving here. I wonder if you could just -- if I could focus Europe on the margin reduction from the second quarter, roughly 100 bps times your sales would imply closer to kind of a $50 million EBIT headwind or $0.50. And in the U.S., your 50 bp margin reduction on the revenue base kind of is roughly a $50 million EBIT. Yet, you didn't fully take down earnings as much as that margin reduction times sales would imply. First question, not to be too positive here, but what is the offset to that margin times sales, which is a drag? I mean, because it seems in your margin guidance, you're not really -- you're actually getting less productivity.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, if you look at overall EPS guidance in that it didn't come down at the same level. As I highlighted earlier slightly better tax rate than we had before, and that is compensating for some of the earnings offset there. Again, I think that's probably
componenttext: I mean, if you look at overall EPS guidance in that it didn't come down at the same level. As I highlighted earlier slightly better tax rate than we had before, and that is compensating for some of the earnings offset there. Again, I think that's probably the biggest driver, the offset.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing, Ken, is obviously the changes that we're dealing with. We really had a strong handle on fixed cost and so on. So we probably have some corporate overhead cost. But tax and corporate overhead are basically the offsets to that.
componenttext: And the only other thing, Ken, is obviously the changes that we're dealing with. We really had a strong handle on fixed cost and so on. So we probably have some corporate overhead cost. But tax and corporate overhead are basically the offsets to that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate, guys. Now just to get into the operational component. For the European 100 bp, can you isolate that relative to the -- I mean, how much is this pound versus core market or your execution? And obviously there's price lags for the -- but
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate, guys. Now just to get into the operational component. For the European 100 bp, can you isolate that relative to the -- I mean, how much is this pound versus core market or your execution? And obviously there's price lags for the -- but how much of that reduction is associated with the pound?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Marc. First of all coming back because you mentioned there is a lot of moving pieces. There are exactly 3 moving pieces that you referred to. That's a temporary slowdown in U.S. demand, promotional environment in washers and the Brexit-related i
componenttext: Ken, it's Marc. First of all coming back because you mentioned there is a lot of moving pieces. There are exactly 3 moving pieces that you referred to. That's a temporary slowdown in U.S. demand, promotional environment in washers and the Brexit-related impact. We don't have any other issues [indiscernible] 3. By definition, some of that drag, we expect also in Q4 even to a lesser extent. We do see a slight recovery of U.S. demand in Q4, not as bad as in Q3. The promotional environment in U.S., it's probably going to last in Q4, but not beyond. U.K. will be less but still somewhat impact in Q4. So that's on a macro level. Now specifically to Europe, when we basically take the $40 million which I referred to earlier Brexit related, that is entire or more than entire year-over-year drop or in other words, we continue to make excellent progress on the  cost takeout related to the integration and synergies, but it's been entirely offset by the impact which we had in the U.K. And that's obviously been very impactful. Will that be also an impact in Q4? Yes, but to a lesser extent.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: So just picking up on what you're saying just now, Marc, you said that the promotional environment in the U.S. would last through the fourth quarter but not beyond. Can you comment on how washing machine inventories look at this point? I mean, is there still an overhang heading into the fourth quarter? Or what gives you confidence that we'll see the promotional environment improving?

componenttext: Denise, it's Marc. So particularly on the question of inventory there's 2 aspects which we need to look at. One is what is likely inventory level of certain competitors. We knew coming into the quarter there's been a massive stockpiling coming in.

componenttext: Now is evidenced by the Department of Commerce.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do think, but we don't have certainty a large amount of inventory has been -- which we burn through. So there will be some inventory overhang into Q4. Now the other side of the equation is trade inventory. We do believe that the trade inventory wer
componenttext: And we do think, but we don't have certainty a large amount of inventory has been -- which we burn through. So there will be some inventory overhang into Q4. Now the other side of the equation is trade inventory. We do believe that the trade inventory were slightly low coming into Q4 or low ending Q3. So it's not a massive impact, but we would expect at least from our perspective the trade inventory on Whirlpool brand, our Whirlpool Corporation brand product be 100,000 to 150,000 below what have been last year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. I know that your Q is going to be out later this afternoon, but could you talk a little bit about just directionally gross margin was in each market And also if there was anything unusual in SG&A this quarter that we should be aware of?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if look at gross margin across the globe, what you'll see is it's relatively flat compared to prior year and it's in line with where our operating profit is. And so even if you break it down by the various regions which are going to see, it's that the
componenttext: So if look at gross margin across the globe, what you'll see is it's relatively flat compared to prior year and it's in line with where our operating profit is. And so even if you break it down by the various regions which are going to see, it's that the change in gross margin is very similar to what you see in the change in operating profit today. So without going through the individual ones, that's what you'll see. And I think Marc's talked about the drivers.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first question, I got a couple questions for you. First is just on the raw materials and if we saw some inflation this quarter and how we should think about how raw material cost inflation for 4Q.
componenttext: Just first question, I got a couple questions for you. First is just on the raw materials and if we saw some inflation this quarter and how we should think about how raw material cost inflation for 4Q.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Jeff. Actually, I think we've been -- as we progress through the year through contracts or hedging or whatever, we're pretty stable in terms of the improvements that we've done what we saw for the full year in raw material. So I wouldn't sa
componenttext: David, this is Jeff. Actually, I think we've been -- as we progress through the year through contracts or hedging or whatever, we're pretty stable in terms of the improvements that we've done what we saw for the full year in raw material. So I wouldn't say there's any material change. There will be less as we indicated I think the last call that the second half, although improving -- because we're going against year-ago base, less of an improvement versus last year but will still be positive. And then looking forward, there's a lot of moving parts, but I don't see anything in the environment that's extraordinarily unusual at this point in time. We don't -- we're pretty locked in for 2016. We're still working on 2017, which we'll talk about in January. But for now, I'd say it's stable.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just second question, I guess, the situation this quarter frames up the challenge you face in trying to defend or gain share in the competitive space. I guess my question is how are you thinking these days about the possibility of substanti
componenttext: Okay. And then just second question, I guess, the situation this quarter frames up the challenge you face in trying to defend or gain share in the competitive space. I guess my question is how are you thinking these days about the possibility of substantially increasing your investment innovation? And also driving productivity on the current level investment by holding your new product development organization accountable for higher hit rate?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we are investing very strongly for innovation. I think we're never been in a better spot in terms of the rate of innovation that we bring in the marketplace. This is a global competitive business. Productivity's always strongly part of our glob
componenttext: Yes, well, we are investing very strongly for innovation. I think we're never been in a better spot in terms of the rate of innovation that we bring in the marketplace. This is a global competitive business. Productivity's always strongly part of our global operating system. And when there's opportunities to raw material costs and so on, we can deliver very strong productivity, as we are right now. Now having said that, we've seen, and as you mentioned certain competitors who -- in our case in the case of washing, we believe strongly are dumping imports in the U.S. market and that's why we also are using global trade mechanisms to try to address the situation. But you should expect more innovation from us, you should expect ongoing productivity from us. And again, as I've said before, we believe in earning market share not buying market share.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the discussion on price increases and recent promotional activity, but maybe you could add a bit more color on how you feel like elasticity trending? So that's both in consumer and retail channels. So it's obviously early to talk about 2017 r
componenttext: I appreciate the discussion on price increases and recent promotional activity, but maybe you could add a bit more color on how you feel like elasticity trending? So that's both in consumer and retail channels. So it's obviously early to talk about 2017 raw materials, but how do you think the market could receive those higher prices?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about this in the past. There's at the kind of prices we're talking about, there's no elasticity. Consumers are in the marketplace probably every 10 years for a product. Their reference points is whatever they happen to look at this week onli
componenttext: We've talked about this in the past. There's at the kind of prices we're talking about, there's no elasticity. Consumers are in the marketplace probably every 10 years for a product. Their reference points is whatever they happen to look at this week online. They have a budget, and whether it's a $399 washer or a $1,499 washer, we offer models at every price point. So again, I don't really believe in the case of the U.S, that has any impact at levels we're talking about demand.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, just to clarify what Jeff was referring to. The reason no price elasticity on a U.S. industry demand perspective, i.e. you come down prices doesn't change anything on our '16 or '17 industry guidance. There is, however, a short-term impact if somebo
componenttext: Marc, just to clarify what Jeff was referring to. The reason no price elasticity on a U.S. industry demand perspective, i.e. you come down prices doesn't change anything on our '16 or '17 industry guidance. There is, however, a short-term impact if somebody else promotes a front-load washer at $499 while our range starts at $699. Of course, we feel that and that is what we referred to.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I guess there are some misconceptions around higher GE. Do you see the industry's a little more competitive with these business under higher ownership? Or is it more of a continuation of being a strong competitor?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I guess there are some misconceptions around higher GE. Do you see the industry's a little more competitive with these business under higher ownership? Or is it more of a continuation of being a strong competitor?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marc. First of all, obviously hard for us to comment on any competitor because we don't talk to them. In simple terms, first of all, you got to bear in mind the integration is still fairly fresh, so it's been just 1 or slightly more than a quarter be
componenttext: It's Marc. First of all, obviously hard for us to comment on any competitor because we don't talk to them. In simple terms, first of all, you got to bear in mind the integration is still fairly fresh, so it's been just 1 or slightly more than a quarter behind it. And so far, I don't see any different behavior. GE has been a very tough competitor, and I think they continue to be that. So we don't see a massive change in their behavior contrary to what some people have speculated about.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I just had a question on North America. I saw the volumes are very nice, but from a price mix standpoint, maybe you could provide a little bit more color on the moving pieces. I know that FX had I think about a point of an impact that you talked about product launches and sort of what's going on with washers. But are there any other elements that are sort of dragging on mix, given that you've got all these product launches and I would expect some positive price mix.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marc again. So let me maybe just give a little bit perspective. And of course, first of all, in our unit numbers, there's a lot of moving pieces. There's Canada, Mexico with different currency elements. Having said that if you want to kind of pinpoin
componenttext: It's Marc again. So let me maybe just give a little bit perspective. And of course, first of all, in our unit numbers, there's a lot of moving pieces. There's Canada, Mexico with different currency elements. Having said that if you want to kind of pinpoint 2 elements which explains the slight ASP decline, average sales decline, is one we related to earlier, is the promotions in washers; and two, we had higher KitchenAid small domestic appliance growth. So it's quite a bit above our average growth in the region, which negatively impacts the average sales value but knowing that it's a very high margin, it helps our profitability.

componenttext: Two questions for you. First of all, on the market share, I hear the comment that KitchenAid small appliance had a good quarter. Can you just give us some contracts relative to AHAM 6 in the quarter just trying to gauge a more accurate valuation of market share gains because it doesn't sound like the 7 versus 0 is the right compare. And then secondly, curious, Jeff, as you think about the benefit from the antidumping ruling coming in January, how we should be thinking about how that might influence the industry and your performance in 2017?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, it's Marc. Let me first try the share perspective. Overall, as we commented earlier, we roughly had 1 point of share growth year-over-year. That is, of course, the result of moving -- different elements. First of all, if you split by product, our wa
componenttext: Eric, it's Marc. Let me first try the share perspective. Overall, as we commented earlier, we roughly had 1 point of share growth year-over-year. That is, of course, the result of moving -- different elements. First of all, if you split by product, our washer market share has not been there. Actually, year-over-year, it's been disappointing. Having said that, refrigeration dish washing and cooking, we had almost more than 1 share point of growth. That's been satisfying. And then you have the other component which is branded versus nonbranded part of our sales. As you can imagine, not own brands piece has been coming down year-over-year but branded piece has seen very strong growth in the entire Q3.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Eric, regarding the antidumping, first of all just a reminder in the process in December it's expected Department of Commerce will establish the final tariffs. You may remember, the preliminary tariffs were over 50% for one competitor and over 100% fo
componenttext: And Eric, regarding the antidumping, first of all just a reminder in the process in December it's expected Department of Commerce will establish the final tariffs. You may remember, the preliminary tariffs were over 50% for one competitor and over 100% for another one. So they were's substantial. And then -- so that will happen in December, and then the ITC will make the final ruling on that dumping discuss caused injury to the washer business in the U.S., and we expect that ruling in January. So at that point in time, and we do see assume we're going to be successful here, those competitors will have to pay really high tariffs or they'll have to do something else. And at the same time -- and again, I don't want to over emphasize this, but as Marc said, we had one competitor in the second quarter ship in months and months of supply in advance of trying to -- as the DOC ruled, beat the cash deposits. And unloading that inventory in the third or perhaps part of the fourth quarter has been a real strain of the operating margin and caused a lot of injury to the washer business. So basically, again I can't speak what competitors are going to do. I know we're going to run our business in an economical way. We're going to earn our market share through great products, and we going to fully expect to make positive margins on them as well.

componenttext: Given your view that the U.S. trends are temporary, Marc, what would lead you to think that is not temporary? I mean, I guess I saw the macro slide that you guys had in your deck, but what variables would lead you to think that these things are kind of slowing versus these long-term rates as you look at for the U.S. markets specifically?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, it's Marc. I mean, again, if you look at the fundamentals -- first of all, in demand trends in housing, household formations intact, employment is getting better, income is finally arriving in the mid-and lower income levels. So we have a lot of --
componenttext: Again, it's Marc. I mean, again, if you look at the fundamentals -- first of all, in demand trends in housing, household formations intact, employment is getting better, income is finally arriving in the mid-and lower income levels. So we have a lot of -- and mortgages and affordability is still very positive. So you have a lot of positive trends on there. We always argued for the last 3 years, and I would still argue, the entire call it housing boom is been constrained by supply side. There's not been enough developed lots issues about getting enough construction workers. Severe supply constraint which also explains a little bit of how prices came up so quickly. So that was the constraint, which we slowly start see easing but not a rapid pace. So if you want to find any negative which could impact that, you can, of course, if the Fed rates would come up too fast, too quickly, that could have an impact. I don't think that's likely, but I don't know. But outside of this one, you would have to find any macro economic outside the housing industry and appliance industry which could impact the confidence.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, I'll just add as Marc mentioned, the fundamentals of appliance demand all are still very strong and we think will be for some time. If you look at the trends, it was an odd trend. The first half was up 5%, and July, August were down about 5%. Tha
componenttext: And Ken, I'll just add as Marc mentioned, the fundamentals of appliance demand all are still very strong and we think will be for some time. If you look at the trends, it was an odd trend. The first half was up 5%, and July, August were down about 5%. That's a 10-point swing, you don't see that very often. And then, we look at other household product category and we saw similar trends. So I think data suggests that the consumer got cautious. Typically, that doesn't last for long periods of time particularly when there's uncertainty ahead. that's why we have confidence it will continue to see growth.

componenttext: Yes, Denise. I wouldn't consider that a big change, it's just the timing of certain projects when we started them, where all of the major innovation that we expected to get out this year, we are. Obviously, we're managing things tightly, but we're certainly not cutting back on anything that we're bringing in the marketplace. Got a full pipeline ready for 2017, so this is just probably more timing than anything else.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Denise, it's Marc. So first of all, let's differentiate overall industry trends from our own demand. I would say, overall, the European markets and we don't yet have a final data for Europe. I would expect them to be closure to 2%. We early indicated
componenttext: Yes. Denise, it's Marc. So first of all, let's differentiate overall industry trends from our own demand. I would say, overall, the European markets and we don't yet have a final data for Europe. I would expect them to be closure to 2%. We early indicated 0% to 2% for the full year and in Q3 somewhere between 1.5% to 2%. But it's too early because we don't have a final data. Also on a full year basis, I would say the entire European market 0% to 2%, probably ending close over [ph] 2%. So the fundamentals of demand in Europe are not that horrible. It's the currency which impacts a lot. If you kind of peel back the onion, of course, a lot of moving pieces I think for us the most promising sign going forward is start seeing recovery in the U.S., in Russia and Ukraine. That's an early sign, but you know in this acquisition, we're very exposed to both U.K. and Russia. And right now, both markets are soft from currency and demand. But we see Russia slowly coming back. And it's now early to call it a recovery but early signs are promising. Specifically to our demand, for us, U.K. markets is better as a market when we saw in our demand. That is directly related to us coming out of price increases in September. The rest of the industry did not fully follow and that impacted our demand. That's the particular impact. Outside of the U.K., I would say by and large, our demand is solid. Probably the only other exception will be Middle East and Africa, which is still being impacted by uncertainty by entire space.
