headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would now like to turn the conference over to the Senior Director of Investor Relati
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would now like to turn the conference over to the Senior Director of Investor Relations, Chris Conley. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Jim Peters, our C
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Whirlpool Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Marc Bitzer, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Jim Peters, our Chief Financial Officer.
Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investors section of our website at whirlpoolcorp.com.
Before we begin, let me remind you that as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corporation's future expectations.
Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed on our latest 10-K and our other periodic reports, as well as on Slide 1 of the presentation.
Turning to Slide 2. We want to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP measures.
We believe these measures are important indicators of our operation and they exclude items that may not be indicative of or are unrelated to results from our ongoing business operations. We also think the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for analyzing trends in our ongoing business operations.
Listeners are directed to the supplemental information package posted on our Investor Relations section of our website for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
[Operator Instructions] 
With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, our operational execution offset some significant external challenges that we saw in the quarter. But we did deliver record results for the third qua
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw in our press release this morning, our operational execution offset some significant external challenges that we saw in the quarter. But we did deliver record results for the third quarter. 
During the quarter, currency continued to be volatile and negative and we saw some softness in the appliance demand, most prominently in the U.K. and the U.S. Despite this volatility, we are able to deliver record results, and year-to-date, our earnings have increased by 18%. In North America and Latin America, we expanded margins while gaining market share, which was done by leveraging our leading brands, launching innovative new products and delivering strong ongoing cost productivity. And finally, consistent with our balanced capital allocation approach, we've repurchased $100 million of our common stock during the quarter. 
Overall, the fundamentals of our business remains strong, and we continue to adapt to our operating plans in order to deliver strong results.
I'll now turn to Slide 5, where you'll see our third quarter results. 
Our revenues, ex currency, increased slightly. Our ongoing business earnings grew to a record $3.66 a share. It is gained through a combination of acquisition synergies, unit volume growth and ongoing cost productivities. And we improved our free cash flow for the year.
Turning to Slide 6. We have an update on the external environment and some of the challenges that we're facing and offsetting. We have seen what we believe is a temporary softness in industry demand in the U.S., particularly you saw earlier in the quarter in July and August, with some rebound in September. We believe this is due to consumer confidence we gained primarily due to the focus around the U.S. elections.
In addition, the promotional environment in the U.S. has been -- has elevated during the quarter, especially in the washing machine category. There, certain import competitors continue to unlawfully dump product, and we're responding with continued investment in our strong brands, launching new, innovative products, as well as our fair trade actions. 
For the year, in Europe, our integration is on track and we're delivering cost synergies in line with our plans. And our previously discussed margin recovery actions in Europe are progressing, and we do expect to see the positive impact of these actions over the next couple of quarters, somewhat later than we originally thought because we continue to see currency and demand volatility, particularly in the U.K. market.
Overall, we expect to deliver a record performance this year with approximately 15% ongoing EPS growth, over 0.5 point of ongoing EBIT margin improvement and good improvement in free cash flow. 
On Slide 7, we've updated our 2016 guidance to reflect these changes. We now expect to deliver ongoing earnings of $14 to $14.25 a share and to generate approximately $700 million in free cash flow.
Turning to Slide 8. We show our balanced capital allocation approach, which has not changed. We continue to appropriately fund our business and expect to invest between $650 million and $700 million in capital this year. As I mentioned, we did repurchase $100 million in share repurchases during the third quarter, and we do intend to continue repurchasing stock in the fourth quarter. So in total, we remain committed to delivering our long-term value creation objectives through our operational execution and a balanced approach to capital allocation.
So with that, I'm going to turn it over to Marc Bitzer to review our global operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review our performance in North America. Net sales increased 2% versus prior year and grew 3% excluding currency, and we expanded our ongoing operating margins to a third quarter recor
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 10, we will review our performance in North America. Net sales increased 2% versus prior year and grew 3% excluding currency, and we expanded our ongoing operating margins to a third quarter record of 12.1%. Our operating margins were driven by strong ongoing cost productivity programs and unit volume growth, which more than offset approximately $25 million in unfavorable currency impact in Canada and Mexico. 
During the quarter, we gained over 1 point of market share versus the prior year as consumer demand for our brands and products have continued to be strong. As demonstrated by our performance, we remain focused on driving both revenue growth and margin expansion.
Turning to Slide 11. I will discuss some external factors affecting our North America region. As Jeff outlined earlier, we have seen a temporary slowdown in U.S. appliance industry demand since our last call. We are confident that the slip in consumer discretionary purchases is temporary as consumer confidence has been impacted by the upcoming U.S. elections. We increasingly see solid consumer demand for our strong brands and new products and expect to continue to generate profitable market share gains. However, we have seen an increase in promotional activity in the U.S., especially on washers. This corresponds with significant inventory stockpiling by certain competitors at the end of the second quarter, who we believe are continuing to unlawfully dump products. This higher promotional intensity had a significant negative impact on our washer margins in the third quarter. We continue to pursue our fair trade case for washers manufacturer in China and anticipate a final ruling in early 2017.
Additionally, we have recently announced cost base price increases, primarily in washers, to allow us to recover the cost of our investments in new and compelling products. We expect that these actions, along with a focus on value-creating promotions and strong productivity programs, will offset negative margin impacts from continued dumping by certain competitors.
We fully expect to deliver strong results in the fourth quarter and remain on track to achieve our long-term goal. 
Turning to Slide 12, we'll discuss key drivers of the U.S. appliance industry. The fundamental underpinning U.S. appliance demand are healthy. During recent years, we have seen steady growth in key macro indicators, including housing starts in both new and existing home sales, as well as improvements to other relevant indicators such as consumer sentiment and unemployment. While some of the individual monthly data is volatile, the trends overwhelmingly demonstrate strong demand for housing, increasing levels of employment, real wage growth and long-term improvement in consumer sentiment. We've seen 15 consecutive quarters of appliance industry growth in the U.S., and all of these underlying macro trends support continued growth to U.S. appliance industry in the coming years.
As such, we believe that the current industry slowdown is a temporary shift, consistent with what we're seeing in the retail environment for household goods and we remain confident that the multiyear cycle of U.S. demand growth will continue in 2017 and beyond. 
Turning to Slide 13. We outline our 2016 operational expectations for the North America region.  We now expect the industry to grow 3% to 4% for the full year. Through the end of the third quarter, the industry's up a little over 3.5%. We continue to expect to grow at or above industry rates with targeted investment in our strong brands and new products, as we have done consistently throughout the year. We continue to execute strong cost productivity programs and we remain focused on achieving growth in our adjacent businesses. We now expect to deliver 11.5% to 12% margin in 2016, an increase over the prior year.
Beginning on Slide 14, we will review our third quarter results for our Europe, Middle East and Africa regions. Sales were $1.3 billion, down 9% versus the prior year. Excluding the impact of currency, sales were down 6% as we saw demand softness in certain key countries, particularly in the U.K.
Ongoing operating margins were 3.7%. Our margins were negatively affected by approximately $40 million in unfavorable impact in our U.K. business from a devaluing British pound and softening demand environment.
Turning to Slide 15, we'll provide an update to our previously deployed actions in Europe. 
The integration of Indesit continue to be on track, and we fully expect to deliver planned cost synergies in the fourth quarter and into 2017. Consistent with what we've seen since the Brexit decision, currency continues to be a headwind and demand in the U.K. remains soft, causing our previously announced cost base price increase to be implemented slower than anticipated. Our platform integration and manufacturing transitions remain on track. However, we reduced manufacturing volumes in response to this lower demand, most of which occurred in the third quarter, and we now expect roughly 0.5 point margin impact for the full year. As a result, our margin expansion in Europe is slightly delayed. 
In summary, we believe we have the right actions in place to manage through volatility and deliver our long-term goals.
On Slide 16, our 2016 priorities for the European, Middle East and Africa region remain largely unchanged. There's a continued focus on integration activities, ongoing cost productivity and growth from adjacent businesses. Similar to the third quarter, we plan to manage inventory levels as we continue product and brand transitions in the fourth quarter.
Our industry guidance remains flat to up 2% for the full year. We now expect to deliver 4.5% to 5% operating margin for the full year and remain confident in our long-term margin guidance of 8%.
I will now discuss our Latin America results on Slide 17.
Sales for the quarter were $800 million, an increase of 7%. Excluding the impact of currencies, sales increased 2%. Our third quarter operating profit totaled $45 million, and margin increased 150 basis points versus the prior year. Despite operating in a challenging demand environment, we expanded margins and delivered strong revenue growth from continued investments in our brands and products. We gained significant market share while also improving price mix in Brazil, and we continue to benefit from substantial fixed cost reduction actions, which we began implementing last year.
On Slide 18, our priorities in Latin America have not changed. We remain well-prepared to manage through volatility, as we have done consistently over the past several quarters through cost productivity, significant market share gains and positive price mix. For a couple quarters now, we've been monitoring the difference between sell-in and sell-out volumes in the Brazilian market, at which time, because we've seen our trade customers build some inventory, we are expecting an inventory correction in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we now expect the Brazil industry to be down 10% to 12% for the full year. We now expect to deliver 6.5% to 7% operating margins for the full year.
Now we turn to our third quarter results for the Asia region, which are shown on Slide 19. 
Net sales were $338 million versus $346 million in the prior year period. Excluding the impact of currency, sales increased 2%. Our ongoing operating profit was $17 million compared to $27 million in the prior year period. Ongoing operating margins were 4.9% as continued demand softness and price/mix challenges in China more than offset continued record performance in India. 
Turning to Slide 20. You will see our 2016 priorities for Asia. We are focused on marketplace investments on our core product offerings, driving strong mix. The brand transition from Sanyo to Whirpool is progressing, and we are now focused on increasing awareness of our Whirlpool brand. As a result of these actions we're confident in our ability to deliver our long-term margin goals in the Asia region. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Jim Peters.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we delivered another quarter of record results despite operating in a challenging external environment. Turning to our third quarter results on Slide 22. Net sales were $5.2 billion. We achiev
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we delivered another quarter of record results despite operating in a challenging external environment. 
Turning to our third quarter results on Slide 22. Net sales were $5.2 billion. We achieved record ongoing earnings of $3.66 per share, primarily driven by strong delivery of acquisition synergies, unit volume growth and ongoing cost productivity program. Currency had a top line impact of approximately $40 million and reduced EBIT margins by approximately 1 point. 
Some currencies have strengthened against the U.S. dollar, most notably in Canada and Brazil. However, we are hedged at rates more reflective of last year's environment, and as such, we are not seeing the full benefit of those currencies strengthening in our operating margin. Our third quarter tax rate was driven by the timing of tax settlements and planning activities, and we now expect a 19% tax rate for the full year. Overall, we are pleased with our results through the first 3 quarters of 2016 and are on track to deliver strong full year results.
On Slide 23, we provide an update on the progress of our restructuring and acquisition integration activities. Through the third quarter, we have incurred restructuring expenses of $116 million and delivered $165 million in benefits. We continue to expect $200 million in expense and $200 million in benefits for the full year, which is ahead of plan. I will now discuss our expectations for full year EBIT margin expansion on Slide 24.
As Marc discussed in the regional reviews, we have seen elevated promotional activity in the U.S. since our last call, as well as delayed benefits of our previously announced cost base price increases in the U.K. Both had a negative impact on our price/mix, which we now expect to be flat to slightly negative for the year. We are also slightly reducing our ongoing cost productivity due to the impact of softer global demand on production levels.  As a result of these changes, we now expect to deliver approximately 7.5% EBIT margin for the full year, more than 0.5 point expansion over the prior year. 
On Slide 25, we share some details of our free cash flow results and capital allocation actions through the third quarter. Our free cash flow improved versus prior year, primarily due to improved earnings. We expect full year free cash flow of $700 million, which is inclusive of $150 million of restructuring cash outlays and $155 million associated with legacy product warranty actions in EMEA. Consistent with our strategy, we continue to execute a balanced approach to capital allocation by funding the capital needs of our business and returning cash to our shareholders.
We have executed $425 million in share repurchases year-to-date, and we plan to buy back additional shares in the fourth quarter, consistent with our prior statement.
Turning to Slide 26. We are adjusting our full year guidance, as discussed earlier. We are confident in our operational plans and expect to deliver up to 15% growth in ongoing earnings per share and approximately $700 million in free cash flow in 2016.
Now I'd like to turn it back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Turning to Slide 28, I'd like to summarize our discussion today. We have deployed strong actions to offset the operating challenges we faced in the third quarter. We do expect to deliver another record year, including about a 15% EPS growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Turning to Slide 28, I'd like to summarize our discussion today. 
We have deployed strong actions to offset the operating challenges we faced in the third quarter. We do expect to deliver another record year, including about a 15% EPS growth and strong free cash flow. 
On Slide 29, you'll see our long-term value creation strategy, which remains unchanged. We are committed to being the best global brand and consumer products company in the world. 
We believe our ability to generate earnings growth and free cash flow is very strong. We have the leading market positions in 3 of the 4 regions out of the world, a very strong platform for our continued growth. And our brands are very well-established and reach over 90% of the clients/consumers globally. So we are confident that our strategy will continue to deliver significant value. 
Finally, on Slide 30, I want to make a few comments on our 2016 operating performance and over a longer period of time. Over the last 5 years, we have delivered record results, including -- counting 2016, with over 20% annualized earnings EPS growth despite what I would describe a challenging external environment. And in the last 2 years, we've absorbed over $6 per share impact from global currencies weakening against the U.S. dollar in a very unprecedented manner. Additionally, we've seen significant demand declines in our major emerging markets, which are Brazil, Russia and China. This has had a $2 impact per share over the last 2 years. But within this environment, we were able to grow our earnings by 10% in 2015, and we expect to grow them additionally by 15% this year. And all while driving strong free cash flow. We've used that cash to reinvest in our business, increase our dividend, pay down debt and buy back nearly $700 million in stock. 
Today, managing through economic volatility is the new normal, and it's part of our everyday operating management system. We believe that we continue to demonstrate our ability to navigate through those challenges, and because of that, we remain confident in our ability to effectively manage our business in this type of environment. 
So in total, we believe we have significant opportunities to continue creating shareholder value going forward. 
So with that, I'm going to end our formal remarks, and we'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Megan McGrath with MKM Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Megan McGrath with MKM Partners.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, a little bit of a practical question on the U.S. market in relation to the washers business. And you indicated that you're going to -- you've started cost base price increases, but you've dealt with this before in the past in terms of this
componenttext: I guess, first, a little bit of a practical question on the U.S. market in relation to the washers business. And you indicated that you're going to -- you've started cost base price increases, but you've dealt with this before in the past in terms of this dumping behavior. How, from a practical perspective, do you implement price increases in an environment where your competitors are lowering their prices aggressively?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, it's Marc Bitzer. Let me try to answer. First of all, let me first talk about what happened in Q3 in washers and what we are going to do about it going forward. First of all, in Q3, as we indicated in our remarks, we saw an increased promotional in
componenttext: Megan, it's Marc Bitzer. Let me try to answer. First of all, let me first talk about what happened in Q3 in washers and what we are going to do about it going forward. First of all, in Q3, as we indicated in our remarks, we saw an increased promotional intensity, in particular, in washers. I would say all the other categories had promotional intensity, but nothing earth-shattering or surprising to our -- from our perspective. In washers, it was more intense. To some extent, we were not completely surprised because we saw certain competitors stockpiling a lot of inventory at the end of Q2, and I think we made a remark on that during the last earnings call. The negative impact on us is kind of twofold, if you want to say. One, because obviously, we cannot and will not participate in certain value-destructing promotions. So of course, you lose the volume and, thus, the leverage in your overall production. Two, is a mix element, because if you basically have the high-end of your range by a certain competitor pulled down very much, you lose a lot of mix. To be more specific, take a typical front load washer, we have a line structure anywhere from $399 or $499 to $999 -- not $399, $499 to $999. If certain competitors bring that down to $599 or even below, it's hard to build a line structure, and therefore, you lose mix. So we had a twofold negative impact on our business. What we're going to do about it, apart from continue to invest in new product and innovation, which we are launching in the market, is two, yes, we have announced certain price increases, because we felt that certain price levels just do not reflect the cost investment we put behind products. These price effects or cost base price increases are in effect for January 1. Thirdly, as Jeff also indicated, we are continuing to pursue the antidumping lawsuits. We remain confident in our ability to win on this one So I think the combination of all these 3 elements make us believe that we can fully restore our margins in the washer business.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more? Your unit actually were up nicely in the quarter in North America. So it does look like overall, you might have gained share. It sounds like it wasn't in washers. I'm not sure if there was some growth outside th
componenttext: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more? Your unit actually were up nicely in the quarter in North America. So it does look like overall, you might have gained share. It sounds like it wasn't in washers. I'm not sure if there was some growth outside the U.S. Could you talk us through your unit growth a little bit in the quarter?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Megan, it's Marc again. First of all, let me also remind everybody on the call that our unit growth is not exactly reflective of T6 or T7 AHAM industry numbers. We said that several times before. So already, on, call it the outside the T6 or T7 volum
componenttext: Yes, Megan, it's Marc again. First of all, let me also remind everybody on the call that our unit growth is not exactly reflective of T6 or T7 AHAM industry numbers. We said that several times before. So already, on, call it the outside the T6 or T7 volume, yes, we saw a decent growth -- a solid growth in Canada, Mexico, and also in our KitchenAid SDA business which had an above-average unit growth, slightly negatively impact our ASVs, but overall, helps our margin. If you peel back the onion and you go back to T6 or T7 units, yes, we saw solid growth in refrigeration, in dishwasher and also in our kitchen business, the cooking business, but of course, in particular in the washer segment, our market share progress was not satisfying.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions if I could. Jim, could you help us with the earnings sensitivity of the pound, knowing that it weakened after the quarter? And then talk about based on the fact that you're seeing maybe increasingly weak demand in the U.K., your abil
componenttext: A couple of questions if I could. Jim, could you help us with the earnings sensitivity of the pound, knowing that it weakened after the quarter? And then talk about based on the fact that you're seeing maybe increasingly weak demand in the U.K., your ability to offset that sort of pressure next year, with subsequent price increases?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam. And to begin with, as I talked about in the script earlier in that, with the pound right now, while we are seeing some weakness to it, we still are hedged within the U.K., and so we'll continue to see ongoing weakness in the U.K. But as Marc tal
componenttext: Yes, Sam. And to begin with, as I talked about in the script earlier in that, with the pound right now, while we are seeing some weakness to it, we still are hedged within the U.K., and so we'll continue to see ongoing weakness in the U.K. But as Marc talked about earlier, our price increases are now beginning -- our previously announced price increases are beginning to take hold. And so I would say that as you look into Q4, we still will have an impact, a deteriorating impact to the pound, but it will begin to more be offset by the price increases at that point.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc. Let me maybe also give a little bit more context and color on this one. As we indicated in earlier calls, our U.K. business at the time of the acquisition was roughly about $1 billion. So it's a very significant business where we have, his
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc. Let me maybe also give a little bit more context and color on this one. As we indicated in earlier calls, our U.K. business at the time of the acquisition was roughly about $1 billion. So it's a very significant business where we have, historically, a strong market position and a strong above average operating margin. If you just look at the pure currency now, Q3 over Q3 last year, you basically have roughly 22% decline. So it's been massive. To Jim's earlier point, it has been a little bit moderated because of some hedging programs, but it's still massive. You also need to keep in mind that about 85% to -- roughly 85% of our products which we sell in the U.K. are imported or  now what's produced on a euro base. So you basically have a full year cost base impact on this one. So it's significant. The $40 million impact, which I referred to in the script, is related to, one, obviously, the margin loss because of a higher cost base; and two, we implemented a price increase in September -- or we started to implement it, and yes, we saw significant volume reduction in the month of September. The combination of these 2 things were roughly $40 million. So it's -- by definition, it's a massive impact on our operating results in Europe in Q3. To your question about the price increases and the progress, we had a small price increase in July, where we frankly had a hard time getting full traction. We had another one in September where we're seeing the traction on the invoices, but yes, we still have a drag on the volume. And we expect that drag to also be there for Q4 even though at a slightly lower level.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, to Marc's point, probably over 95% of all the products sold in the U.K. are imported. So it's -- our view is that the pricing is critical for us to get our margins back. And I think others will have to decide what they're going to do.
componenttext: And again, to Marc's point, probably over 95% of all the products sold in the U.K. are imported. So it's -- our view is that the pricing is critical for us to get our margins back. And I think others will have to decide what they're going to do.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In isolation, what's the EPS impact of just the pound for 2017 of where we are right now. Just trying to get a sense of that...
componenttext: In isolation, what's the EPS impact of just the pound for 2017 of where we are right now. Just trying to get a sense of that...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We said in third quarter, again, without -- we had the impact of the pound and we had the impact to lower demand plus this basically $40 million, which is roughly $0.40 a share. So it was really big for a quarter. But going forward, 2 things. One is the r
componenttext: We said in third quarter, again, without -- we had the impact of the pound and we had the impact to lower demand plus this basically $40 million, which is roughly $0.40 a share. So it was really big for a quarter. But going forward, 2 things. One is the rate that we get our price increase, which we said it would take at least a couple of quarters for us to work this through our system. And to Jim's point, we are normal -- we have our normal hedging process in place which will smooth out some of the volatility, but we have the whole impact due  to that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Sam, in our guidance where we talked about a 1 point impact due to currency throughout the year, what we've seen is the weakening of the pound but the strengthening of some other currencies that offset each other. So we still feel that, that is accura
componenttext: And Sam, in our guidance where we talked about a 1 point impact due to currency throughout the year, what we've seen is the weakening of the pound but the strengthening of some other currencies that offset each other. So we still feel that, that is accurate for the full basket of currencies for this year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last question before I defer to others, the cash flow guidance was lower more so at least by my math than the EPS guidance. Are you drilling down inventories outside -- I think you mentioned the EMEA, you're drawing down inventories. But where should we a
componenttext: Last question before I defer to others, the cash flow guidance was lower more so at least by my math than the EPS guidance. Are you drilling down inventories outside -- I think you mentioned the EMEA, you're drawing down inventories. But where should we anticipate inventories by year-end based on current plans?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at in our guidance, again, our free cash flow guidance is more just reflective of the lower earnings, of being at the lower end of our earnings. We went to the lower end of our free cash flow guidance. Again, inventories, we think, wil
componenttext: I think if you look at in our guidance, again, our free cash flow guidance is more just reflective of the lower earnings, of being at the lower end of our earnings. We went to the lower end of our free cash flow guidance. Again, inventories, we think, will be relatively consistent year-over-year. So I don't think you're going to see a big change there. They will come down significantly in the fourth quarter as we talked about and Marc talked about with some of the actions that we are taking.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe it's for Jeff, just start big picture. 2018, you guys have talked about earning $20 to $22 per share, and today, you're taking down your margin targets for this year -- or for the full year and you also reduced cash flow guidance. Is this kind of a
componenttext: Maybe it's for Jeff, just start big picture. 2018, you guys have talked about earning $20 to $22 per share, and today, you're taking down your margin targets for this year -- or for the full year and you also reduced cash flow guidance. Is this kind of a temporary adjustment to kind of the macro environment soft patch in the U.S. and the U.K? Or do you feel that current trends will make it a lot more difficult to get to your long-term EPS targets?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, again, it really relates to our -- the time it takes us for a recovery, as we talked about here. But nothing fundamentally has changed about what I would call our long-term strategic drivers of our earnings and free cash flow potential. So the goals
componenttext: Bob, again, it really relates to our -- the time it takes us for a recovery, as we talked about here. But nothing fundamentally has changed about what I would call our long-term strategic drivers of our earnings and free cash flow potential. So the goals we have out there, $23 billion to $24 billion, 9% to 10% EBIT, 5% to 6% free cash flow, which would equate roughly to $20 to $22 a share, we still think our global operating model certainly has the capability of delivering that. What we're dealing with right now, as you saw, is we're dealing with some fairly substantial external shocks that we had taken actions for, and some things, like as Marc mentioned, the demand in the U.S., we think, will right itself in the coming months. The U.K. is going to take longer, and we got to see the effect of this elevated promotional scheme in the U.S. But so having said all that, I would say that the goals, we feel good about. We're assessing the timing of those goals given where we are at this moment. In our January call, as we normally do, we'll give our 2017 guidance and provide you a very thorough update on our long-range goals.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. On -- and maybe you could just drill down. If you try to segregate North America, what part of the headwind was just from increased promotional activity? And what part was due to general consumer weakness? I mean, it does seem like the con
componenttext: That's helpful. On -- and maybe you could just drill down. If you try to segregate North America, what part of the headwind was just from increased promotional activity? And what part was due to general consumer weakness? I mean, it does seem like the consumer is freaked out a little bit around the election. Do you think that's kind of a transitory thing? And since the end of the quarter, just looking at shipments, do you feel the consumers kind of back in action, this is really just a lull in demand that will self-correct? Or is this something more like a change in the trajectory of what you anticipated?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's Marc. Let me just try to take it. First of all, in Q3, we still expanded margins in North America. So we moved from 12.0 to 12.1. Having said that, I mean, it's all basically a stronger environment and less promotion pressure on margin expansion
componenttext: Bob, it's Marc. Let me just try to take it. First of all, in Q3, we still expanded margins in North America. So we moved from 12.0 to 12.1. Having said that, I mean, it's all basically a stronger environment and less promotion pressure on margin expansion would have been significantly different. That's very obvious. So to your first question about the consumer demand, to some extent, it's of course, a little bit speculative of that answer. But it's -- we do see consumer -- just span of attention is right now shifting towards other topics and discretionary demand, and ultimately, yes, we see what we think is a temporary softness of consumer confidence. As you know, in our products in particular, the discretionary demand is largely driven by consumer confidence. Will that improve and recover after November 8? Probably not immediately, not the next day. But over time, we expect it to do so. If you also look at the fundamentals, and that was what we included in the presentation, in the script, the fundamentals of the housing market are 100% intact. You can look at it from whatever angle, we just don't see a slowdown of the cycle. So in the broader scheme of things, we see the consumer sentiment right now being of a very temporary nature, and we do see a full recovery in 2017.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a lot of different pieces moving here. I wonder if you could just -- if I could focus Europe on the margin reduction from the second quarter, roughly 100 bps times your sales would imply closer to kind of a $50 million EBIT headwind or $0.50. And in th
componenttext: So a lot of different pieces moving here. I wonder if you could just -- if I could focus Europe on the margin reduction from the second quarter, roughly 100 bps times your sales would imply closer to kind of a $50 million EBIT headwind or $0.50. And in the U.S., your 50 bps margin reduction on the revenue base kind of is roughly at $50 million EBIT. Yet, you didn't fully take down earnings as much as that margin reduction times sales would imply. First question, not to be too positive here, but what is the offset to that margin times sales, which is a drag? I mean, because it seems in your margin guidance, you're not really -- you're actually getting a little less productivity.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, if you look at our overall EPS guidance in that, and again, it didn't come down at the same level. You do see that we have, as I highlighted earlier, slightly better tax rate than we had before, and that is compensating for some of the earnings
componenttext: So I mean, if you look at our overall EPS guidance in that, and again, it didn't come down at the same level. You do see that we have, as I highlighted earlier, slightly better tax rate than we had before, and that is compensating for some of the earnings offset there. Again, I think that's probably the biggest driver of the offset...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing, Ken, is, obviously, with the changes that we're dealing with, we really have the strong handle on fixed cost and so on, so we've also probably reduced some corporate overhead cost. But the tax and corporate overhead are basically
componenttext: And the only other thing, Ken, is, obviously, with the changes that we're dealing with, we really have the strong handle on fixed cost and so on, so we've also probably reduced some corporate overhead cost. But the tax and corporate overhead are basically the offsets to that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate it, guys. Now just to get into the operational component. For the European 100 bps, can you isolate that relative to the pound? I mean, how much is this pound versus core market or your execution? And obviously, there's price lags for the
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate it, guys. Now just to get into the operational component. For the European 100 bps, can you isolate that relative to the pound? I mean, how much is this pound versus core market or your execution? And obviously, there's price lags for the -- but how much of that reduction is associated with the pound?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Marc. First of all, coming back, because you mentioned there is a lot of moving pieces. There are exactly 3 moving pieces that you referred to. That's a temporary slowdown in U.S. demand, that's the promotional environment in washers and the Bre
componenttext: Ken, it's Marc. First of all, coming back, because you mentioned there is a lot of moving pieces. There are exactly 3 moving pieces that you referred to. That's a temporary slowdown in U.S. demand, that's the promotional environment in washers and the Brexit-related impact. We don't have any other issues going on [indiscernible]. By definition, some of that drag we expect also in Q4 even to a lesser extent. So we do see a slight recovery of U.S. demand in Q4, not as bad as in Q3. The promotional environment in U.S., it's probably going to last in Q4, but not beyond. U.K. will be less, but still somewhat impacting Q4. So that's on a macro level. Now specifically to Europe, when you basically take the $40 million, which I referred to earlier, Brexit-related, that is an entire, or almost more than entire year-over-year drop. Or in other words, we continue to make excellent progress on the cost takeout related to the integration and the synergies, but it's been entirely offset by the impact which we had in the U.K. And that's obviously been very impactful. Will that be also impacting Q4? Yes, but to a lesser extent.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Denise Chai with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Denise Chai with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just picking up on what you're saying just now, Marc, you said that the promotional environment in the U.S. would last through the fourth quarter but not beyond. Can you comment on how washing machine inventories look at this point? I mean, is there st
componenttext: So just picking up on what you're saying just now, Marc, you said that the promotional environment in the U.S. would last through the fourth quarter but not beyond. Can you comment on how washing machine inventories look at this point? I mean, is there still an overhang heading into the fourth quarter? Or what gives you confidence that we'll see the promotional environment improve?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Denise, it's Marc. So there's -- particularly on the question of inventory, there's 2 aspects which we need to look at. One is, what is the likely inventory level of certain competitors? We knew coming into the quarter, there both have -- has been a massi
componenttext: Denise, it's Marc. So there's -- particularly on the question of inventory, there's 2 aspects which we need to look at. One is, what is the likely inventory level of certain competitors? We knew coming into the quarter, there both have -- has been a massive stockpiling coming in...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, is evidenced by the Department of Commerce...
componenttext: Now, is evidenced by the Department of Commerce...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do think, but we don't have certainty, that the large amount of inventory has been literally burned through. So there will still be some inventory overhang into Q4. Now the other side of the equation is of trade inventory. We do believe that the tra
componenttext: So we do think, but we don't have certainty, that the large amount of inventory has been literally burned through. So there will still be some inventory overhang into Q4. Now the other side of the equation is of trade inventory. We do believe that the trade inventory was slightly low coming into Q4 or low ending Q3. So it's not a massive impact, but we would expect, at least from our perspective, the trade inventories on Whirlpool brand, that our Whirlpool Corporation brand of products will be 100,000 to 150,000 below what have been last year.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I know that your Q is going to be out later this afternoon, but could you talk a little bit about just directionally gross margin was in each market? And also, if there was anything unusual in SG&A this quarter that we should be aware of?
componenttext: Okay, great. And I know that your Q is going to be out later this afternoon, but could you talk a little bit about just directionally gross margin was in each market? And also, if there was anything unusual in SG&A this quarter that we should be aware of?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at gross margin across the globe, what you'll see is it's relatively flat compared to prior year and it's in line with where our operating profit is. And so even if you break it down by the various regions, which we're going to see, it's th
componenttext: So if you look at gross margin across the globe, what you'll see is it's relatively flat compared to prior year and it's in line with where our operating profit is. And so even if you break it down by the various regions, which we're going to see, it's that the change in gross margin is very similar to what you see in the change in operating profit today. So without going through the individual ones, that's what you'll see. And I think Marc's already talked about the drivers.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to David MacGregor with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to David MacGregor with Longbow Research.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first question, I got a couple questions for you. First is just on the raw materials, and if we saw some inflation this quarter and how we should think about how raw material cost inflation for 4Q.
componenttext: Just first question, I got a couple questions for you. First is just on the raw materials, and if we saw some inflation this quarter and how we should think about how raw material cost inflation for 4Q.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, this is Jeff. Actually, I think we've been -- as we progress through the year through contracts or hedging or whatever, we're pretty stable in terms of the improvements that we saw for the full year in raw material. So I wouldn't say there's any mat
componenttext: Dave, this is Jeff. Actually, I think we've been -- as we progress through the year through contracts or hedging or whatever, we're pretty stable in terms of the improvements that we saw for the full year in raw material. So I wouldn't say there's any material change. There will be less, as we indicated I think in the last call, the second half, although improving will -- because we're going against the year-ago base, will be less of an improvement versus last year, but it'll still be positive. And then looking forward, there's a lot of moving parts, but I don't see anything in the environment that's extraordinarily unusual at this point in time. We don't -- we're pretty locked in for 2016. We're still working on 2017, which we'll talk about in January. But for now, I'd say it's stable.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just second question, I guess, the situation this quarter frames up the challenges you face in trying to defend or gain share in the competitive space. I guess my question is how are you thinking these days about the possibility of substant
componenttext: Okay. And then just second question, I guess, the situation this quarter frames up the challenges you face in trying to defend or gain share in the competitive space. I guess my question is how are you thinking these days about the possibility of substantially increasing your investment in innovation and also driving productivity on the current level of investment by holding your new product development organization accountable for a higher hit rate?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we are investing very strongly for innovation. I think we're -- never been in a better spot in terms of the rate of innovation that we bring in the marketplace. This is a globally competitive business. Productivity is always strongly part of ou
componenttext: Yes. Well, we are investing very strongly for innovation. I think we're -- never been in a better spot in terms of the rate of innovation that we bring in the marketplace. This is a globally competitive business. Productivity is always strongly part of our global operating system. And when there's opportunities to see lower raw material costs, new product [indiscernible] and so on, we can deliver very strong productivity, as we are right now. Now having said that, we've seen, and as you mentioned, certain competitors who, in our case, in the case of washing, we believe strongly are dumping imports in the U.S. market, and that's why we also are using our global trade mechanisms to try to address the situation. But you should expect more innovation from us. You should expect ongoing productivity from us. And again, as I've said before, we believe in earning market share, not buying market share.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Neal on for Mike. I appreciate the discussion around price increases and recent promotional activity. But maybe you could add a bit more color on how you feel like elasticity trending? So that's both in the consumer and retail channels. So it's ob
componenttext: This is Neal on for Mike. I appreciate the discussion around price increases and recent promotional activity. But maybe you could add a bit more color on how you feel like elasticity trending? So that's both in the consumer and retail channels. So it's obviously early to talk about 2017 raw materials, but how do you think the market could receive those higher prices?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about this in the past. There's -- at the kind of prices we're talking about, there's no elasticity. Consumers are in the marketplace probably every 10 years for a product. Their reference points is whatever they happen to look at this week o
componenttext: We've talked about this in the past. There's -- at the kind of prices we're talking about, there's no elasticity. Consumers are in the marketplace probably every 10 years for a product. Their reference points is whatever they happen to look at this week online. They have a budget. And whether it's a $399 washer or a $1,499 washer, we offer models at every price point. So again, I don't really believe in the case of the U.S., there -- it has any impact at the levels we're talking about on demand.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to -- it's Marc. Just to clarify what Jeff was referring to. There is no price elasticity on a U.S. industry demand perspective, i.e. you come down, prices doesn't change anything on our '16 or '17 industry guidance. There is, however, a short-term i
componenttext: Just to -- it's Marc. Just to clarify what Jeff was referring to. There is no price elasticity on a U.S. industry demand perspective, i.e. you come down, prices doesn't change anything on our '16 or '17 industry guidance. There is, however, a short-term impact if somebody else promotes a front-load washer at $499 while our range starts at $699. Of course, we feel that and that is what we referred to.

componenttext: Yes, it's Marc. So first of all, obviously, hard for us to comment on any competitor because we don't talk to them. In simple terms, first of all, you got to bear in mind the integration is still fairly fresh. So it's been just 1 or slightly more than a quarter behind it. And so far, I don't see any different behavior. GE has been a very tough competitor, and I think they continue to be that. So we don't see a massive change in their behavior contrary to what sometimes have been speculated about.

componenttext: I just had a question on North America. I saw the volumes were very nice. But from a price/mix standpoint, maybe if you could provide a little bit more color on the moving pieces. I know that FX had, I think, about 1 point of an impact that you talked about product launches and sort of what's going on with washers. But is there -- are there any other elements that are sort of dragging on mix, given that you've got all these product launches and I would expect some positive price/mix.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Marc again. So let me maybe just give a little bit perspective. And of course, first of all, in our unit numbers, there's a lot of moving pieces. There's Canada, Mexico with different currency elements. Having said that, if you want to kind of p
componenttext: Yes, it's Marc again. So let me maybe just give a little bit perspective. And of course, first of all, in our unit numbers, there's a lot of moving pieces. There's Canada, Mexico with different currency elements. Having said that, if you want to kind of pinpoint 2 elements which explains the slight ASV decline, average sales value decline, is, one, is what we related to earlier, is the promotion intensity in washers; and two, yes, we had higher KitchenAid small domestic appliance growth. Quite a bit above our average growth in the region, which negatively impacts the average sales value, but knowing that it's a very strong margin product. it helps our profitability.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. First of all, on the market share, and I hear the comment that KitchenAid small appliances had a good quarter. Can you just give us some context of your growth relative to AHAM 6 flat in the quarter? Just trying to gauge a more accu
componenttext: Two questions for you. First of all, on the market share, and I hear the comment that KitchenAid small appliances had a good quarter. Can you just give us some context of your growth relative to AHAM 6 flat in the quarter? Just trying to gauge a more accurate evaluation of your market share gains, because it doesn't sound like the 7 versus 0 is the right compare. And then secondly, curious, Jeff, as you think about the benefit from the antidumping ruling coming in January, how we should be thinking about how that might influence the industry and your performance in 2017.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, it's Marc. Let me first try to answer the share perspective. Overall, as we commented earlier, we roughly had a 1 point of share growth year-over-year. That is, of course, the result of moving elements -- of different elements. First of all, if you
componenttext: Eric, it's Marc. Let me first try to answer the share perspective. Overall, as we commented earlier, we roughly had a 1 point of share growth year-over-year. That is, of course, the result of moving elements -- of different elements. First of all, if you split by product, our washer market share has not been there. Actually, year-over-year, it's been disappointing. Having said that, that also means in refrigeration, dishwashing and cooking, we had almost more than 1 share point of growth. [indiscernible] actually very satisfying. Then you have the other component which is the branded versus non-branded part of our sales. As you can imagine, the not own-brand piece, which is largely for our  big customer, that has been coming down year-over-year, but the branded piece has seen very strong growth in the entire Q3.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Eric, regarding the antidumping, first of all, just a reminder on the process. In December, it's expected the Department of Commerce will establish the final tariffs. And you may remember, the preliminary tariffs were over 50% for one competitor
componenttext: Yes. And Eric, regarding the antidumping, first of all, just a reminder on the process. In December, it's expected the Department of Commerce will establish the final tariffs. And you may remember, the preliminary tariffs were over 50% for one competitor and over 100% for another one. So they're substantial. And then -- so that will happen in December. And then the ITC will make the final ruling on -- that dumping has caused injury to the washer business in the U.S., and we expect that ruling in January. So at that point in time, and we do see assume we're going to be successful here, then those competitors will have to pay really high tariffs or they'll have to do something else. And at the same time -- and again, I don't want to over emphasize this, but as Marc said, I mean,  we had one competitor in the second quarter ship in months and months of supply in advance of trying to -- as the DOC ruled, beat the cash deposits. And unloading that inventory in the third, and perhaps, part of the fourth quarter, has been a real strain on the operating margins and has caused a lot of injury to the washer business. So basically, again I can't speak what competitors are going to do. I know we're going to run our business in an economical way. We're going to earn our market share through great products, and we're fully -- but we fully expect to make positive margins on them as well.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given your view that the U.S. trends are temporary, Marc, what would lead you to think that it's not temporary, I guess?  I mean, I saw the macro slide that you guys have in your deck, but what variables would you -- lead you to think that things are kind
componenttext: Given your view that the U.S. trends are temporary, Marc, what would lead you to think that it's not temporary, I guess?  I mean, I saw the macro slide that you guys have in your deck, but what variables would you -- lead you to think that things are kind of slowing versus these long-term rates that you look at for the U.S. markets specifically?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, it's Marc. I mean, again, if you look at the fundamentals -- first of all, on demand trends of housing, household formations intact, unemployment is getting better, income is finally arriving in mid-and lower income levels. So you have a lot of --
componenttext: Again, it's Marc. I mean, again, if you look at the fundamentals -- first of all, on demand trends of housing, household formations intact, unemployment is getting better, income is finally arriving in mid-and lower income levels. So you have a lot of -- and mortgages and affordability is still very positive. So you have a lot of the positive trends there. We always argued for the last 3 years, and I would still argue, the entire, call it, housing boom has been a little bit constrained by the supply side. There has not been enough developed lots. When we had issues about getting enough construction workers, so there's been a severe supply constraint, which also explains a little bit why the house prices came up so quickly. So there was a constraint, which we slowly see easing, but not a rapid pace. So if you want to find any negative which could impact that, you can put up theories then. Of course, if the Fed rates would come up too fast, too quickly, that could have an impact. I don't think that's likely, but I don't know. But outside of this one, you would have to find any macro economic shocks outside the housing industry and appliance industry which could impact consumer in such confidence.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, I would just add, as Marc mentioned, the fundamentals of appliance demand all are still very strong, and we think will be for some time. If you look at the trends, it was an odd trend. The first half was up 5%, and July, August were down about 5%
componenttext: And Ken, I would just add, as Marc mentioned, the fundamentals of appliance demand all are still very strong, and we think will be for some time. If you look at the trends, it was an odd trend. The first half was up 5%, and July, August were down about 5%. That's a 10-point swing. You don't see that very often. And then, we look at other household product categories and we saw similar trends. So I think both the data suggests that the consumer got cautious. Typically, that doesn't last for long periods of time, particularly when there's certainty ahead. And that's why we have confidence we'll continue to see growth.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Denise. It's -- I wouldn't consider that a big change. It's just the timing of certain projects when we started them, where all the major innovation that we expected to get out this year, we are.  Obviously, we're managing things tightly, but we're c
componenttext: Yes, Denise. It's -- I wouldn't consider that a big change. It's just the timing of certain projects when we started them, where all the major innovation that we expected to get out this year, we are.  Obviously, we're managing things tightly, but we're certainly not cutting back on anything that we're bringing in the marketplace. We've got a full pipeline ready for 2017, so this is just probably more timing than anything else.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then can you talk a little bit more about European demand ex the U.K.? I mean, if you just isolate the U.K., how much were volumes down compared to the rest of Europe? And generally, how has the U.K. trended since Brexit?
componenttext: Got it. And then can you talk a little bit more about European demand ex the U.K.? I mean, if you just isolate the U.K., how much were volumes down compared to the rest of Europe? And generally, how has the U.K. trended since Brexit?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Denise, it's Marc. So first of all, let's differentiate overall industry trends from our own demand, which we'll see. I would say, overall, the European market -- and we don't yet have a final sell-in data for Europe -- I would expect them to be clos
componenttext: Yes. Denise, it's Marc. So first of all, let's differentiate overall industry trends from our own demand, which we'll see. I would say, overall, the European market -- and we don't yet have a final sell-in data for Europe -- I would expect them to be closer to 2%. We earlier indicated 0% to 2% for the full year. And in Q3, I would expect it right now somewhere between 1.5% and 2%. But it's too early because we don't have the final data. Also on a full year basis, I would say the entire European market still in 0% to 2%, probably ending close to over 2%. So the fundamentals of demand in Europe are not that horrible. It's the currency which impacts a lot. If you kind of peel back the onion, of course, there's a lot of moving pieces. I think for us, the most promising sign going forward, we start seeing recovery in Russia and Ukraine. That's an early sign. But you know we're -- in this acquisition, we're very exposed to both U.K. and Russia. And right now, both markets are very soft from currency and demand. But we see Russia slowly coming back. And now, it's too early to yet call it a recovery, but I would say the early signs have been promising. Now specific to our demand, for us, U.K. markets did better as a market than we saw in our demand. And that is directly related to us coming out of a price increase in September, which the rest of the industry did not fully follow and that impacted our demand. That's the particular impact. Outside of the U.K., I would say by and large, our demand is solid. Probably the only other exception will be Middle East and Africa, which is still impacted by a lot of uncertainty in demand and by the entire space.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Marc. Yes, I referred to year-over-year down volume on the private label side of our business. That is true. Not entirely surprising, consistent with prior trends. More than offset in our branded business. So Whirlpool, Maytag, KitchenAid are
componenttext: David, it's Marc. Yes, I referred to year-over-year down volume on the private label side of our business. That is true. Not entirely surprising, consistent with prior trends. More than offset in our branded business. So Whirlpool, Maytag, KitchenAid are all going extremely well. JCPenney, as we discussed earlier, we monitor them. We still consider it a pilot. It's still not yet proven to be, in our view, fully successful, and we will see. But we will monitor it. And we always said we will ultimately have our brand where we believe the consumer distribution, consumer demand will be. So this is not a final call or decision. We're monitoring it.
